act scene
london an ante chamber king's palace
enter archbishop canterbury bishop ely
canterbury lord i'll tell self bill urg'd
which th' eleventh year last king's reign
was had indeed against us pass'd
did push out farther question
ely but how lord shall resist now
canterbury must thought if pass against us
lose better half our possession
all temporal lands which men devout
by testament have given church
would they strip from us being valu'd thus
as much as would maintain king's honour
full fifteen earls fifteen hundred knights
relief lazars weak age
indigent faint souls past corporal toil
hundred alms houses right well supplied
coffers king beside
thousand pounds by th' year thus runs bill
ely this would drink deep
canterbury 't would drink cup all
ely but what prevention
canterbury king full grace fair regard
canterbury courses his youth promis'd not
breath no sooner left his father's body
but his wildness mortified him
seem'd die too yea at very moment
consideration an angel came
whipp'd th' offending adam out him
leaving his body as paradise
t'envelop contain celestial spirits
never was such sudden scholar made
such heady currance scouring faults
nor never hydra headed wilfulnes
so soon did lose his seat all at once
as this king
ely are blessed change
canterbury hear him but reason divinity
all admiring an inward wish
would desire king were made prelate
hear him debate commonwealth affairs
list his discourse war shall hear
fearful battle rend'red music
turn him any cause policy
gordian knot he will unloose
familiar as his garter when he speaks
air charter'd libertine still
mute wonder lurketh mens ears
steal his sweet honey'd sentences
so art practic part life
which wonder how his grace should glean
since his addiction was courses vain
his companies unletter'd rude shallow
his hours filld up riots banquets sports
never noted him any study
any retirement any sequestration
from open haunts popularity
ely strawberry grows underneath nettle
wholesome berries thrive ripen best
so prince obscur'd his contemplation
under veil wildness which no doubt
grew summer grass fastest by night
unseen yet crescive his faculty
canterbury must so miracles are ceas'd
therefore must needs admit means
how things are perfected
ely but good lord
how now mitigation this bill
incline or no
canterbury he seems indifferent
or rather swaying more upon our part
than cherishing th' exhibiters against us
have made an offer his majesty
upon our spiritual convocation
regard causes now hand
which have opend his grace at large
as touching france give greater sum
did his predecessors part withal
ely how did this offer seem receiv'd lord
canterbury good acceptance his majesty
save there was not time enough hear
as perceiv'd his grace would fain have done
severals unhidden passages
his true tides some certain dukedoms
generally crown seat france
deriv'd from edward his great grandfather
canterbury french ambassador upon instant
crav'd audience hour think come
give him hearing four o'clock
ely
canterbury then go know his embassy
which could ready guess declare
before frenchman speak word

scene ii
enter king gloucester bedford exeter warwick westmoreland
attendants
king henry where gracious lord canterbury
exeter not here presence
king henry send him good uncle
westmoreland shall call th' ambassador liege
king henry not yet cousin would resolv'd
before hear him some things weight
task our thoughts concerning us france
bishop ely
canterbury god his angels guard sacred throne
make long become
king henry sure thank
learned lord pray proceed
justly religiously unfold
why law salique they have france
or should or should not bar us our claim
god forbid dear faithful lord
or nicely charge understanding soul
opening titles miscreate whose right
suits not native colours truth
god doth know how many now health
shall drop their blood approbation
what reverence shall incite us
therefore take heed how impawn our person
how awake our sleeping sword war
charge name god take heed
without much fall blood whose guiltless drops
are every one woe sore complaint
'gainst him whose wrongs gives edge unto swords
makes such waste brief mortality
under this conjuration speak lord
will hear note believe heart
what speak conscience wash'd
as pure as sin baptism
canterbury then hear gracious sovereign peers
this imperial throne there no bar
make against highness' claim france
but this which they produce from pharamond
'in terram salicam mulieres ne succedant'
'no woman shall succeed salique land'
which salique land french unjustly gloze
realm france pharamond
founder this law female bar
yet their own authors faithfully affirm
between floods sala elbe
where charles great having subdu'd saxons
there left behind settled certain french
who holding disdain german women
some dishonest manners their life
establish'd then this law wit no female
should inheritrix salique land
which salique as said 'twixt elbe sala
at this day germany calld meisen
was not devised realm france
nor did french possess salique land
until four hundred one twenty years
after defunction king pharamond
idly suppos'd founder this law
who died within year our redemption
four hundred twenty six charles great
subdu'd saxons did seat french
beyond river sala year
king pepin which deposed childeric
did as heir general being descended
blithild which was daughter king clothair
make claim title crown france
hugh capet also who usurp'd crown
charles duke lorraine sole heir male
true line stock charles great
find his title some shows truth
though pure truth was corrupt naught
daughter charlemain who was son
lewis emperor lewis son
charles great also king lewis tenth
who was sole heir usurper capet
could not keep quiet his conscience
wearing crown france till satisfied
fair queen isabel his grandmother
was lineal lady ermengare
daughter charles foresaid duke lorraine
was re united crown france
so as clear as summer's sun
king pepins title hugh capet's claim
king lewis his satisfaction all appear
hold right tide female
so do kings france unto this day
howbeit they would hold up this salique law
bar highness claiming from female
rather choose hide them net
usurp'd from progenitors
king henry may right conscience make this claim
canterbury sin upon head dread sovereign
book numbers writ
when man dies let inheritance
descend unto daughter gracious lord
stand own unwind bloody flag
look back into mighty ancestors
go dread lord great grandsire's tomb
great uncle's edward black prince
who french ground play'd tragedy
making defeat fun power france
whiles his most mighty father hill
stood smiling behold his lions whelp
forage blood french nobility
o noble english could entertain
half their forces full pride france
let another half stand laughing by
ely awake remembrance these valiant dead
puissant arm renew their feats
are their heir sit upon their throne
blood courage renowned them
runs veins thrice puissant liege
very may morn his youth
ripe exploits mighty enterprises
exeter brother kings monarchs earth
do all expect should rouse yourself
westmoreland they know grace hath cause means might
so hath highness never king england
had nobles richer more loyal subjects
whose hearts have left their bodies here england
lie paviliond fields france
canterbury o let their bodies follow dear liege
blood sword fire win right
aid whereof spiritualty
will raise highness such mighty sum
bring any ancestors
king henry must not only arm t' invade french
but lay down our proportions defend
against scot who will make road upon us
all advantages
canterbury they those marches gracious sovereign
shall wall sufficient defend
our inland from pilfering borderers
king henry do not mean coursing snatchers only
who hath been still giddy neighbour us
shall read great grandfather
never went his forces into france
but scot his unfurnish'd kingdom
came pouring tide into breach
ample brim fulness his force
galling gleaned land hot assays
girdling grievous siege castles towns
england being empty defence
canterbury she hath been then more fear'd than harm'd liege
hear her but exampled by herself
when all her chivalry hath been france
she mourning widow her nobles
she hath herself not only well defended
but taken impounded as stray
king scots whom she did send france
fill king edward's fame prisoner kings
make her chronicle as rich praise
sunken wreck sumless treasuries
westmoreland but there's saying very old true
'if will france win
then scotland first begin'
once eagle england being prey
her unguarded nest weasel scot
comes sneaking so sucks her princely eggs
playing mouse absence cat
tear havoc more than she can eat
yet but crush'd necessity
since have locks safeguard necessaries
pretty traps catch petty thieves
while armed hand doth fight abroad
th' advised head defends itself at home
government though high low lower
put into parts doth keep one consent
congreeing full natural close
music
state man divers functions
setting endeavour continual motion
which fixed as an aim or but
obedience so work honey bees
creatures by rule nature teach
act order peopled kingdom
they have king officers sorts
where some magistrates correct at home
others merchants venture trade abroad
make boot upon summer's velvet buds
which pillage they merry march bring home
tent royal their emperor
who busied his majesty surveys
singing masons building roofs gold
civil citizens kneading up honey
poor mechanic porters crowding
their heavy burdens at his narrow gate
sad ey'd justice his surly hum
lazy yawning drone this infer
many things having full reference
one consent may work contrariously
as many arrows loosed several ways
come one mark as many ways meet one town
as many fresh streams meet one salt sea
as many lines close dials centre
so many thousand actions once afoot
end one purpose all well home
divide happy england into four
whereof take one quarter into france
withal shall make all gallia shake
if thrice such powers left at home
cannot defend our own doors from dog
let us worried our nation lose
name hardiness policy
king henry call messengers sent from dauphin
exeunt some attendants
yours noble sinews our power
france being ours we'll bend our awe
or break all pieces or there we'll sit
ruling large ample empery
o'er france all her almost kingly dukedoms
or lay these bones an unworthy urn
tombless no remembrance over them
either our history shall full mouth
speak freely our acts or else our grave
not worshipp'd waxen epitaph
enter ambassadors france
now are well prepar'd know pleasure
our fair cousin dauphin hear
greeting from him not from king
ambassador may't please majesty give us leave
freely render what have charge
or shall sparingly show far
dauphins meaning our embassy
unto whose grace our passion as subject
as are our wretches fett'red our prisons
therefore frank uncurbed plainness
tell us dauphins mind
ambassador thus then few
highness lately sending into france
did claim some certain dukedoms right
great predecessor king edward third
answer which claim prince our master
bids advis'd there's nought france
can nimble galliard won
cannot revel into dukedoms there
he therefore sends meeter spirit
this tun treasure lieu this
desires let dukedoms claim
hear no more this dauphin speaks
king henry what treasure uncle
exeter tennis balls liege
his present pains thank
when have match'd our rackets these balls
will france by god's grace play set
shall strike his father's crown into hazard
tell him he hath made match such wrangler
all courts france will disturb'd
chaces understand him well
how he comes o'er us our wilder days
not measuring what use made them
therefore living hence did give ourself
barbarous licence as 'tis ever common
men are merriest when they are from home
but tell dauphin will keep state
king show sail greatness
when do rouse throne france
have laid by majesty
plodded man working days
but will rise there so full glory
yea strike dauphin blind look us
tell pleasant prince this mock his
hath turnd his balls gun stones his soul
shall stand sore charged wasteful vengeance
shall fly them many thousand widows
shall this his mock mock their dear husbands
mock mothers from their sons mock castles down
some are yet ungotten unborn
shall have cause curse dauphins scorn
whom do appeal whose name
tell dauphin am coming
venge as may put forth
rightful hand well hallow'd cause
so get hence peace tell dauphin
his jest will savour but shallow wit
when thousands weep more than did laugh at
convey them safe conduct fare well
exeunt ambassadors
king henry hope make sender blush at
therefore lords omit no happy hour
may give furth'rance our expedition
have now no thought us but france
save those god run before our business
therefore let our proportions these wars
soon collected all things thought upon
may reasonable swiftness ad
more feathers our wings god before
therefore let every man now task his thought
this fair action may foot brought exeunt
act ii prologue
flourish enter chorus
chorus now all youth england are fire
silken dalliance wardrobe lies
now thrive armourers honour's thought
reigns solely breast every man
they sell pasture now buy horse
winged heels as english mercuries
now sits expectation air
hides sword from hilts unto point
crowns imperial crowns coronets
promis'd harry his followers
french advis'd by good intelligence
this most dreadful preparation
shake their fear pale policy
seek divert english purposes
little body mighty heart
what mightst thou do honour would thee do
were all thy children kind natural
but see thy fault france hath thee found out
nest hollow bosoms which he fills
treacherous crowns three corrupted men
one richard earl cambridge second
henry lord scroop masham third
sir thomas grey knight northumberland
confirm'd conspiracy fearful france
by their hands this grace kings must die
if hell treason hold their promises
ere he take ship france southampton
linger patience we'll digest
th' abuse distance force play
sum paid traitors are agreed
king set from london scene
now transported gentles southampton
thence france shall convey safe
bring back charming narrow seas
give gentle pass if may
we'll not offend one stomach our play
but till king come forth not till then
unto southampton do shift our scene exit
scene
london before boar's head tavern eastcheap
enter corporal nym lieutenant bardolph
nym good morrow lieutenant bardolph
bardolph what are ancient pistol friends yet
nym part care not say little but when time shall
serve there shall smiles but shall as may dare
not fight but will wink hold out mine iron simple
one but what though will toast cheese will endure
cold as another mans sword will there's an end
bardolph will bestow breakfast make friends we'll
all three sworn brothers france let't so good corporal
nym faith will live so long as may that's certain
when cannot live any longer will do as may
rest rendezvous
bardolph certain corporal he married nell
quickly certainly she did wrong were
troth plight her
nym cannot tell things must as they may men may sleep
they may have their throats about them at time some say
knives have edges must as may though patience
cannot tell
enter pistol hostess
bardolph here comes ancient pistol his wife good corporal
patient here
nym how now mine host pistol
pistol base tike callst thou host
now by this hand swear scorn term
nor shall nell keep lodgers

another fall man their faults are open

french king's palace

give our vineyards barbarous people
dauphin o dieu vivant shall few sprays us
emptying our fathers' luxury

spirt up so suddenly into clouds
overlook their grafters
britaine normans but bastard normans norman bastards
unfought withal but will sell dukedom
buy slobb'ry dirty farm
nook shotten isle albion
constable dieu de batailles where have they this mettle
not their climate foggy raw dull
whom as despite sun looks pale
killing their fruit frowns can sodden water
drench sur reind jades their barley broth
decoct their cold blood such valiant heat
seem frosty o honour our land
let us not hang roping icicles
upon our houses' thatch whiles more frosty people
sweat drops gallant youth our rich fields
poor call them their native lords
dauphin by faith honour
our madams mock at us plainly say
our mettle bred out they will give
their bodies lust english youth
britaine they bid us english dancing schools
teach lavoltas high swift corantos
saying our grace only our heels
are most lofty runaways
french king where montjoy herald speed him hence
let him greet england our sharp defiance
up princes spirit honour edged
more sharper than swords hie field
charles delabreth high constable france
alengon brabant bar burgundy
jaques chatillon rambures vaudemont
beaumont grandpre roussi fauconbridge
foix lestrake bouciqualt charolois
high dukes great princes barons lords knights
great seats now quit great shames
bar harry england sweeps through our land
pennons painted blood harfleur
rush his host as doth melted snow
alps doth spit void his rheum upon
go down upon him have power enough
captive chariot into rouen
bring him our prisoner
constable this becomes great
sorry am his numbers are so few
his soldiers sick famish'd their march
am sure when he shall see our army
he'll drop his heart into sink fear
french king therefore lord constable haste montjoy
let him say england send
know what willing ransom he will give
prince dauphin shall stay us rouen
dauphin not so do beseech majesty
french king patient shall remain us
now forth lord constable princes all
quickly bring us word england's fall exeunt

king henry unfold

england shall repent his folly see his weakness admire our

montjoy montjoy

without impeachment say sooth
though 'tis no wisdom confess so much
unto an enemy craft vantage
people are sickness much enfeebled
numbers lessend those few have
almost no better than so many french
who when they were health tell thee herald
thought upon one pair english legs
did march three frenchmen yet forgive god
hath blown vice must repent
go therefore tell thy master here am

army but weak sickly guard
yet god before tell him will come
though france himself such another neighbour

if may pass will if hind'red

sum all our answer but this
would not seek battle as are
nor as are say will not shun

act iv prologue
enter chorus
chorus now entertain conjecture time
when creeping murmur poring dark
from camp camp through foul womb night
hum either army stilly sounds
fix'd sentinels almost receive
secret whispers each other's watch
fire answers fire through their paly flames
each battle sees other's umber'd face
steed threatens steed high boastful neighs
piercing night's dull ear from tents
armourers accomplishing knights
give dreadful note preparation
country cocks do crow clocks do ton
third hour drowsy morning name
proud their numbers secure soul
confident over lusty french
do low rated english play at dice
chide cripple tardy gaited night
who foul ugly witch doth limp
so tediously away poor condemned english
sit patiently inly ruminate
morning's danger their gesture sad
investing lank lean cheeks war worn coats
presenteth them unto gazing moon
so many horrid ghosts o now who will behold
royal captain this ruind band
walking from watch watch from tent tent
let him cry 'praise glory his head'
forth he goes visits all his host
calls them brothers friends countrymen
upon his royal face there no note
how dread an army hath enrounded him
nor doth he dedicate one jot colour
unto weary all watched night
but freshly looks over bears attaint
cheerful semblance sweet majesty
every wretch pining pale before
beholding him plucks comfort from his looks
his liberal eye doth give every one
thawing cold fear mean gentle all
behold as may unworthiness define
little touch harry night
so our scene must battle fly
where o pity shall much disgrace
four or five most vile ragged foils
right ill dispos'd brawl ridiculous
name agincourt yet sit see
scene
france english camp at agincourt
enter king bedford gloucester
king henry gloucester 'tis true are great danger
greater therefore should our courage
good morrow brother bedford god almighty
there some soul goodness things evil
would men observingly distil out
our bad neighbour makes us early stirrers
besides they are our outward consciences
preachers us all admonishing
should dress us fairly our end
thus may gather honey from weed
make moral devil himself
enter erpingham
good morrow old sir thomas erpingham
good soft pillow good white head
were better than churlish turf france
since may say 'now lie king'
king henry 'tis good men love their present pains
upon example so spirit eased
when mind quick'ned out doubt
organs though defunct dead before
break up their drowsy grave newly move
casted slough fresh legerity
lend thy cloak sir thomas brothers both
commend princes our camp
desire them all pavilion
gloucester shall liege
erpingham shall attend grace
king henry no good knight
go brothers lords england
bosom must debate awhile
then would no other company
erpingham lord heaven bless thee noble harry
exeunt all but king

empty

king henry friend
king henry under sir thomas erpingham
williams good old commander most kind gentleman pray
what thinks he our estate
king henry even as men wreck'd upon sand look wash'd
off next tide
bates he hath not told his thought king
king henry no nor not meet he should though speak
think king but man as am violet smells
him as doth element shows him as doth
by his nakedness he appears but man though his
affections are higher mounted than ours yet when they stoop
they stoop wing therefore when he sees reason
fears as do his fears out doubt same relish
as ours are yet reason no man should possess him any
appearance fear lest he by showing should dishearten his
empty
bates he may show what outward courage he will but believe as
cold night as 'tis he could wish himself thames up
were quit here
king henry by troth will speak conscience king
think he would not wish himself anywhere but where he
bates then would he were here alone so should he sure
ransomed many poor mens lives saved
king henry dare say love him not so ill wish him here
alone howsoever speak this feel other mens minds
methinks could not die anywhere so contented as king's
company his cause being just his quarrel honourable
bates ay or more than should seek after know enough if
know are king's subjects if his cause wrong our
obedience king wipes crime out us
williams but if cause not good king himself hath
heavy reckoning make when all those legs arms heads
chopp'd off battle shall join together at latter day
cry all 'we died at such place' some swearing some crying
surgeon some upon their wives left poor behind them some
upon debts they owe some upon their children rawly left
can they charitably dispose anything when blood their
argument now if these men do not die well will black
matter king led them who disobey were
against all proportion subjection
king henry so if son by his father sent about
merchandise do sinfully miscarry upon sea imputation
his wickedness by rule should imposed upon his father
sent him or if servant under his master's command
transporting sum money assailed by robbers die
master author servant's damnation but this not so
king not bound answer particular endings his
soldiers father his son nor master his servant
they purpose not their death when they purpose their
services besides there no king his cause never so
spotless if come arbitrement swords can try out
all unspotted soldiers some peradventure have them
guilt premeditated contrived murder some beguiling
virgins broken seals perjury some making wars
pillage robbery now if these men have defeated law
outrun native punishment though they can outstrip men they
have no wings fly from god war his beadle war his
vengeance so here men are punish'd before breach
king's laws now king's quarrel where they feared
death they have borne life away where they would safe
they perish then if they die unprovided no more king
guilty their damnation than he was before guilty those
impieties which they are now visited every subject's
therefore should every soldier wars do as every sick man
his bed wash every mote out his conscience dying so
death him advantage or not dying time was blessedly
lost wherein such preparation was gained him escapes
were not sin think making god so free an offer he
let him outlive day see his greatness teach
others how they should prepare
williams 'tis certain every man dies ill ill upon his
own head king not answer
fight lustily him
king henry myself heard king say he would not ransom'd
williams ay he said so make us fight cheerfully but when our
throats are cut he may ransom'd ne'er wiser
king henry if live see will never trust his word after
williams pay him then that's perilous shot out an
elder gun poor private displeasure can do against
monarch may as well go about turn sun ice
fanning his face peacock's feather you'll never trust
king henry reproof something too round should angry
if time were convenient
williams let quarrel between us if live
king henry embrace
williams how shall know thee again
king henry give any gage thine will wear
bonnet then if ever thou dar'st acknowledge will make
quarrel

empty

bates friends english fools friends have

no english treason cut french crowns morrow

exeunt soldiers
upon king let us our lives our souls
our debts our careful wives
our children our sins lay king
must bear all o hard condition
every fool whose sense no more can feel
but his own wringing what infinite heart's ease
must kings neglect private men enjoy
what have kings privates have not too
save ceremony save general ceremony
what art thou thou idol ceremony
what kind god art thou suffer'st more
mortal griefs than do thy worshippers
what are thy rents what are thy comings
what thy soul adoration
art thou aught else but place degree form
creating awe fear other men
wherein thou art less happy being fear'd
than they fearing
what drink'st thou oft instead homage sweet
but poisond flattery o sick great greatness
bid thy ceremony give thee cure
thinks thou fiery fever will go out
will give place flexure low bending
canst thou when thou command'st beggar's knee
command health no thou proud dream
play'st so subtly king's repose
am king find thee know
'tis not balm sceptre ball
sword mace crown imperial
intertissued robe gold pearl
farced tide running fore king
beats upon high shore this world
no not all these thrice gorgeous ceremony
not all these laid bed majestical
can sleep so soundly as wretched slave
who body filld vacant mind
gets him rest cramm'd distressful bread
never sees horrid night child hell
but lackey from rise set
sweats eye pheebus all night
doth rise help hyperion his horse
follows so ever running year
profitable labour his grave
but ceremony such wretch
winding up days toil nights sleep
had fore hand vantage king
slave member country's peace
enjoys but gross brain little wots
what watch king keeps maintain peace

erpingham lord nobles jealous absence
seek through camp find
king good old knight
collect them all together at tent
i'll before thee
erpingham shall do't lord exit
king o god battles steel soldiers' hearts
possess them not fear take from them now
pluck their hearts from them not day o lord
o not day think not upon fault
father made compassing crown
richard's body have interred new
have bestowed more contrite tears
than from issued forced drops blood
five hundred poor have yearly pay
who twice day their wither'd hands hold up
toward heaven pardon blood have built
sing still richard's soul more will do
though all can do nothing worth
since penitence comes after all
imploring pardon

gloucester liege

enter messenger
messenger english are embattld french peers
constable horse gallant princes straight horse
fair show shall suck away their souls
leaving them but shales husks men
there not work enough all our hands
scarce blood enough all their sickly veins
give each naked curtle axe stain
our french gallants shall day draw out
sheathe lack sport let us but blow them
vapour our valour will o'erturn them
'tis positive 'gainst all exceptions lords
who unnecessary action swarm
about our squares battle were enow
purge this field such hilding foe
though upon this mountains basis by
took stand idle speculation
but our honours must not what's say
very little little let us do
all done then let trumpets sound
tucket sonance note mount
england shall couch down fear yield
enter grandpre
grandpre why do stay so long lords france
yond island carrions desperate their bones
ill favouredly become morning field
their ragged curtains poorly are let loose
our air shakes them passing scornfully
big mars seems bankrupt their beggar'd host
faintly through rusty beaver peeps
torch staves their hand their poor jades
lob down their heads dropping hides hips
gum down roping from their pale dead eyes
their pale dull mouths gimmald bit
lies foul chaw'd grass still motionless
their executors knavish crows
fly o'er them all impatient their hour
description cannot suit itself words
demonstrate life such battle
constable they have said their prayers they stay death
dauphin shall go send them dinners fresh suits
give their fasting horses provender
after fight them
constable stay but guidon field
will banner from trumpet take
use haste come come away
sun high outwear day exeunt
scene iii
enter gloucester bedford exeter erpingham all his host

bedford he as full valour as kindness
princely both
westmoreland o now had here
but one ten thousand those men england
do no work day
king what's he wishes so
cousin westmoreland no fair cousin
if are mark'd die are enow
do our country loss if live
fewer men greater share honour
god's will pray thee wish not one man more
nor care who doth feed upon cost
yearns not if men garments wear
such outward things dwell not desires
but if sin covet honour
am most offending soul alive
no faith coz wish not man from england
god's peace would not lose so great an honour
as one man more methinks would share from
best hope have o do not wish one more
he which hath no stomach this fight
let him depart his passport shall made
crowns convoy put into his purse
would not die mans company
fears his fellowship die us
this day calld feast crispian
he outlives this day comes safe home
will stand tip toe when this day nam'd
rouse him at name crispian
will yearly vigil feast his neighbours
say 'to morrow saint crispian'
then will he strip his sleeve show his scars
say 'these wounds had crispians day'
old men forget yet all shall forgot
but he'll remember advantages
what feats he did day then shall our names
familiar his mouth as household words
harry king bedford exeter
their flowing cups freshly rememb'red
this story shall good man teach his son
crispin crispian shall ne'er go by
from this day ending world
but shall remembered
few happy few band brothers
he day sheds his blood
shall brother he ne'er so vile
this day shall gentle his condition
shall think themselves accurs'd they were not here
hold their manhoods cheap whiles any speaks
fought us upon saint crispins day
re enter salisbury
salisbury sovereign lord bestow yourself speed
french are bravely their battles set
will all expedience charge us
king henry all things are ready if our minds so
westmoreland perish man whose mind backward now
westmoreland god's will liege would alone
without more help could fight this royal battle

which likes better than wish us one
know places god all
tucket enter montjoy
montjoy once more come know thee king harry
if thy ransom thou wilt now compound
before thy most assured overthrow
thou needs must englutted besides mercy
constable desires thee thou wilt mind
thy followers repentance their souls
may make peaceful sweet retire
from off these fields where wretches their poor bodies
must lie fester
king henry who hath sent thee now
montjoy constable france
king henry pray thee bear former answer back
good god why should they mock poor fellows thus
man once did sell lions skin
while beast liv'd was killd hunting him
many our bodies shall no doubt
find native graves upon which trust
shall witness live brass this day's work
those leave their valiant bones france
dying men though buried dunghills
they shall fam'd there sun shall greet them
leaving their earthly parts choke clime
smell whereof shall breed plague france
mark then abounding valour our english
being dead bullet's grazing
break out into second course mischief
killing relapse mortality
let speak proudly tell constable
are but warriors working day
our gayness our gilt are all besmirch'd
there's not piece feather our host
good argument hope will not fly
time hath worn us into slovenry
but by mass our hearts are trim
poor soldiers tell yet ere night
they'll fresher robes or they will pluck
gay new coats o'er french soldiers' heads
turn them out service if they do this
as if god please they shall ransom then
come thou no more ransom gentle herald
they shall have none swear but these joints
which if they have as will leave 'em them
shall yield them little tell constable
montjoy shall king harry so fare thee well
thou never shalt hear herald any more exit
king henry fear thou wilt once more come again ransom
enter duke york

king henry take brave york now soldiers march away
how thou pleasest god dispose day exeunt

scene vi
another part field
alarum enter king his train prisoners exeter others
king henry well have done thrice valiant countrymen
but alls not done yet keep french field
exeter duke york commends him majesty
king henry lives he good uncle thrice within this hour
saw him down thrice up again fighting
exeter which array brave soldier doth he lie
larding plain by his bloody side
yoke fellow his honour owing wounds
noble earl suffolk also lies
suffolk first died york all haggled over
comes him where gore he lay insteeped
takes him by beard kisses gashes
bloodily did yawn upon his face
he cries aloud 'tarry cousin suffolk
tarry sweet soul mine then fly abreast
as this glorious well foughten field
kept together our chivalry'
upon these words came cheer'd him up
he smild face raught his hand
feeble grip says 'dear lord
commend service sovereign'
so did he turn over suffolk's neck
he threw his wounded arm kiss'd his lips
testament noble ending love
pretty sweet manner forc'd
those waters from which would have stopp'd
but had not so much man
all mother came into mine eyes
gave up tears
king henry blame not
hearing this must perforce compound
mistful eyes or they will issue too alarum
french have reinforc'd their scatter'd men
then every soldier kill his prisoners
give word through exeunt

act v prologue

by whom this great assembly contriv'd

this good day this gracious meeting
as are now glad behold eyes

against french met them their bent
venom such looks fairly hope
have lost their quality this day
shall change all griefs quarrels into love

queen isabel english princes an do salute
burgundy duty both equal love
great kings france england have labour'd
all wits pains strong endeavours
bring most imperial majesties
mightiness both parts best can witness
since then office hath so far prevaild
face face royal eye eye
have congreeted let not disgrace
if demand before this royal view
what rub or what impediment there
why naked poor mangled peace
dear nurse arts plenties joyful births
should not this best garden world
alas she hath from france too long been chas'd
all her husbandry doth lie heaps
corrupting own fertility
her vine merry cheerer heart
unpruned dies her hedges even pleach'd
prisoners wildly overgrown hair
put forth disorder'd twigs her fallow leas
darnel hemlock rank fumitory
doth root upon while coulter rusts
even mead erst brought sweetly forth
freckled cowslip burnet green clover
wanting scythe all uncorrected rank
conceives by idleness nothing teems
but hateful docks rough thistles kecksies burs
losing both beauty utility
as our vineyards fallows meads hedges
defective their natures grow wildness
even so our houses ourselves children
sciences should become our country
but grow savages as soldiers will
nothing do but meditate blood
swearing stern looks diffus'd attire
everything seems unnatural
which reduce into our former favout
are assembled speech entreats
may know let why gentle peace
should not expel these inconveniences
king henry if duke burgundy would peace
whose want gives growth th' imperfections
which have cited must buy peace
full accord all our just demands
whose tenours particular effects
have enscheduld briefly hands
burgundy king hath heard them which as yet
there no answer made
king henry well then peace
french king have but cursorary eye
o'erglanced articles pleaseth grace
appoint some council presently
sit us once more better heed
re survey them will suddenly
pass our accept peremptory answer

french king nor this have not brother so denied
but our request shall make let pass
king henry pray then love dear alliance
let one article rank rest
thereupon give daughter

may cease their hatred this dear conjunction

their sweet bosoms never war advance

lords amen

as man wife being two are one love

our bending author hath pursu'd story

first part king henry sixth
act scene 1
westminster abbey
dead march enter funeral king henry fifth
attended by duke bedford regent france
duke gloucester protector duke exeter
bedford hung heavens black yield day
night comets importing change times states
brandish crystal tresses sky
them scourge bad revolting stars
have consented unto henry's death
king henry fifth too famous live long
england ne'er lost king so much worth
gloucester england ne'er had king until his time
virtue he had deserving command
his arms spread wider than dragons wings
his sparkling eyes replete wrathful fire
more dazzled drove back his enemies
than mid day sun fierce bent against their faces
what should say his deeds exceed all speech
he ne'er lift up his hand but conquered
exeter mourn black why mourn not blood
henry dead never shall revive
upon wooden coffin attend
our stately presence glorify
captives bound triumphant car
what shall curse planets mishap
plotted thus our glory's overthrow
or shall think subtle witted french
conjurers sorcerers afraid him
by magic verses have contriv'd his end
winchester he was king bless'd king kings
unto french dreadful judgment day
battles lord hosts he fought
church's prayers made him so prosperous
gloucester church where had not churchmen
empty
his thread life had not so soon decay'd
none do but an effeminate prince
whom school boy may overawe
winchester gloucester whate'er thou art
empty
thy wife proud she holdeth thee awe
more than god or religious churchmen may
gloucester name not religion thou lov'st flesh
ne'er throughout year church thou go'st
except pray against thy foes
bedford cease cease these jars rest minds peace
let's altar heralds wait us
instead gold we'll offer up our arms
since arms avail not now henry's dead
when at their mothers' moist'ned eyes babes shall suck
our isle made nourish salt tears
none but women left wail dead
henry fifth thy ghost invocate
prosper this realm keep from civil broils
combat adverse planets heavens
far more glorious star thy soul will make
than julius caesar or bright
enter messenger
sad tidings bring out france
loss slaughter discomfiture
guienne champagne rheims orleans
paris guysors poictiers are all quite lost
bedford what say'st thou man before dead henry's corse
speak softly or loss those great towns
will make him burst his lead rise from death
gloucester paris lost rouen yielded up
if henry were recalld life again
exeter how were they lost what treachery was us'd
messenger no treachery but want men money
amongst soldiers this muttered
here maintain several factions
whilst field should dispatch'd fought
are disputing generals
one would have ling'ring wars little cost
another would fly swift but wanteth wings
third thinks without expense at all
awake awake english nobility
let not sloth dim honours new begot
cropp'd are flower de luces arms
england's coat one half cut away
exeter were our tears wanting this funeral
these tidings would call forth their flowing tides
bedford they concern regent am france
give steeled coat i'll fight france
away these disgraceful wailing robes
weep their intermissive miseries
enter second messenger
second messenger lords view these letters full bad
empty
france revolted from english quite
except some petty towns no import
dauphin charles crowned king rheims
bastard orleans him joind
reignier duke anjou doth take his part
exeter dauphin crowned king all fly him
o whither shall fly from this reproach
gloucester will not fly but our enemies' throats
bedford if thou slack i'll fight out
bedford gloucester why doubt'st thou forwardness
an army have muster'd thoughts
wherewith already france overrun
enter third messenger
third messenger gracious lords add
wherewith now bedew king henry's hearse
must inform dismal fight
betwixt stout lord talbot french
winchester what wherein talbot overcame is't so
third messenger o no wherein lord talbot was
empty
circumstance i'll tell more at large
tenth august last this dreadful lord
retiring from siege orleans
by three twenty thousand french
was round encompassed set upon
no leisure had he enrank his men
he wanted pikes set before his archers
instead whereof sharp stakes pluck'd out hedges
they pitched ground confusedly
keep horsemen off from breaking
more than three hours fight continued
where valiant talbot above human thought
hundreds he sent hell none durst stand him
here there everywhere enrag'd he slew
french exclaim'd devil was arms
all whole army stood agaz'd him
his soldiers spying his undaunted spirit
'a talbot talbot' cried out amain
rush'd into bowels battle
here had conquest fully been seald up
if sir john fastolfe had not play'd coward
purpose relieve follow them
cowardly fled not having struck one stroke
hence grew general wreck massacre
enclosed were they their enemies
base walloon win dauphins grace
thrust talbot spear into back
whom all france their chief assembled strength
durst not presume look once face
bedford talbot slain then will slay myself
whilst such worthy leader wanting aid
unto his dastard foemen betray'd
third messenger o no he lives but took prisoner
lord scales him lord hungerford
most rest slaughter'd or took likewise
bedford his ransom there none but shall pay
i'll hale dauphin headlong from his throne
his crown shall ransom friend
four their lords i'll change one ours
bonfires france forthwith am make
keep our great saint george's feast withal
ten thousand soldiers will take
whose bloody deeds shall make an europe quake
third messenger so had need orleans besieg'd
english army grown weak faint
earl salisbury craveth supply
hardly keeps his men from mutiny
since they so few watch such multitude
either quell dauphin utterly
or bring him obedience yoke
bedford do remember here take leave
go about preparation exit
gloucester i'll tower all haste can
view th' artillery munition
then will proclaim young henry king exit
exeter eltham will where young king
being ordaind his special governor
winchester aside each hath his place function
empty
am left out nothing remains
but long will not jack out office
king from eltham intend steal
sit at chiefest stern public weal exeunt
scene 2
france before orleans
sound flourish enter charles dauphin alencon
charles mars his true moving even as heavens
so earth this day not known
late did he shine upon english side
now are victors upon us he smiles
what towns any moment but have
at pleasure here lie near orleans
otherwhiles famish'd english pale ghosts
faintly besiege us one hour month
alencon they want their porridge their fat bull
either they must dieted mules
have their provender tied their mouths
or piteous they will look drowned mice
reignier let's raise siege why live idly here
talbot taken whom wont fear
remaineth none but mad braind salisbury
he may well fretting spend his gall
nor men nor money hath he make war

him forgive death killeth
when he sees go back one foot or flee exeunt
here alarum they are beaten hack by english
great loss re enter charles alencon reignier

dogs cowards dastards would ne'er have fled
but they left midst enemies

he fighteth as one weary his life
do rush upon us as their hungry prey

england all olivers rowlands bred
during time edward third did reign
more truly now may this verified
none but samsons goliases
sendeth forth skirmish one ten
lean raw bond rascals who would e'er suppose
they had such courage audacity
empty
hunger will enforce them more eager
old know them rather their teeth

else ne'er could they hold out so as they do
by consent we'll even let them alone
alencon so
bastard where's prince dauphin have news him
charles bastard orleans thrice welcome us
bastard methinks looks are sad cheer appalld
hath late overthrow wrought this offence
not dismay'd succour at hand
holy maid hither bring
which by vision sent her from heaven
ordained raise this tedious siege
drive english forth bounds france
exceeding nine sibyls old rome
what's past what's come she can descry
speak shall call her believe words
they are certain unfallible
charles go call her exit bastard
but first try her skill

joan la pucelle
reignier fair maid 't thou wilt do these wondrous feats
pucelle reignier 't thou thinkest beguile
where dauphin come come from behind
know thee well though never seen before
not amaz'd there's nothing hid from
private will talk thee apart
stand back lords give us leave awhile
reignier she takes upon her bravely at first dash
wit untraind any kind art
heaven our lady gracious hath pleas'd
shine contemptible estate
lo whilst waited tender lambs
suns parching heat display'd cheeks
god's mother deigned appear
vision full majesty
willd leave base vocation
free country from calamity
complete glory she reveald herself
whereas was black swart before
those clear rays which she infus'd
beauty am bless'd which may see
ask what question thou canst possible
will answer unpremeditated
courage try by combat if thou dar'st
thou shalt find exceed sex
resolve this thou shalt fortunate
charles thou hast astonish'd thy high terms
only this proof i'll thy valour make
single combat thou shalt buckle
if thou vanquishest thy words are true
otherwise renounce all confidence
pucelle am prepar'd here keen edg'd sword
deck'd five flower de luces each side
which at touraine saint katherine's churchyard
out great deal old iron chose forth
pucelle while live i'll ne'er fly from man
here they fight joan la pucelle overcomes
charles stay stay thy hands thou art an amazon
fightest sword deborah
pucelle christ's mother helps else were too weak
charles whoe'er helps thee 'tis thou must help
impatiently burn thy desire
heart hands thou hast at once subdu'd
excellent pucelle if thy name so
'tis french dauphin sueth thee thus
pucelle must not yield any rites love
professions sacred from above
when have chased all thy foes from hence
then will think upon recompense
charles meantime look gracious thy prostrate thrall
reignier lord methinks very long talk
alencon doubtless he shrives this woman her smock
else ne'er could he so long protract his speech
alencon he may mean more than poor men do know
these women are shrewd tempters their tongues
reignier lord where are what devise
shall give o'er orleans or no
pucelle why no say distrustful recreants
fight till last gasp will guard
charles what she says i'll confirm we'll fight out
pucelle assignd am english scourge
this night siege assuredly i'll raise
since have entered into these wars
glory circle water
which never ceaseth enlarge itself
till by broad spreading disperse nought
henry's death english circle ends
dispersed are glories included
now am proud insulting ship
which caesar his fortune bare at once
charles was mahomet inspired dove
helen mother great constantine
nor yet saint philip's daughters were thee
bright star venus falln down earth
how may reverently worship thee enough

how wert thou handled being prisoner
or by what means got'st thou releas'd
talbot earl bedford had prisoner
calld brave lord ponton de santrailles
him was exchang'd ransomed
but baser man arms by far
once contempt they would have barter'd
which disdaining scornd craved death
rather than would so vile esteem'd
fine redeem'd was as desir'd
but o treacherous fastolfe wounds heart
if now had him brought into power
salisbury yet tellst thou not how thou wert entertaind
talbot scoffs scorns contumelious taunts
open market place produc'd they
public spectacle all
here said they terror french
scarecrow affrights our children so
then broke from officers led
nails digg'd stones out ground
grisly countenance made others fly
none durst come near fear sudden death
iron walls they deem'd not secure
so great fear name 'mongst them was spread
they suppos'd could rend bars steel
spurn pieces posts adamant
wherefore guard chosen shot had
walk'd about every minute while
if did but stir out bed
enter boy linstock
salisbury grieve hear what torments endur'd
but will reveng'd sufficiently
now supper time orleans
here through this grate count each one
view frenchmen how they fortify

sir thomas gargrave sir william glansdale
let have express opinions

fall down

talbot what chance this suddenly hath cross'd us
how far'st thou mirror all martial men
one thy eyes thy cheek's side struck off
accursed tower accursed fatal hand
hath contriv'd this woeful tragedy
thirteen battles salisbury o'ercame
henry fifth he first traind wars
whilst any trump did sound or drum struck up
his sword did ne'er leave striking field
yet liv'st thou salisbury though thy speech doth fail
sun one eye vieweth all world
heaven thou gracious none alive
if salisbury wants mercy at thy hands
bear hence his body will help bury

thou shalt not die whiles
he beckons his hand smiles
remember avenge french'

scene 5
before orleans
here an alarum again talbot pursueth
dauphin driveth him then enter joan la pucelle

talbot where strength valour force
woman clad armour chaseth them
enter la pucelle
here here she comes i'll have bout thee
devil or devils dam i'll conjure thee
blood will draw thee thou art witch
straightway give thy soul him thou serv'st
pucelle come come 'tis only must disgrace thee
here they fight
talbot heavens can suffer hell so prevail
from shoulders crack arms asunder
but will chastise this high minded strumpet
they fight again
pucelle talbot farewell thy hour not yet come
must go victual orleans forthwith
short alarum then enter town soldiers
o'ertake if thou canst scorn thy strength
go go cheer up thy hungry starved men
help salisbury make his testament
talbot thoughts are whirled potter's wheel
know not where am nor what do
witch by fear not force hannibal
drives back our troops conquers as she lists
so bees smoke doves noisome stench
are from their hives houses driven away
they calld us our fierceness english dogs
now whelps crying run away
short alarum
or tear lions out england's coat
renounce soil give sheep lions' stead
sheep run not half so treacherous from wolf
or horse or oxen from leopard
as fly from oft subdued slaves
alarum here another skirmish
will not retire into trenches
all consented unto salisbury's death
none would strike stroke his revenge
spite us or aught could do
o would were die salisbury
shame hereof will make hide head
exit talbot alarum retreat

france triumph thy glorious prophetess
recover'd town orleans
more blessed hap did ne'er befall our state

when they shall hear how have play'd men

which will divide crown her
all priests friars realm

than rhodope's memphis ever was
memory her when she dead
her ashes an urn more precious
than rich jeweld coffer darius
transported shall at high festivals
before kings queens france
no longer saint denis will cry
but joan la pucelle shall france's saint
come let us banquet royally
act ii scene 1
before orleans

by whose approach regions artois
wallon picardy are friends us
this happy night frenchmen are secure
having all day carous'd banqueted
as fitting best quittance their deceit
contriv'd by art baleful sorcery
bedford coward france how much he wrongs his fame
despairing his own arm's fortitude
join witches help hell
burgundy traitors have never other company
but what's pucelle whom they term so pure
talbot maid they say
bedford maid so martial
if underneath standard french
she carry armour as she hath begun

god our fortress whose conquering name
let us resolve scale their flinty bulwarks

do make our entrance several ways
if chance one us do fail
bedford agreed i'll yond corner
burgundy this
talbot here will talbot mount or make his grave
now salisbury thee right

how much duty am bound both

talbot'
sentinel arm arm enemy doth make assault
enter several ways bastard alencon reignier
half ready half unready

bastard unready ay glad 'scap'd so well
reignier 'twas time trow wake leave our beds
hearing alarums at our chamber doors
alencon all exploits since first follow'd arms
ne'er heard warlike enterprise
more venturous or desperate than this
reignier if not hell heavens sure favour him
alencon here cometh charles marvel how he sped
enter charles la pucelle
bastard tut holy joan was his defensive guard
charles this thy cunning thou deceitful dame
didst thou at first flatter us withal
make us partakers little gain
now our loss might ten times so much
pucelle wherefore charles impatient his friend
sleeping or waking must still prevail
or will blame lay fault
improvident soldiers had watch been good
this sudden mischief never could have falln
charles duke alencon this was default
being captain watch night
did look no better weighty charge
alencon had all quarters been as safely kept
as whereof had government
bastard mine was secure
reignier so was mine lord
charles myself most part all this night
within her quarter mine own precinct
was employ'd passing fro
about relieving sentinels
then how or which way should they first break
pucelle question lords no further case
how or which way 'tis sure they found some place
now there rests no other shift but this
gather our soldiers scatter'd dispers'd
lay new platforms endamage them
alarum enter an english soldier crying
'a talbot talbot' they fly leaving their
clothes behind
soldier i'll so bold take what they have left
cry talbot serves sword
have loaden many spoils
scene 2
orleans within town
enter talbot bedford burgundy captain
others
bedford day begins break night fled
whose pitchy mantle over veild earth
here sound retreat cease our hot pursuit
retreat sounded
talbot bring forth body old salisbury
middle centre this cursed town
now have paid vow unto his soul
every drop blood was drawn from him
there hath at least five frenchmen died night
hereafter ages may behold
what ruin happened revenge him
within their chiefest temple i'll erect
tomb wherein his corpse shall interr'd
upon which every one may read
treacherous manner his mournful death
what terror he had been france
but lords all our bloody massacre
muse met not dauphins grace
his new come champion virtuous joan arc
nor any his false confederates
bedford 'tis thought lord talbot when fight began
rous'd sudden from their drowsy beds
they did amongst troops armed men
burgundy myself as far as could well discern
smoke dusky vapours night
am sure scar'd dauphin his trull
when arm arm they both came swiftly running
pair loving turtle doves
could not live asunder day or night
after things are set order here
we'll follow them all power have
enter messenger
call ye warlike talbot his acts
so much applauded through realm france
talbot here talbot who would speak him
messenger virtuous lady countess auvergne
modesty admiring thy renown
by entreats great lord thou wouldst vouchsafe
visit her poor castle where she lies
she may boast she hath beheld man
whose glory fills world loud report
will turn into peaceful comic sport
when ladies crave encount'red
may not lord despise her gentle suit

act iv scene 1
park palace
enter king gloucester winchester york suffolk somerset warwick

tear garter from thy cravens leg plucking off

thou wast installed high degree
pardon princely henry rest
when but all was six thousand strong

before met or stroke was given
trusty squire did run away
which assault lost twelve hundred men
myself divers gentlemen beside

corrupt tainted thousand vices
because want grace others have
judge straight thing impossible
no misconceived joan arc hath been
virgin from her tender infancy
chaste immaculate very thought
whose maiden blood thus rigorously effus'd
will cry vengeance at gates heaven
york ay ay away her execution
warwick hark ye sirs because she maid
spare no fagots let there enow
place barrels pitch upon fatal stake
pucelle will nothing turn unrelenting hearts
then joan discover thine infirmity
warranteth by law thy privilege
am child ye bloody homicides
murder not then fruit within womb
although ye hale violent death

warwick greatest miracle e'er ye wrought
all strict preciseness come this
did imagine what would her refuge

especially since charles must father
pucelle are deceiv'd child none his
was alencon enjoy'd love
york alencon notorious machiavel
dies an if had thousand lives
pucelle o give leave have deluded
'twas neither charles nor yet duke nam'd

there were so many whom she may accuse
warwick it's sign she hath been liberal free
york yet forsooth she virgin pure
strumpet thy words condemn thy brat thee
use no entreaty vain

betwixt our nation aspiring french
here at hand dauphin his train
approacheth confer about some matter

our great progenitors had conquered

what conditions league must

hollow passage poisond voice
by sight these our baleful enemies

mere compassion lenity
ease country distressful war
an suffer breathe fruitful peace
shall become true liegemen his crown

yet substance authority

this proffer absurd reasonless

more than half gallian territories
therein reverenc'd their lawful king
shall lucre rest unvanquish'd
detract so much from prerogative
as calld but viceroy whole
which have than coveting more
cast from possibility all

now matter grows compromise
stand'st thou aloof upon comparison

benefit proceeding from our king
not any challenge desert

empty

shall not find opportunity

by our proceeding hostility
although break when pleasure serves

scene 5
london palace
enter suffolk conference king
gloucester exeter
king henry wondrous rare description noble earl
her virtues graced external gifts
do breed love's settled passions heart
as rigour tempestuous gusts
provokes mightiest hulk against tide
so am driven by breath her renown
either suffer shipwreck or arrive
where may have fruition her love
suffolk tush good lord this superficial tale
but preface her worthy praise
had sufficient skill utter them
would make volume enticing lines
able ravish any dull conceit
which more she not so divine
so full replete choice all delights
but as humble lowliness mind
she content at command
command mean virtuous intents
love honour henry as her lord
therefore lord protector give consent
margaret may england's royal queen
gloucester so should give consent flatter sin
know lord highness betroth'd
unto another lady esteem
how shall then dispense contract
not deface honour reproach
suffolk as doth ruler unlawful oaths
or one at triumph having vow'd
by reason his adversary's odds
poor earls daughter unequal odds
therefore may broke without offence
gloucester why what pray margaret more than
empty
her father no better than an earl
although glorious titles he excel
suffolk yes lord her father king
king naples jerusalem
as his alliance will confirm our peace
keep frenchmen allegiance
gloucester so earl armagnac may do
because he near kinsman unto charles
exeter beside his wealth doth warrant liberal dower
where reignier sooner will receive than give
suffolk dow'r lords disgrace not so king
he should so abject base poor
choose wealth not perfect love
not seek queen make him rich
so worthless peasants bargain their wives
as market men oxen sheep or horse
marriage matter more worth
than dealt by attorneyship
not whom will but whom his grace affects
must companion his nuptial bed
therefore lords since he affects her most
most all these reasons bindeth us
what wedlock forced but hell
an age discord continual strife
whereas contrary bringeth bliss
pattern celestial peace
whom should match henry being king
but margaret daughter king
her peerless feature joined her birth
approves her fit none but king
her valiant courage undaunted spirit
will answer our hope issue king
henry son unto conqueror
likely beget more conquerors
if lady so high resolve
as fair margaret he link'd love
then yield lords here conclude
margaret shall queen none but she
king henry whether through force report
noble lord suffolk or
any passion inflaming love
cannot tell but this am assur'd
feel such sharp dissension breast
such fierce alarums both hope fear
as am sick working thoughts
take therefore shipping post lord france
agree any covenants procure
lady margaret do vouchsafe come
cross seas england crownd
expenses sufficient charge
among people gather up tenth
gone say till do return
rest perplexed thousand cares
good uncle banish all offence
if do censure by what were
not what are know will excuse
this sudden execution will
so conduct where from company
gloucester ay grief fear both at first last
exeunt gloucester exeter
suffolk thus suffolk hath prevaild thus he goes
as did youthful paris once greece
hope find event love
but prosper better than troyan did
margaret shall now queen rule king
but will rule both her king realm exit
end

scene ii
london duke york's garden

york then thus
edward third lords had seven sons
first edward black prince prince wales
second william hatfield third
lionel duke clarence next whom
fifth was edmund langley duke york
sixth was thomas woodstock duke gloucester
william windsor was seventh last
edward black prince died before his father
left behind him richard his only son
who after edward third's death reignd as king
till henry bolingbroke duke lancaster
eldest son heir john gaunt
crownd by name henry fourth
sent his poor queen france from whence she came
him pomfret where as all know
harmless richard was murdered traitorously

york which now they hold by force not by right

who kept him captivity till he died

act iii scene
abbey at bury st edmunds
sound sennet enter king queen cardinal suffolk york
buckingham salisbury warwick parliament
king henry muse lord gloucester not come
'tis not his wont hindmost man
whate'er occasion keeps him from us now
queen can not see or will ye not observe
what majesty he bears himself
how insolent late he become
how proud how peremptory unlike himself
know time since he was mild affable
if did but glance far off look
immediately he was upon his knee
all court admir'd him submission
but meet him now morn
when every one will give time day
passeth by stiff unbowed knee
disdaining duty us belongs
small curs are not regarded when they grin
but great men tremble when lion roars
humphrey no little man england
first note he near descent
should fall he next will mount
seemeth then no policy
respecting what rancorous mind he bears
he should come about royal person
or admitted highness' council
by flattery hath he won commons' hearts
when he please make commotion
'tis fear'd they all will follow him
now 'tis spring weeds are shallow rooted
suffer them now they'll o'ergrow garden
choke herbs want husbandry
reverent care bear unto lord
if fond can womans fear
which fear if better reasons can supplant
will subscribe say wrong'd duke
lord suffolk buckingham york
reprove allegation if can
or else conclude words effectual
suffolk well hath highness seen into this duke
had first been put speak mind
think should have told grace's tale
upon life began her devilish practices
or if he were not privy those faults
yet by reputing his high descent
as next king he was successive heir
such high vaunts his nobility
did instigate bedlam brainsick duchess
by wicked means frame our sovereigns fall
smooth runs water where brook deep
his simple show he harbours treason
no no sovereign gloucester man
unsounded yet full deep deceit
cardinal did he not contrary form law
devise strange deaths small offences done
york did he not his protectorship
levy great sums money through realm
soldiers' pay france never sent
by means whereof towns each day revolted
buckingham tut these are petty faults faults unknown
king henry lords at once care have us
mow down thorns would annoy our foot
worthy praise but shall speak conscience
our kinsman gloucester as innocent
from meaning treason our royal person
as sucking lamb or harmless dove
duke virtuous mild too well given
dream evil or work downfall
queen ah what's more dangerous than this fond affiance
he's disposed as hateful raven
he lamb his skin surely lent him
he's inclind as ravenous wolf
who cannot steal shape means deceit
take heed lord welfare us all
hangs cutting short fraudful man

as firmly as hope fertile england
thus are blossoms blasted bud
caterpillars eat leaves away
but will remedy this gear ere long
or sell title glorious grave
enter gloucester
pardon liege have stay'd so long

unless thou wert more loyal than thou art
do arrest thee high treason here

nor change countenance this arrest
heart unspotted not easily daunted
purest spring not so free from mud
as am clear from treason sovereign
york 'tis thought lord took bribes france
being protector stay'd soldiers' pay
by means whereof his highness hath lost france
gloucester but thought so what are they think
never robb'd soldiers their pay
nor ever had one penny bribe from france
so help god as have watch'd night
ay night by night studying good england
doit e'er wrested from king
brought against at trial day
no many pound mine own proper store
because would not tax needy commons
have dispursed garrisons
never ask'd restitution
cardinal serves well lord say so much
gloucester say no more than truth so help god
york protectorship did devise
strange tortures offenders never heard
gloucester why 'tis well known whiles was protector
pity was all fault was
should melt at an offender's tears
lowly words were ransom their fault
unless were bloody murderer
or foul felonious thief fleec'd poor passengers
never gave them condign punishment
murder indeed bloody sin tortur'd
above felon or what trespass else
but mightier crimes are laid unto charge
whereof cannot easily purge yourself
do arrest his highness' name
here commit lord cardinal
keep until further time trial
king henry lord gloucester 'tis special hope
will clear yourself from all suspense
conscience tells are innocent
gloucester ah gracious lord these days are dangerous
charity chas'd hence by rancour's hand
foul subornation predominant
equity exild highness' land
know their complot have life
if death might make this island happy
prove period their tyranny
would expend all willingness
but mine made prologue their play
thousands more yet suspect no peril
beaufort's red sparkling eyes blab his heart's malice
suffolk's cloudy brow his stormy hate
sharp buckingham unburdens his tongue
envious load lies upon his heart
dogged york reaches at moon
whose overweening arm have pluck'd back
by false accuse doth level at life
sovereign lady rest
causeless have laid disgraces head
liefest liege mine enemy
ay all have laid heads together
myself had notice conventicles
all make away guiltless life
shall not want false witness condemn
nor store treasons augment guilt
ancient proverb will well effected
'a staff quickly found beat dog'
cardinal liege his railing intolerable
from treasons secret knife traitor's rage
thus upbraided chid rated at
offender granted scope speech
'twill make them cool zeal unto grace
suffolk hath he not twit our sovereign lady here
ignominious words though clerkly couch'd
as if she had suborned some swear
false allegations o'erthrow his state
queen but can give loser leave chide
beshrew winners they play'd false
well such losers may have leave speak
buckingham he'll wrest sense hold us here all day
lord cardinal he prisoner
cardinal sirs take away duke guard him sure
gloucester ah thus king henry throws away his crutch
before his legs firm bear his body
thus shepherd beaten from thy side
wolves are gnarling who shall gnaw thee first
good king henry thy decay fear exit guarded
king henry lords what wisdoms seemeth best
do or undo as if ourself were here
queen what will highness leave parliament
king henry ay margaret heart drownd grief
whose flood begins flow within mine eyes
body round engirt misery
what's more miserable than discontent
ah uncle humphrey thy face see
yet good humphrey hour come
e'er prov'd thee false or fear'd thy faith
what louring star now envies thy estate
these great lords margaret our queen
do seek subversion thy harmless life
thou never didst them wrong nor no man wrong
as butcher takes away calf
binds wretch beats when strays
bearing bloody slaughter house
as dam runs lowing up down
looking way her harmless young one went
can do nought but wail her darling's loss
even so myself bewails good gloucester's case
sad unhelpful tears dimm'd eyes
look after him cannot do him good
so mighty are his vowed enemies
his fortunes will weep 'twixt each groan
say 'who's traitor gloucester he none' exit
henry lord cold great affairs
too full foolish pity gloucester's show
beguiles him as mournful crocodile
sorrow snares relenting passengers
or as snake rolld flow'ring bank
shining checker'd slough doth sting child
beauty thinks excellent
believe lords were none more wise than
yet herein judge mine own wit good
rid us from fear have him
cardinal he should die worthy policy
but yet want colour his death
'tis meet he condemnd by course law
suffolk but mind were no policy
king will labour still save his life
commons haply rise save his life
yet have but trivial argument
more than mistrust shows him worthy death
suffolk ah york no man alive so fain as
york 'tis york hath more reason his death
but lord cardinal lord suffolk
say as think speak from souls
were't not all one an empty eagle were set
guard chicken from hungry kite
as place duke humphrey king's protector
queen so poor chicken should sure death
suffolk madam 'tis true were't not madness then
who being accus'd crafty murderer
his guilt should but idly posted over
because his purpose not executed
no let him die he fox
by nature prov'd an enemy flock
before his chaps staind crimson blood
as humphrey prov'd by reasons liege
do not stand quillets how slay him
by gins by snares by subtlety
so he dead good deceit
which mates him first first intends deceit
queen thrice noble suffolk 'tis resolutely spoke
suffolk not resolute except so much were done
things are often spoke seldom meant
but heart accordeth tongue
seeing deed meritorious
preserve sovereign from his foe
say but word will his priest
ere can take due orders priest
say consent censure well deed
i'll provide his executioner
tender so safety liege
suffolk here hand deed worthy doing
queen so say
york now three have spoke
skills not greatly who impugns our doom
enter post
signify rebels there are up
put englishmen unto sword
send succours lords stop rage betime
before wound do grow uncurable
being green there great hope help
cardinal breach craves quick expedient stop
what counsel give this weighty cause
york somerset sent as regent thither
'tis meet lucky ruler employ'd
somerset if york all his far fet policy
had been regent there instead
he never would have stay'd france so long
york no not lose all as thou hast done
rather would have lost life betimes
than bring burden dishonour home
by staying there so long till all were lost
show one scar character'd thy skin
mens flesh preserv'd so whole do seldom win
if wind fuel brought feed
no more good york sweet somerset still
thy fortune york hadst thou been regent there
might happily have prov'd far worse than his
york what worse than nought nay then shame take all
somerset number thee wishest shame
cardinal lord york try what fortune
th' uncivil kerns ireland are arms
temper clay blood englishmen
collected choicely from each county some
try hap against irishmen
york will lord so please his majesty
suffolk why our authority his consent
what do establish he confirms
then noble york take thou this task hand
york am content provide soldiers lords
whiles take order mine own affairs
suffolk charge lord york will see perform'd
cardinal no more him will deal him
henceforth he shall trouble us no more
so break off day almost spent
lord suffolk must talk event
york lord suffolk within fourteen days
at bristol expect soldiers
there i'll ship them all ireland
suffolk i'll see truly done lord york
exeunt all but york
change misdoubt resolution
thou hop'st or what thou art
resign death not worth th' enjoying
let pale fac'd fear keep mean born man
find no harbour royal heart
faster than spring time show'rs comes thought thought
not thought but thinks dignity
brain more busy than labouring spider
weaves tedious snares trap mine enemies
send packing an host men
fear but warm starved snake
who cherish'd breasts will sting hearts
'twas men lack'd will give them
take kindly yet well assur'd
put sharp weapons madmans hands
whiles ireland nourish mighty band
will stir up england some black storm
shall blow ten thousand souls heaven or hell
until golden circuit head
glorious suns transparent beams
do calm fury this mad bred flaw
minister intent
have seduc'd headstrong kentishman
john cade ashford
make commotion as full well he can
under tide john mortimer
ireland have seen this stubborn cade
fought so long tiff his thighs darts
were almost sharp quilld porpentine
end being rescu'd have seen
him caper upright wild morisco
shaking bloody darts as he his bells
full often shag hair'd crafty kern
hath he conversed enemy
undiscover'd come again
given notice their villainies
john mortimer which now dead
face gait speech he doth resemble
by this shall perceive commons' mind
how they affect house claim york
say he taken rack'd tortured
know no pain they can inflict upon him
will make him say mov'd him those arms
say he thrive as 'tis great he will
why then from ireland come strength
humphrey being dead as he shall
henry put apart next exit
scene ii
bury st edmunds room state

will reward this venturous deed
king all peers are here at hand
have laid fair bed all things well
according as gave directions

re enter suffolk
how now why look'st thou pale why tremblest thou
where our uncle what's matter suffolk

king o heavenly god
queen how fares gracious lord
king henry what doth lord suffolk comfort
came he right now sing ravens note
whose dismal tune bereft vital pow'rs
thinks he chirping wren
by crying comfort from hollow breast
can chase away first conceived sound
hide not thy poison such sug'red words
lay not thy hands forbear say
their touch affrights as serpent's sting
upon thy eye balls murderous tyranny
sits grim majesty fright world
look not upon thine eyes are wounding
yet do not go away come basilisk
kill innocent gazer thy sight
shade death shall find joy
life but double death'now gloucester's dead
queen why do rate lord suffolk thus
although duke was enemy him
myself foe as he was
might liquid tears or heart offending groans
or blood consuming sighs recall his life
would blind weeping sick groans
look pale as primrose blood drinking sighs
all have noble duke alive
what know how world may deem
known were but hollow friends
may judg'd made duke away
princes' courts filld reproach
this get by his death ay unhappy
queen crownd infamy
king henry ah woe gloucester wretched man
queen woe more wretched than he
what dost thou turn away hide thy face
am no loathsome leper look
what art thou adder waxen deaf
poisonous too kill thy forlorn queen
why then dame margaret was ne'er thy joy
erect his statue worship
make image but an alehouse sign
was this nigh wreck'd upon sea
twice by awkward wind from england's bank
drove back again unto native clime
what boded this but well forewarning wind
did seem say 'seek not scorpions nest
nor set no footing this unkind shore'
he loos'd them forth their brazen caves
bid them blow towards england's blessed shore
or turn our stern upon dreadful rock
yet aeolus would not murderer
but left hateful office unto thee
pretty vaulting sea refus'd drown
knowing thou wouldst have drownd shore
tears as salt as sea through thy unkindness
splitting rocks cow'r'd sinking sands
because thy flinty heart more hard than they
might thy palace perish margaret
as far as could ken thy chalky cliffs
when from thy shore tempest beat us back
stood upon hatches storm
when dusky sky began rob
earnest gaping sight thy land's view
took costly jewel from neck
heart was bound diamonds
so wish'd thy body might heart
even this lost fair england's view
bid mine eyes packing heart
calld them blind dusky spectacles
losing ken albions wished coast
how often have tempted suffolk's tongue
agent thy foul inconstancy
sit witch as ascanius did
when he madding dido would unfold
am not witch'd her or thou not false him
ay can no more die margaret
henry weeps thou dost live so long
noise within enter warwick salisbury
many commons
warwick reported mighty sovereign
good duke humphrey traitorously murd'red
by suffolk cardinal beaufort's means
commons an angry hive bees
care not who they sting his revenge
myself have calm'd their spleenful mutiny
until they hear order his death
king henry he dead good warwick 'tis too true
but how he died god knows not henry
enter his chamber view his breathless corpse
comment then upon his sudden death
warwick shall do liege stay salisbury
rude multitude till return exit
king henry o thou judgest all things stay thoughts
thoughts labour persuade soul
some violent hands were laid humphrey's life
if suspect false forgive god
judgment only doth belong thee
fain would go chafe his paly lips
twenty thousand kisses drain
upon his face an ocean salt tears
tell love unto his dumb deaf trunk
but all vain are these mean obsequies
survey his dead earthy image
what were but make sorrow greater
bed put forth body enter warwick
warwick come hither gracious sovereign view this body
king henry see how deep grave made
his soul fled all worldly solace
seeing him see life death
warwick as surely as soul intends live
free us from his father's wrathful curse
do believe violent hands were laid
upon life this thrice famed duke
suffolk dreadful oath sworn solemn tongue
what instance gives lord warwick his vow
warwick see how blood settled his face
oft have seen timely parted ghost
ashy semblance meagre pale bloodless
being all descended labouring heart
attracts same aidance 'gainst enemy
which heart there cools ne'er returneth
blush beautify cheek again
but see his face black full blood
his eye balls further out than when he liv'd
staring full ghastly strangled man
his hair uprear'd his nostrils stretch'd struggling
his hands abroad display'd as one grasp'd
tugg'd life was by strength subdu'd
his well proportiond beard made rough rugged
summer's corn by tempest lodged
cannot but he was murd'red here
least all these signs were probable
suffolk why warwick who should do duke death
myself beaufort had him protection
hope sir are no murderers
warwick but both were vow'd duke humphrey's foes
forsooth had good duke keep
'tis well seen he found an enemy
queen then belike suspect these noblemen
as guilty duke humphrey's timeless death
warwick who finds heifer dead bleeding fresh
sees fast by butcher an axe
but will suspect 'twas he made slaughter
who finds partridge puttock's nest
but may imagine how bird was dead
although kite soar unbloodied beak
queen are butcher suffolk where's knife

but here's vengeful sword rusted ease
shall scoured his rancorous heart
slanders murder's crimson badge
say if thou dar'st proud lord warwickshire
am faulty duke humphrey's death

though suffolk dare him twenty thousand times

every word speak his behalf
slander royal dignity

was graft crab tree slip whose fruit thou art
never nevils' noble race
