salisbury commons within sirs stand apart king
shall know mind
dread lord commons send word by
unless lord suffolk straight done death

mere instinct love loyalty
free from stubborn opposite intent

sent from sort tinkers king

sure thoughts do hourly prophesy

whose far unworthy deputy am

queen o henry let plead gentle suffolk
king henry ungentle queen call him gentle suffolk
no more say if thou dost plead him
thou wilt but add increase unto wrath
had but said would have kept word
but when swear irrevocable
if after three days' space thou here be'st found
any ground am ruler
come warwick come good warwick go
have great matters impart thee
exeunt all but queen suffolk
queen mischance sorrow go along
heart's discontent sour affliction
playfellows keep company
there's two devil make third
threefold vengeance tend upon steps
suffolk cease gentle queen these execrations
queen fie coward woman soft hearted wretch
has thou not spirit curse thine enemy
suffolk plague upon them wherefore should curse them
would curses kill as doth mandrake's groan
would invent as bitter searching terms
as curst as harsh horrible hear
deliver'd strongly through fixed teeth
full as many signs deadly hate
as lean fac'd envy her loathsome cave
mine eyes should sparkle beaten flint
mine hair fix'd an end as one distract
ay every joint should seem curse ban
even now burdend heart would break
should not curse them poison their drink
gall worse than gall daintiest they taste
their sweetest shade grove cypress trees
their chiefest prospect murd'ring basilisks
their softest touch as smart as lizards' stings
boding screech owls make consort full
all foul terrors dark seated hell
queen enough sweet suffolk thou torment'st thyself
these dread curses sun 'gainst glass
or an overcharged gun recoil
turns force them upon thyself
suffolk bade ban will bid leave
now by ground am banish'd from
well could curse away winter's night
where biting cold would never let grass grow
think but minute spent sport

may dew mournful tears
nor let rain heaven wet this place
wash away woeful monuments
o could this kiss printed thy hand
thou might'st think upon these by seal
through whom thousand sighs are breath'd thee

as one surfeits thinking want
will repeal thee or well assur'd
adventure banished myself
banished am if but from thee
go speak not even now gone
o go not yet even thus two friends condemnd
embrace kiss take ten thousand leaves
loather hundred times part than die

once by king three times thrice by thee
'tis not land care wert thou thence
wilderness populous enough
so suffolk had thy heavenly company
where thou art there world itself
every several pleasure world
where thou art not desolation
can no more live thou joy thy life

southern clouds contend tears

thy sight die what were else
but pleasant slumber thy lap
here could breathe soul into air

act iv scene

whilst our pinnace anchors downs
or their blood stain this discoloured shore

thou art his mate make boot this

told by water should die

broke sword arms torn defac'd

suffolk poole
lieutenant ay kennel puddle sink whose filth dirt
troubles silver spring where england drinks
now will dam up this thy yawning mouth
swallowing treasure realm
thy lips kiss'd queen shall sweep ground
thou smildst at good duke humphrey's death
against senseless winds shalt grin vain
wedded thou hags hell
daring affy mighty lord
unto daughter worthless king
having neither subject wealth nor diadem
by devilish policy art thou grown great
ambitious sylla overgorg'd
gobbets thy mother's bleeding heart
by thee anjou maine were sold france
false revolting normans thorough thee
hath slain their governors surpris'd our forts
sent ragged soldiers wounded home
princely warwick nevils all
whose dreadful swords were never drawn vain
as hating thee are rising up arms
now house york thrust from crown
by shameful murder guiltless king
lofty proud encroaching tyranny
burns revenging fire whose hopeful colours
under which writ 'invitis nubibus'
commons here kent are up arms
conclude reproach beggary
crept into palace our king
all by thee away convey him hence
suffolk o were god shoot forth thunder
upon these paltry servile abject drudges
small things make base men proud this villain here
being captain pinnace threatens more
drones suck not eagles' blood but rob beehives
impossible should die
by such lowly vassal as thyself
thy words move rage not remorse
go message from queen france
charge thee waft safely cross channel

whitmore come suffolk must waft thee thy death
suffolk gelidus timor occupat artus thee fear
what are ye daunted now now will ye stoop

us'd command untaught plead favour
far should honour such as these
humble suit no rather let head
stoop block than these knees bow any
save god heaven king
sooner dance upon bloody pole
true nobility exempt from fear
more can bear than dare execute

this death may never forgot

stabb'd julius caesar savage islanders

his army ragged multitude
hinds peasants rude merciless
hath given them heart courage proceed
all scholars lawyers courtiers gentlemen
they call false caterpillars intend their death
king henry o graceless men they know not what they do
buckingham gracious lord retire killingworth
until power rais'd put them down
queen ah were duke suffolk now alive
these kentish rebels would soon appeas'd
king henry lord say traitors hate thee
say so might grace's person danger
sight odious their eyes
therefore this city will stay
live alone as secret as may
enter another messenger
second messenger jack cade hath gotten london bridge
citizens fly forsake their houses
rascal people thirsting after prey
join traitor they jointly swear
buckingham then linger not lord away take horse
king henry come margaret god our hope will succour us
queen hope gone now suffolk deceas'd
king henry lord say farewell lord trust not kentish
empty
buckingham trust nobody fear betray'd
say trust have mine innocence
therefore am bold resolute exeunt
scene v
enter lord scales upon tower walking then enter two or three citizens
empty
scales how now jack cade slain
first citizen no lord nor likely slain they have
won bridge killing all those withstand them
lord mayor craves aid honour from
tower defend city from rebels
scales such aid as can spare shall command
but am troubled here them myself
but get smithfield gather head
thither will send matthew goffe
fight king country lives
so farewell must hence again exeunt

london cannon street

calls other than lord mortimer

come let's away exeunt

traitorously corrupted youth realm erecting
grammar school whereas before our forefathers had no other

us'd contrary king his crown dignity thou
hast built paper mill will proved thy face thou
hast men about thee usually talk noun verb
such abominable words as no christian ear can endure hear

been most worthy live thou dost ride foot cloth dost
thou not
say what
cade marry thou ought'st not let thy horse wear cloak when

dick work their shirt too as myself example am
say men kent
dick what say kent
say nothing but this 'tis 'bona terra mala gens'

say hear but speak bear where will
kent commentaries caesar writ
term'd civilst place all this isle
sweet country because full riches
people liberal valiant active wealthy
sold not maine lost not normandy
yet recover them would lose life

when have aught exacted at hands

unless possess'd devilish spirits
cannot but forbear murder

scene ix
killing worth castle

could command no more content than
no sooner was crept out cradle
but was made king at nine months old
was never subject long'd king
as do long wish subject

show'd how well love prince country

or unto death do country good

scene x
kent idens garden
enter cade
cade fie ambitions fie myself have sword yet am
ready famish these five days have hid these woods
durst not peep out all country laid but now
am so hungry if might have lease life
wall have climb'd into this garden see if can eat grass
or pick sallet another while which not amiss cool
mans stomach this hot weather think this word 'sallet'
was born do good many time but sallet
brain pain had been cleft brown bill many time
when have been dry bravely marching hath serv'd
instead quart pot drink now word 'sallet'
must serve feed
enter iden
may enjoy such quiet walks as these
this small inheritance father left
contenteth worth monarchy
seek not wax great by others' waning
or gather wealth care not what envy
sufficeth have maintains state
sends poor well pleased from gate

all as dead as door nail pray god may never eat grass
empty

alexander iden an esquire kent
took odds combat poor famish'd man

set limb limb thou art far lesser
thy leg stick compared this truncheon

if mine arm heaved air
thy grave digg'd already earth
as words whose greatness answers words
let this sword report what speech forbears
cade by valour most complete champion ever heard

scene ii
saint albans
alarums battle enter warwick

enter york
how now noble lord what all foot

but match match have encount'red him
made prey carrion kites crows
even bonny beast he lov'd so well

york hold warwick seek thee out some other chase
myself must hunt this deer death
warwick then nobly york 'tis crown thou fight'st
as intend clifford thrive day
grieves soul leave thee unassaild exit

but thou art so fast mine enemy
but 'tis shown ignobly treason

as justice true right express

young clifford shame confusion all rout
fear frames disorder disorder wounds
where should guard o war thou son hell
whom angry heavens do make their minister
throw frozen bosoms our part
hot coals vengeance let no soldier fly
he truly dedicate war
hath no self love nor he loves himself
hath not essentially but by circumstance
o let vile world end
premised flames last day
knit earth heaven together
now let general trumpet blow his blast
particularities petty sounds
cease wast thou ordaind dear father
lose thy youth peace achieve
silver livery advised age
thy reverence thy chair days thus
heart turnd stone while 'tis mine
shall stony york not our old men spares
no more will their babes tears virginal
shall even as dew fire
beauty tyrant oft reclaims
shall flaming wrath oil flax
henceforth will not have do pity
meet an infant house york
into as many gobbets will cut
cruelty will seek out fame
come thou new ruin old clifford's house
as did aeneas old anchises bear
so bear thee upon manly shoulders
but then aeneas bare living load
nothing so heavy as these woes mine
exit body
enter richard somerset fight somerset killed
richard so lie thou there
castle saint albans somerset
hath made wizard famous his death
sword hold thy temper heart wrathful still
priests pray enemies but princes kill exit
fight excursions enter king queen others
queen away lord are slow shame away
king henry can outrun heavens good margaret stay
queen what are made you'll nor fight nor fly
now manhood wisdom defence
by what can which can no more but fly
alarum afar off
if ta'en then should see bottom
all our fortunes but if haply scape
as well may if not through neglect
shall london get where are lov'd
where this breach now our fortunes made
may readily stopp'd
re enter young clifford
would speak blasphemy ere bid fly
but fly must uncurable discomfit
reigns hearts all our present parts
away relief will live
see their day them our fortune give
away lord away exeunt

fields near saint albans

winter lion who rage forgets
aged contusions all brush time
gallant brow youth
repairs him occasion this happy day
not itself nor have won one foot
if salisbury lost
richard noble father
three times day holp him his horse
persuaded him from any further act
but still where danger was still there met him
rich hangings homely house
so was his will his old feeble body
but noble as he look where he comes
enter salisbury
salisbury now by sword well hast thou fought day
by th' mass so did all thank richard
god knows how long have live
have defended from imminent death
well lords have not got which have
'tis not enough our foes are this time fled
being opposites such repairing nature
york know our safety follow them
as hear king fled london
call present court parliament
let us pursue him ere writs go forth
what says lord warwick shall after them
now by faith lords 'twas glorious day
saint albans' battle won by famous york
shall eterniz'd all age come

more such days as these us befall exeunt

act scene
london parliament house
alarum enter duke york edward richard norfolk montague warwick
soldiers white roses their hats
warwick wonder how king escap'd our hands
york while pursu'd horsemen north
he slily stole away left his men
whereat great lord northumberland
cheer'd up drooping army himself
lord clifford lord stafford all abreast
charg'd our main battle's front breaking
were by swords common soldiers slain
edward lord stafford's father duke buckingham
either slain or wounded dangerous
cleft his beaver downright blow
this true father behold his blood
montague brother here's earl wiltshire's blood
richard speak thou tell them what did
throwing down somerset's head
york richard hath best deserv'd all sons
but grace dead lord somerset
norfolk such hope have all line john gaunt
richard thus do hope shake king henry's head
warwick so do victorious prince york
before see thee seated throne
which now house lancaster usurps
this palace fearful king
this regal seat possess york
this thine not king henry's heirs'
york assist then sweet warwick will
hither have broken by force
norfolk we'll all assist he flies shall die
york thanks gentle norfolk stay by lords
soldiers stay lodge by this night
they go up
unless he seek thrust out perforce
york queen this day here holds her parliament
but little thinks shall her council
by words or blows here let us win our right
richard arm'd as are let's stay within this house
warwick bloody parliament shall this calld
unless plantagenet duke york king
bashful henry depos'd whose cowardice
hath made us by words our enemies
mean take possession right
warwick neither king nor he loves him best
proudest he holds up lancaster
dares stir wing if warwick shake his bells
i'll plant plantagenet root him up who dares
resolve thee richard claim english crown
york occupies throne
flourish enter king henry clifford northumberland
westmoreland exeter others red roses
king henry lords look where sturdy rebel sits
even chair state belike he means
back'd by power warwick false peer
aspire unto crown reign as king
earl northumberland he slew thy father
thine lord clifford both have vow'd revenge
him his sons his favourites his friends
northumberland if not heavens reveng'd
clifford hope thereof makes clifford mourn steel
heart anger burns cannot brook
king henry patient gentle earl westmoreland
clifford patience poltroons such as he
he durst not sit there had father liv'd
gracious lord here parliament
let us assail family york
northumberland well hast thou spoken cousin so
king henry ah know not city favours them
they have troops soldiers at their beck
king henry far thought this from henry's heart
make shambles parliament house
cousin exeter frowns words threats
shall war henry means use
thou factious duke york descend throne
kneel grace mercy at feet
am thy sovereign
york am thine
exeter shame come down he made thee duke york
exeter thy father was traitor crown
warwick exeter thou art traitor crown
following this usurping henry
clifford whom should he follow but his natural king
warwick true clifford that's richard duke york
king henry shall stand thou sit throne
york must shall so content thyself
warwick duke lancaster let him king
westmoreland he both king duke lancaster
warwick warwick shall disprove forget
are those which chas'd from field
slew fathers colours spread
march'd through city palace gates
northumberland yes warwick remember grief
by his soul thou thy house shall rue
westmoreland plantagenet thee these thy sons
thy kinsmen thy friends i'll have more lives
than drops blood were father's veins
send thee warwick such messenger
as shall revenge his death before stir
warwick poor clifford how scorn his worthless threats
york will show our title crown
if not our swords shall plead field

scene ii
before york

sought encompass'd crown
doth not object cheer heart lord

see this sight irks very soul
withhold revenge dear god 'tis not fault
nor wittingly have infring'd vow

harmful pity must laid aside
not beast would usurp their den
whose hand forest bear doth lick
not his spoils her young before her face
who scapes lurking serpent's mortal sting
not he sets his foot upon her back
smallest worm will turn being trodden
doves will peck safeguard their brood
ambitious york did level at thy crown
thou smiling while he knit his angry brows
raise his issue loving sire

didst yield consent disinherit him
which argued thee most unloving father
unreasonable creatures feed their young
though mans face fearful their eyes
yet protection their tender ones
who hath not seen them even those wings
which sometime they have us'd fearful flight
offering their own lives their young's defence
shame liege make them precedent
were not pity this goodly boy
should lose his birthright by his father's fault
long hereafter say unto his child
'what great grandfather grandsire got
careless father fondly gave away'

let his manly face which promiseth
hold thine own leave thine own him

things ill got had ever bad success
happy always was son
whose father his hoarding went hell

would father had left no more
as brings thousand fold more care keep
than possession any jot pleasure

how doth grieve thy head here

upon clifford cruel child killer

am king privileg'd speak

cannot cur'd by words therefore still
richard then executioner unsheathe thy sword
by him made us all am resolv'd
clifford's manhood lies upon his tongue
edward say henry shall have right or no
thousand men have broke their fasts day
warwick if thou deny their blood upon thy head
york justice puts his armour
prince wales if right which warwick says right
there no wrong but every thing right
richard whoever got thee there thy mother stands
well wot thou hast thy mother's tongue
queen margaret but thou art neither thy sire nor dam
but foul misshapen stigmatic
mark'd by destinies avoided
richard iron naples hid english gilt
whose father bears title king
as if channel should calld sea
sham'st thou not knowing whence thou art extraught
let thy tongue detect thy base born heart
edward wisp straw were worth thousand crowns
make this shameless callet know herself
helen greece was fairer far than thou
although thy husband may menelaus
by false woman as this king by thee
his father revelld heart france
tam'd king made dauphin stoop
had he match'd according his state
he might have kept glory this day
but when he took beggar his bed
grac'd thy poor sire his bridal day
even then sunshine brew'd show'r him
wash'd his father's fortunes forth france
what hath broach'd this tumult but thy pride
hadst thou been meek our title still had slept
pity gentle king
had slipp'd our claim until another age
george but when saw our sunshine made thy spring
thy summer bred us no increase
set axe thy usurping root
though edge hath something hit ourselves
yet know thou since have begun strike
or bath'd thy growing our heated bloods
edward this resolution defy thee
not willing any longer conference
since thou deniest gentle king speak
sound trumpets let our bloody colours wave
either victory or else grave
queen margaret stay edward
edward no wrangling woman we'll no longer stay
these words will cost ten thousand lives this day
scene iii
field battle between towton saxton yorkshire

warwick forspent toil as runners race

spite spite needs must rest awhile

this world frowns edward's sun clouded

enter george
george our hap lost our hope but sad despair
our ranks are broke ruin follows us
what counsel give whither shall fly
edward bootless flight they follow us wings
weak are cannot shun pursuit
enter richard
thy brother's blood thirsty earth hath drunk
broach'd steely point clifford's lance
very pangs death he cried
dismal clangor heard from far
'warwick revenge brother revenge death'
so underneath belly their steeds
staind their fetlocks his smoking blood
noble gentleman gave up ghost
warwick then let earth drunken our blood
why stand soft hearted women here
wailing our losses whiles foe doth rage
look upon as if tragedy
were play'd jest by counterfeiting actors
here knee vow god above
i'll never pause again never stand still
till either death hath clos'd these eyes mine
or fortune given measure revenge
edward o warwick do bend knee thine
ere knee rise from earth's cold face
throw hands mine eyes heart thee
thou setter up plucker down kings
beseeching thee if thy will stands
foes this body must prey
yet thy brazen gates heaven may ope
give sweet passage sinful soul
now lords take leave until meet again
where'er heaven or earth
let embrace thee weary arms
did never weep now melt woe
winter should cut off our spring time so
warwick away away once more sweet lords farewell
george yet let us all together our troops
give them leave fly will not stay
call them pillars will stand us
if thrive promise them such rewards
as victors wear at olympian games
yet hope life victory
forslow no longer make hence amain exeunt

another part field
alarum enter king henry alone
king henry this battle fares morning's war
when dying clouds contend growing light
what time shepherd blowing his nails
can neither call perfect day nor night
now sways this way mighty sea
forc'd by tide combat wind
now sways way selfsame sea
sometime flood prevails then wind
now one better then another best
both tugging victors breast breast
yet neither conqueror nor conquered
so equal poise this fell war
here this molehill will sit down
whom god will there victory
margaret queen clifford too
have chid from battle swearing both
would were dead if god's good will were so
what this world but grief woe
o god methinks were happy life
no better than homely swain
sit upon hill as do now
carve out dials quaintly point by point
thereby see minutes how they run
how many makes hour full complete
how many hours brings about day
how many years mortal man may live
when this known then divide times
so many hours must tend flock

so many hours must contemplate
so many hours must sport myself
so many days ewes have been young
so many weeks ere poor fools will can
so many years ere shall shear fleece
pass'd over end they were created
would bring white hairs unto quiet grave
ah what life were this how sweet how lovely
gives not hawthorn bush sweeter shade
shepherds looking their silly sheep
than doth rich embroider'd canopy
kings fear their subjects' treachery
o yes doth thousand fold doth
conclude shepherd's homely curds
his wonted sleep under fresh tree's shade
all which secure sweetly he enjoys
far beyond prince's delicates
his viands sparkling golden cup
his body couched curious bed
when care mistrust treason waits him

another door
this man whom hand hand slew fight
may possessed some store crowns

who's this o god father's face
whom this conflict unwares have killd
o heavy times begetting such events

came part york press'd by his master
who at his hands receiv'd life
have by hands life bereaved him
pardon god knew not what did
pardon father knew not thee

no more words till they have flow'd their fill

whiles lions war battle their dens

let our hearts eyes civil war
blind tears break o'ercharg'd grief

father thou so stoutly hath resisted

but let see this our foemans face
ah no no no no mine only son

this deadly quarrel daily doth beget

o death would stay these ruthful deeds

shed seas tears ne'er satisfied

misthink king not satisfied

but mighty lord this merry inclination
please dismiss either ay or no

would he were wasted marrow bones all

cross from golden time look
yet between souls desire
lustful edward's title buried
clarence henry his son young edward
all unlook'd issue their bodies
take their rooms ere can place myself
cold premeditation purpose
one stands upon promontory
spies far off shore where he would tread
wishing his foot were equal his eye
chides sea sunders him from thence
saying he'll lade dry have his way
so do wish crown being so far off

so say i'll cut causes off
flattering impossibilities

well say there no kingdom then richard
what other pleasure can world afford
i'll make heaven lady's lap
deck body gay ornaments
witch sweet ladies words looks
o miserable thought more unlikely
than accomplish twenty golden crowns
why love forswore mother's womb
she did corrupt frail nature some bribe

make an envious mountain back
where sits deformity mock body
shape legs an unequal size
disproportion every part
chaos or an unlick'd bear whelp
carries no impression dam
am then man belov'd
then since this earth affords no joy
but command check o'erbear such
as are better person than myself
i'll make heaven dream upon crown
whiles live t' account this world but hell
until misshap'd trunk bear this head
round impaled glorious crown
yet know not how get crown
many lives stand between home
rents thorns rent thorns
seeking way straying from way
not knowing how find open air
but toiling desperately find out

from torment will free myself
or hew way out bloody axe
why can smile murder whiles smile

frame face all occasions

deceive more slily than ulysses could
sinon take another troy
can add colours chameleon
change shapes protheus advantages
set murderous machiavel school
tut were farther off i'll pluck down exit

dishonour laid ground

humble seat conform myself

england's true anointed lawful king
this cause poor margaret

while bethink means break off

see where comes breeder sorrow

this he moves both wind tide

lord sovereign thy vowed friend

where fame late ent'ring at his heedful ears
hath plac'd thy beauty's image thy virtue

before answer warwick his demand
springs not from edward's well meant honest love
but from deceit bred by necessity
how can tyrants safely govern home
unless abroad they purchase great alliance
prove him tyrant this reason may suffice
yet here prince edward stands king henry's son
look therefore lewis by this league marriage
thou draw not thy danger dishonour
though usurpers sway rule while
yet heav'ns are just time suppresseth wrongs
warwick injurious margaret
prince wales why not queen

thou no more art prince than she queen
which did subdue greatest part spain
after john gaunt henry fourth
whose wisdom was mirror wisest
after wise prince henry fifth
who by his prowess conquered all france
from these our henry lineally descends

told not how henry sixth hath lost
all which henry fifth had gotten
but rest tell pedigree
threescore two years silly time
make prescription kingdom's worth

link him were not lawful chosen
warwick thereon pawn credit mine honour
lewis but he gracious people's eye
warwick more henry was unfortunate
lewis then further all dissembling set aside
unto our sister bona
warwick such seems
as may beseem monarch himself
myself have often heard him say swear
this his love was an eternal plant
whereof root was fix'd virtue's ground
leaves fruit maintaind beauty's sun

unless lady bona quit his pain
bona grant or denial shall mine
warwick yet confess often ere this day
when have heard king's desert recounted
mine ear hath tempted judgment desire

but if title crown weak
as may appear by edward's good success

from giving aid which late promised
estate requires mine can yield

where having nothing nothing can he lose

now soothe forgery his

this proveth edward's love warwick's honesty

by hope have heavenly bliss

father came untimely his death

i'll undertake land them our coast
'tis not his new made bride shall succour him
as clarence as letters tell
he's very likely now fall from him
matching more wanton lust than honour
or than strength safety our country
bona dear brother how shall bona reveng'd
but by thy help this distressed queen

unless thou rescue him from foul despair
warwick mine fair lady bona joins yours

therefore at last firmly am resolv'd

therefore i'll uncrown him ere't long
there's thy reward gone exit post
lewis but warwick
thou oxford five thousand men
as occasion serves this noble queen
prince shall follow fresh supply
yet ere thou go but answer one doubt
what pledge have thy firm loyalty
warwick this shall assure constant loyalty
if our queen this young prince agree
i'll join mine eldest daughter joy
him forthwith holy wedlock bands
queen margaret yes agree thank motion
therefore delay not give thy hand warwick
thy hand thy faith irrevocable
only warwick's daughter shall thine
prince wales yes accept her she well deserves
here pledge vow give hand
he gives his hand warwick
lewis stay now these soldiers shall levied
thou lord bourbon our high admiral
shall waft them over our royal fleet
mocking marriage dame france
exeunt all but warwick
warwick came from edward as ambassador
but return his sworn mortal foe
matter marriage was charge he gave
but dreadful war shall answer his demand
had he none else make stale but
then none but shall turn his jest sorrow
was chief rais'd him crown
not pity henry's misery
but seek revenge edward's mockery exit
act iv scene
london palace
enter gloucester clarence somerset montague
gloucester now tell brother clarence what think
this new marriage lady grey
hath not our brother made worthy choice
clarence alas know 'tis far from hence france
somerset lords forbear this talk here comes king
flourish enter king edward attended lady
grey as queen pembroke stafford hastings
others four stand one side four other
gloucester his well chosen bride
clarence mind tell him plainly what think
king edward now brother clarence how our choice
stand pensive as half malcontent
clarence as well as lewis france or earl warwick
they'll take no offence at our abuse
king edward suppose they take offence without cause
they are but lewis warwick am edward
king warwick's must have will
gloucester shall have will because our king
yet hasty marriage seldom proveth well
king edward yea brother richard are offended too
gloucester not
no god forbid should wish them sever'd
sunder them yoke so well together
king edward setting scorns mislike aside
tell some reason why lady grey
should not become wife england's queen
too somerset montague
speak freely what think
clarence then this mine opinion king lewis
becomes enemy mocking him
about marriage lady bona
now dishonoured by this new marriage
king edward what if both lewis warwick appeas'd
by such invention as can devise
montague yet have joind france such alliance
would more have strength'ned this our commonwealth
'gainst foreign storms than any home bred marriage
hastings why knows not montague itself
england safe if true within itself
montague but safer when 'tis back'd france
let us back'd god seas
which he hath giv'n fence impregnable
their helps only defend ourselves
them ourselves our safety lies
clarence this one speech lord hastings well deserves
have heir lord hungerford
king edward ay what was will grant
this once will shall stand law
gloucester yet methinks grace hath not done well
unto brother loving bride
she better would have fitted or clarence
but bride bury brotherhood
clarence or else would not have bestow'd heir
lord bonville new wife's son
leave brothers go speed elsewhere
king edward alas poor clarence wife
thou art malcontent will provide thee
clarence choosing yourself show'd judgment
play broker mine own behalf
end shortly mind leave
king edward leave or tarry edward will king
not tied unto his brother's will
queen elizabeth lords before pleas'd his majesty
raise state title queen
do but right must all confess
was not ignoble descent
meaner than myself have had fortune
so dislikes whom would pleasing
doth cloud joys danger sorrow
king edward love forbear fawn upon their frowns
what danger or what sorrow can befall thee
so long as edward thy constant friend
their true sovereign whom they must obey
nay whom they shall obey love thee too
unless they seek hatred at hands
which if they do yet will keep thee safe
gloucester aside hear yet say not much but think more
enter post
king edward now messenger what letters or what news
from france
messenger sovereign liege no letters few words
but such as without special pardon
dare not relate
king edward go pardon thee therefore brief
tell their words as near as thou canst guess them
messenger at depart these were his very words
'go tell false edward supposed king
lewis france sending over masquers
revel him his new bride'
king edward lewis so brave belike he thinks henry
but what said lady bona marriage
messenger these were her words utt'red mild disdain
'tell him hope he'll prove widower shortly
i'll wear willow garland his sake'
she had wrong but what said henry's queen
have heard she was there place
messenger 'tell him' quoth she 'my mourning weeds are done
am ready put armour on'
king edward belike she minds play amazon
but what said warwick these injuries
messenger he more incens'd against majesty
than all rest discharg'd these words
'tell him from he hath done wrong
king edward ha durst traitor breathe out so proud words
well will arm being thus forewarnd
they shall have wars pay their presumption
but say warwick friends margaret
messenger ay gracious sovereign they are so link'd friendship
young prince edward marries warwick's daughter
clarence belike elder clarence will have younger
now brother king farewell sit fast
will hence warwick's other daughter
may not prove inferior yourself
love warwick follow
exit somerset follows
gloucester aside not
thoughts aim at further matter
stay not love edward but crown
king edward clarence somerset both gone warwick
yet am arm'd against worst can happen
haste needful this desp'rate case
go levy men make prepare war
they are already or quickly will landed
myself person will straight follow
exeunt pembroke stafford
but ere go hastings montague
resolve doubt twain all rest
are near warwick by blood by alliance
tell if love warwick more than
if so then both depart him
but if mind hold true obedience
give assurance some friendly vow
may never have suspect
montague so god help montague as he proves true
hastings hastings as he favours edward's cause
king edward now brother richard will stand by us
gloucester ay despite all shall withstand
king edward why so then am sure victory
now therefore let us hence lose no hour
scene ii
plain warwickshire
enter warwick oxford french soldiers
warwick trust lord all hitherto goes well
common people by numbers swarm us
enter clarence somerset
but see where somerset clarence comes
speak suddenly lords are all friends
clarence fear not lord
welcome somerset hold cowardice
rest mistrustful where noble heart
hath pawnd an open hand sign love
else might think clarence edward's brother
were but feigned friend our proceedings
but welcome sweet clarence daughter shall thine
now what rests but night's coverture
thy brother being carelessly encamp'd
his soldiers lurking towns about
may surprise take him at our pleasure
our scouts have found adventure very easy
as ulysses stout diomede
sleight manhood stole rhesus' tents
brought from thence thracian fatal steeds
so well cover'd night's black mantle
at unawares may beat down edward's guard
seize himself say not 'slaughter him'
intend but only surprise him
applaud name henry leader
they all cry 'henry'
why then let's our way silent sort
warwick his friends god saint george exeunt
scene iii
edward's camp near warwick
enter three watchmen guard king's tent
first watchman come masters each man take his stand
king by this set him down sleep
first watchman why no he hath made solemn vow
never lie take his natural rest
till warwick or himself quite suppress'd
second watchman morrow then belike shall day
if warwick so near as men report
third watchman but say pray what nobleman
king here resteth his tent
first watchman 'tis lord hastings king's chiefest friend
third watchman o so but why commands king
while he himself keeps cold field
second watchman 'tis more honour because more dangerous
third watchman ay but give worship quietness
better than dangerous honour
if warwick knew what estate he stands
'tis doubted he would waken him
first watchman unless our halberds did shut up his passage
second watchman ay wherefore else guard his royal tent
but defend his person from night foes
french soldiers silent all
warwick this his tent see where stand his guard
courage masters honour now or never
but follow edward shall ours
first watchman who goes there
second watchman stay or thou diest
warwick rest cry all 'warwick warwick'
set upon guard who fly crying 'arm arm' warwick
rest following them
rest bringing king out his gown
sitting chair gloucester hastings fly over stage
somerset what are they fly there
warwick richard hastings let them go here duke
king edward duke why warwick when parted
thou calldst king
warwick ay but case alter'd
when disgrac'd embassade
then degraded from being king
alas how should govern any kingdom
know not how use ambassadors
nor how contented one wife
nor how use brothers brotherly
nor how study people's welfare
nor how shroud yourself from enemies
king edward yea brother clarence art thou here too
nay then see edward needs must down
yet warwick despite all mischance
edward will always bear himself as king
though fortune's malice overthrow state
mind exceeds compass her wheel
warwick then his mind edward england's king
takes off his crown
but henry now shall wear english crown
true king indeed thou but shadow
lord somerset at request
see forthwith duke edward convey'd
when have fought pembroke his fellows
i'll follow tell what answer
lewis lady bona send him
now while farewell good duke york
king edward what fates impose men must needs abide
boots not resist both wind tide
they lead him out forcibly
oxford what now remains lords us do
but march london our soldiers
free king henry from imprisonment
see him seated regal throne exeunt
scene iv
london palace
enter queen elizabeth rivers
rivers madam what makes this sudden change
queen elizabeth why brother rivers are yet learn
what late misfortune befalln king edward
rivers what loss some pitch'd battle against warwick
rivers then sovereign slain
queen elizabeth ay almost slain he taken prisoner
either betray'd by falsehood his guard
or by his foe surpris'd at unawares
as further have understand
new committed bishop york
fell warwick's brother by our foe
rivers these news must confess are full grief
yet gracious madam bear as may
queen elizabeth till then fair hope must hinder life's decay
rather wean from despair
love edward's offspring womb
this makes bridle passion
bear mildness misfortune's cross
ay ay this draw many tear
stop rising blood sucking sighs
lest sighs or tears blast or drown
king edward's fruit true heir th' english crown
queen elizabeth am inform'd he comes towards london
set crown once more henry's head
guess thou rest king edward's friends must down
but prevent tyrant's violence
trust not him hath once broken faith
i'll hence forthwith unto sanctuary
save at least heir edward's right
there shall rest secure from force fraud
come therefore let us fly while may fly
scene v
park near middleham castle yorkshire
enter gloucester lord hastings sir william stanley others
gloucester now lord hastings sir william stanley
leave off wonder why drew hither
into this chiefest thicket park
thus stands case know our king brother
prisoner bishop here at whose hands
he hath good usage great liberty
comes hunting this way disport himself
have advertis'd him by secret means
if about this hour he make this way
under colour his usual game
he shall here find his friends horse men
set him free from his captivity
enter king edward huntsman him
huntsman this way lord this way lies game
king edward nay this way man see where huntsmen stand
stand thus close steal bishop's deer
gloucester brother time case requireth haste
horse stands ready at park corner
king edward but whither shall then
hastings lynn lord shipt from thence flanders
gloucester well guess'd believe was meaning
king edward stanley will requite thy forwardness

scene vi
london tower
flourish enter king henry clarence warwick somerset young henry
earl richmond oxford montague lieutenant tower attendants
king henry master lieutenant now god friends
have shaken edward from regal seat
fear hope sorrows unto joys
at our enlargement what are thy due fees
lieutenant subjects may challenge nothing their sov'reigns
but if an humble prayer may prevail
then crave pardon majesty
king henry what lieutenant well using
nay thou sure i'll well requite thy kindness
made imprisonment pleasure
ay such pleasure as incaged birds
at last by notes household harmony
they quite forget their loss liberty
but warwick after god thou set'st free
chiefly therefore thank god thee
he was author thou instrument
therefore may conquer fortune's spite
by living low where fortune cannot hurt
people this blessed land
may not punish'd thwarting stars
here resign government thee
thou art fortunate all thy deeds
warwick grace hath still been fam'd virtuous
now may seem as wise as virtuous
by spying avoiding fortune's malice
few men rightly temper stars
yet this one thing let blame grace
choosing when clarence place
clarence no warwick thou art worthy sway
adjudg'd an olive branch laurel crown
as likely blest peace war
therefore yield thee free consent
warwick choose clarence only protector
king henry warwick clarence give both hands
now join hands hands hearts
no dissension hinder government
make both protectors this land
while myself will lead private life
sins rebuke creator's praise
warwick what answers clarence his sovereigns will
clarence he consents if warwick yield consent
thy fortune repose myself
warwick why then though loath yet must content
we'll yoke together double shadow
henry's body supply his place
mean bearing weight government
while he enjoys honour his ease
forthwith edward pronounc'd traitor
all his lands goods confiscated
clarence what else succession determind
warwick ay therein clarence shall not want his part
king henry but first all chief affairs
let entreat command no more
margaret queen son edward
sent return from france speed
till see them here by doubtful fear
clarence shall done sovereign all speed
king henry lord somerset what youth
whom seem have so tender care
somerset liege young henry earl richmond
king henry come hither england's hope
lays his hand his head
if secret powers
suggest but truth divining thoughts
this pretty lad will prove our country's bliss
his head by nature fram'd wear crown
his hand wield sceptre himself
likely time bless regal throne
make much him lords this he
must help more than are hurt by
enter post
warwick what news friend
post edward escaped from brother
fled as he hears since burgundy
post he was convey'd by richard duke gloucester
lord hastings who attended him
secret ambush forest side
from bishop's huntsmen rescu'd him
hunting was his daily exercise
warwick brother was too careless his charge
but let us hence sovereign provide
salve any sore may betide
exeunt all but somerset richmond oxford
doubtless burgundy will yield him help
shall have more wars befor't long
as henry's late presaging prophecy
did glad heart hope this young richmond
so doth heart misgive these conflicts
what may befall him his harm ours
therefore lord oxford prevent worst
forthwith we'll send him hence brittany
till storms past civil enmity
'tis richmond rest shall down
somerset shall so he shall brittany
come therefore let's about speedily exeunt
scene vii
before york

king edward now brother richard lord hastings rest
yet thus far fortune maketh us amends
says once more shall interchange

brought desired help from burgundy
what then remains being thus arriv'd
from ravenspurgh haven before gates york
but enter as into our dukedom
gloucester gates made fast brother not this
many men stumble at threshold
are well foretold danger lurks within

enter walls mayor york
his brethren
mayor lords were forewarned coming
shut gates safety ourselves
now owe allegiance unto henry

as being well content alone

he descends

takes his keys

if you'll not here proclaim yourself our king
i'll leave fortune gone
keep them back come succour
gloucester why brother wherefore stand nice points
king edward when grow stronger then we'll make our claim

hastings away scrupulous wit now arms must rule

bruit thereof will bring many friends

now will edward's champion

throws down gauntlet

above border this horizon
we'll forward towards warwick his mates
well wot henry no soldier

not mutinous peace yet bold war

thou brother montague buckingham

cousin exeter what thinks lordship
methinks power edward hath field
should not able encounter mine
exeter doubt he will seduce rest
king henry that's not fear meed hath got fame
have not stopp'd mine ears their demands
nor posted off their suits slow delays
pity hath been balm heal their wounds
mildness hath allay'd their swelling griefs
have not been desirous their wealth
nor much oppress'd them great subsidies
nor forward revenge though they much err'd
then why should they love edward more than
no exeter these graces challenge grace
when lion fawns upon lamb
lamb will never cease follow him
shout within 'a lancaster lancaster'
exeter hark hark lord what shouts are these
king edward seize shame fac'd henry bear him hence
once again proclaim us king england
are fount makes small brooks flow
now stops thy spring sea shall suck them dry
swell so much higher by their ebb
hence him tower let him not speak
exeunt some king henry
lords towards coventry bend our course
where peremptory warwick now remains
cold biting winter mars our hop'd hay
gloucester away betimes before his forces join
take great grown traitor unawares
brave warriors march amain towards coventry exeunt
act v scene
empty

where post came from montague

enter sir john somerville
warwick say somerville what says loving son
by thy guess how nigh clarence now
somerville at southam did leave him his forces
do expect him here some two hours hence

somerville not his lord here southam lies
drum honour hears marcheth from warwick
warwick who should belike unlook'd friends
somerville they are at hand shall quickly know
march flourish enter king edward gloucester
soldiers

where slept our scouts or how are they seduc'd
could hear no news his repair
king edward now warwick wilt thou ope city gates
speak gentle words humbly bend thy knee
call edward king at his hands beg mercy
he shall pardon thee these outrages

confess who set thee up pluck'd thee down
call warwick patron penitent
gloucester thought at least he would have said king
or did he make jest against his will
warwick not dukedom sir goodly gift

i'll do thee service so good gift

king edward why then 'tis mine if but by warwick's gift
warwick thou art no atlas so great weight
weakling warwick takes his gift again
king edward but warwick's king edward's prisoner
gallant warwick do but answer this
what body when head off
gloucester alas warwick had no more forecast
but whiles he thought steal single ten
king was slily finger'd from deck
left poor henry at bishop's palace
ten one you'll meet him tower
king edward 'tis even so yet are warwick still
nay when strike now or else iron cools
warwick had rather chop this hand off at blow
other fling at thy face
than bear so low sail strike thee
king edward sail how thou canst have wind tide thy friend
this hand fast wound about thy coal black hair
shall whiles thy head warm new cut off
write dust this sentence thy blood
'wind changing warwick now can change no more'
warwick o cheerful colours see where oxford comes
oxford oxford oxford lancaster
he his forces enter city
gloucester gates are open let us enter too
king edward so other foes may set upon our backs
stand good array they no doubt
will issue out again bid us battle
if not city being but small defence
we'll quietly rouse traitors same
enter montague drum colours
montague montague montague lancaster
he his forces enter city

even dearest blood bodies bear

mind presageth happy gain conquest
enter somerset drum colours
somerset somerset somerset lancaster
gloucester two thy name both dukes somerset
have sold their lives unto house york
thou shalt third if this sword hold
enter clarence drum colours
warwick lo where george clarence sweeps along
force enough bid his brother battle
whom an upright zeal right prevails
more than nature brother's love
clarence clarence clarence lancaster
parley sirrah george clarence
sound parley richard clarence whisper
warwick come clarence come thou wilt if warwick call
clarence taking red rose from his hat throwing
at warwick
father warwick know what this means
look here throw infamy at thee
will not ruinate father's house
who gave his blood lime stones together
clarence so harsh so blunt unnatural
bend fatal instruments war
against his brother his lawful king
perhaps thou wilt object holy oath
keep oath were more impiety
than jephtha when he sacrific'd his daughter
am so sorry trespass made
deserve well at brother's hands
here proclaim myself thy mortal foe
as will meet thee if thou stir abroad
plague thee thy foul misleading
so proud hearted warwick defy thee
brother turn blushing cheeks
pardon edward will make amends
richard do not frown upon faults
will henceforth no more unconstant
king edward now welcome more ten times more belov'd
than if thou never hadst deserv'd our hate
warwick o passing traitor perjur'd unjust

or shall beat stones about thine ears

will away towards barnet presently
bid thee battle edward if thou dar'st
king edward yes warwick edward dares leads way
lords field saint george victory
exeunt yorkists
scene ii
field battle near barnet
alarum excursions enter king edward bringing forth warwick wounded
king edward so lie thou there die thou die our fear
warwick was bug fear'd us all
now montague sit fast seek thee
warwick's bones may keep thine company exit
warwick ah who nigh come friend or foe
tell who victor york or warwick
blood want strength sick heart shows
must yield body earth
by fall conquest foe
thus yields cedar axe's edge
whose arms gave shelter princely eagle
under whose shade ramping lion slept
whose top branch overpeer'd jove's spreading tree
kept low shrubs from winter's pow'rful wind
these eyes now are dimm'd death's black veil
search secret treasons world
wrinkles brows now filld blood
were lik'ned oft kingly sepulchres
who liv'd king but could dig his grave
who durst smile when warwick bent his brow
lo now glory smear'd dust blood
parks walks manors had
even now forsake all lands
nothing left but body's length
live how can yet die must
enter oxford somerset
somerset ah warwick warwick wert thou as are
might recover all our loss again
queen from france hath brought puissant power
even now heard news ah couldst thou fly
warwick why then would not fly ah montague
if thou there sweet brother take hand
thy lips keep soul while
thy tears would wash this cold congealed blood
glues lips will not let speak
come quickly montague or am dead
somerset ah warwick montague hath breath'd his last
latest gasp cried out warwick
said 'commend valiant brother'
more he would have said more he spoke
which sounded clamour vault
mought not distinguish'd but at last
'o farewell warwick'
warwick sweet rest his soul fly lords save yourselves
warwick bids all farewell meet heaven
empty
oxford away away meet queens great power
here they bear away his body
scene iii
another part field
flourish enter king triumph gloucester clarence rest
are grac'd wreaths victory
but midst this bright shining day
spy black suspicious threat'ning cloud
will encounter our glorious sun
ere he attain his easeful western bed
mean lords those powers queen
hath rais'd gallia have arriv'd our coast
as hear march fight us
clarence little gale will soon disperse cloud
thy very beams will dry those vapours up
every cloud engenders not storm
gloucester queen valued thirty thousand strong
somerset oxford fled her
if she have time breathe well assur'd
her faction will full as strong as ours
king edward are advertis'd by our loving friends
they do hold their course toward tewksbury
having now best at barnet field
as march our strength will augmented
every county as go along
strike up drum cry 'courage' away exeunt
scene iv
plains wear tewksbury
flourish march enter queen margaret prince edward somerset oxford
soldiers
queen margaret great lords wise men ne'er sit wail their
empty
what though mast now blown overboard
cable broke holding anchor lost
half our sailors swallow'd flood
yet lives our pilot still is't meet he
should leave helm fearful lad
tearful eyes add water sea
give more strength which hath too much
whiles his moan ship splits rock
which industry courage might have sav'd
say warwick was our anchor what
montague our top mast what him
our slaught'red friends tackles what these
why not oxford here another anchor
somerset another goodly mast
friends france our shrouds tacklings
though unskilful why not ned
once allow'd skilful pilot's charge
will not from helm sit weep
from shelves rocks threaten us wreck
as good chide waves as speak them fair
what edward but ruthless sea
what clarence but quicksand deceit
richard but ragged fatal rock
all these enemies our poor bark
say can swim alas 'tis but while
tread sand why there quickly sink
bestride rock tide will wash off
this speak lords let understand
if case some one would fly from us
there's no hop'd mercy brothers
more than ruthless waves sands rocks
why courage then what cannot avoided
'twere childish weakness lament or fear
prince wales methinks woman this valiant spirit
should if coward hear her speak these words
infuse his breast magnanimity
speak not this as doubting any here
did but suspect fearful man
he should have leave go away betimes
lest our need he might infect another
make him spirit himself
if any such here as god forbid
let him depart before need his help
oxford women children so high courage
warriors faint why 'twere perpetual shame
doth live again thee long mayst thou eve
bear his image renew his glories
somerset he will not fight such hope
go home bed owl by day
if he arise mock'd wond'red at

oxford thought no less his policy

scene vi

king henry so flies reckless shepherd from wolf
so first harmless sheep doth yield his fleece
next his throat unto butcher's knife
what scene death hath roscius now act
gloucester suspicion always haunts guilty mind
king henry bird hath been limed bush
trembling wings misdoubteth every bush
hapless male one sweet bird
have now fatal object eye
where poor young was lim'd was caught killd

taught his son office fowl
yet all his wings fool was drownd
king henry daedalus poor boy icarus
sun sear'd wings sweet boy
thy brother edward thyself sea
whose envious gulf did swallow up his life
ah kill thy weapon not words
breast can better brook thy dagger's point
than can ears tragic history
but wherefore dost thou come is't life

why then thou are an executioner
gloucester thy son killd his presumption

thou hadst not liv'd kill son mine
thus prophesy many thousand
which now mistrust no parcel fear
many an old mans sigh many widow's
many an orphans water standing eye
men their sons wives their husbands

chatt'ring pies dismal discords sung
thy mother felt more than mother's pain
yet brought forth less than mother's hope
wit an indigest deformed lump

signify thou cam'st bite world
if rest true which have heard
thou cam'st

stabs him
this amongst rest was ordaind

sink ground thought would have mounted

if any spark life yet remaining
down down hell say sent thee thither
stabs him again
have neither pity love nor fear

came into world legs forward
had not reason think ye make haste
seek their ruin usurp'd our right
midwife wonder'd women cried

so was which plainly signified
should snarl bite play dog
then since heavens have shap'd body so
let hell make crook'd mind answer
this word 'love' which greybeards call divine
resident men one another
not am myself alone

but will sort pitchy day thee
will buzz abroad such prophecies

king henry eighth
prologue
come no more make laugh things now
bear weighty serious brow
sad high working full state woe
such noble scenes as draw eye flow
now present those can pity here
may if they think well let fall tear
subject will deserve such as give
may here find truth too those come see
only show or two so agree
play may pass if they still willing
i'll undertake may see away their shilling
richly two short hours only they
come hear merry bawdy play
noise targets or see fellow
long motley coat guarded yellow
will deceiv'd gentle hearers know
as fool fight beside forfeiting
our own brains opinion bring
make only true now intend
will leave us never an understanding friend
therefore goodness sake as are known
first happiest hearers town
sad as would make ye think ye see
very persons our noble story
as they were living think see them great
thousand friends then moment see
how soon this mightiness meets misery
if can merry then i'll say
man may weep upon his wedding day
act scene 1
london palace
enter duke norfolk at one door at other

healthful ever since fresh admirer
what saw there
buckingham an untimely ague
stay'd prisoner chamber when
those suns glory those two lights men
met vale andren
norfolk 'twixt guynes arde
was then present saw them salute horseback
their embracement as they grew together
which had they what four thrond ones could have weigh'd
such compounded one
buckingham all whole time
was chamber's prisoner
norfolk then lost
view earthly glory men might say
till this time pomp was single but now married
one above itself each following day
made former wonders its day french
all clinquant all gold heathen gods
shone down english morrow they
made britain india every man stood
show'd mine their dwarfish pages were
as cherubins an gilt madams too
not us'd toil did almost sweat bear
pride upon them their very labour
was them as painting now this masque
made fool beggar two kings
equal lustre were now best now worst
as presence did present them him eye
still him praise being present both
'twas said they saw but one no discerner
durst wag his tongue censure when these suns
so they phrase 'em by their heralds challeng'd
noble spirits arms they did perform
beyond thought's compass former fabulous story
bevis was believ'd
buckingham o go far

mean who set body limbs

such business

act scene 3
london palace
enter lord chamberlain lord sandys
chamberlain is't possible spells france should juggle
men into such strange mysteries
sandys new customs
though they never so ridiculous
nay let 'em unmanly yet are follow'd
have got by late voyage but merely
fit or two o' th' face but they are shrewd ones
when they hold 'em would swear directly
their very noses had been counsellors
pepin or clotharius they keep state so
sandys they have all new legs lame ones one would take
never saw 'em pace before spavin
or springhalt reignd among 'em

all their honourable points ignorance
pertaining thereunto as fights fireworks
abusing better men than they can

understand again honest men

lag end their lewdness laugh'd at

are grown so catching

example
griffith well voice goes madam
after stout earl northumberland
arrested him at york brought him forward
as man sorely tainted his answer
he fell sick suddenly grew so ill
he could not sit his mule
griffith at last easy roads he came leicester
lodg'd abbey where reverend abbot
all his covent honourably receiv'd him
whom he gave these words 'o father abbot
an old man broken storms state
come lay his weary bones among ye
give him little earth charity'
so went bed where eagerly his sickness
pursu'd him still three nights after this
foretold should his last full repentance
continual meditations tears sorrows
he gave his honours world again
his blessed part heaven slept peace
katharine so may he rest his faults lie gently him
yet thus far griffith give leave speak him
yet charity he was man
an unbounded stomach ever ranking
himself princes one by suggestion
his own opinion was his law i' th' presence
he would say untruths ever double
both his words meaning he was never
but where he meant ruin pitiful
his promises were as he then was mighty
but his performance as he now nothing
his own body he was ill gave
clergy ill example
griffith noble madam
write water may please highness
hear speak his good now
katharine yes good griffith
were malicious else
griffith this cardinal
though from an humble stock undoubtedly
was fashiond much honour from his cradle
he was scholar ripe good one
exceeding wise fair spoken persuading
but those men sought him sweet as summer
though he were unsatisfied getting
which was sin yet bestowing madam
he was most princely ever witness him
those twins learning he rais'd
ipswich oxford one which fell him
unwilling outlive good did
other though unfinish'd yet so famous
so excellent art still so rising
his overthrow heap'd happiness upon him
then not till then he felt himself
found blessedness being little
add greater honours his age
than man could give him he died fearing god
katharine after death wish no other herald
no other speaker living actions
keep mine honour from corruption
but such an honest chronicler as griffith
thy religious truth modesty
now his ashes honour peace him
patience near still set lower
have not long trouble thee good griffith

nam'd knell whilst sit meditating
celestial harmony go
sad solemn music
griffith she asleep good wench let's sit down quiet
vision
enter solemnly tripping one after another six
personages clad white robes wearing their
heads garlands bays golden vizards their
faces branches bays or palm their hands they
first congee unto her then dance at certain
changes first two hold spare garland over her
head at which other four make reverent curtsies
then two held garland deliver
order their changes holding garland over
her head which done they deliver same garland
last two who likewise observe same order
at which as were by inspiration she makes
her sleep signs rejoicing holdeth up her
hands heaven so their dancing vanish
carrying garland them music continues
katharine spirits peace where are ye are ye all gone
leave here wretchedness behind ye
katharine not call
saw ye none enter since slept
griffith none madam

invite banquet whose bright faces
cast thousand beams upon sun
they promis'd eternal happiness
brought garlands griffith which feel
am not worthy yet wear shall assuredly
possess fancy

they are harsh heavy music ceases
patience do note
how much her grace alter'd sudden
how long her face drawn how pale she looks
an earthly cold mark her eyes
griffith she going wench pray pray
patience heaven comfort her
messenger ant grace
katharine are saucy fellow
deserve no more reverence

use so rude behaviour go kneel

haste made unmannerly there staying

who from sacred ashes her honour

which if he can prove 'a pops out

king john good blunt fellow why being younger born

but once he slander'd bastardy
but whe'er as true begot or no
still lay upon mother's head
but am as well begot liege
fair fall bones took pains
compare our faces judge yourself

o old sir robert father knee
king john why what madcap hath heaven lent us here
elinor he hath trick coeur de lions face
accent his tongue affecteth him
do not read some tokens son
large composition this man
king john mine eye hath well examined his parts
finds them perfect richard sirrah speak
what doth move claim brother's land
bastard because he hath half face father
half fac'd groat five hundred pound year
robert gracious liege when father liv'd
brother did employ father much
bastard well sir by this cannot get land
tale must how he employ'd mother
robert once dispatch'd him an embassy
germany there emperor
treat high affairs touching time
th' advantage his absence took king
where how he did prevail shame speak
but truth truth large lengths seas shores
between father mother lay
as have heard father speak himself
when this same lusty gentleman was got
upon his death bed he by will bequeath'd
his lands took his death
this mother's son was none his
if he were he came into world
then good liege let have what mine
father's land as was father's will
king john sirrah brother legitimate
father's wife did after wedlock bear him
if she did play false fault was hers
which fault lies hazards all husbands
marry wives tell how if brother
who as say took pains get this son
had father claim'd this son his
this calf bred from his cow from all world
sooth he might then if he were brother's
brother might not claim him nor father
being none his refuse him this concludes
mother's son did get father's heir
father's heir must have father's land
robert shall then father's will no force
dispossess child which not his
bastard no more force dispossess sir

thy brother enjoy thy land
or reputed son coeur de lion
lord thy presence no land beside
bastard madam an if brother had shape
had his sir robert's his him
if legs were two such riding rods
arms such eel skins stuff'd face so thin
mine ear durst not stick rose
his shape were heir all this land
would might never stir from off this place
would give every foot have this face
would not sir nob any case

am soldier now bound france

face hath got five hundred pound year
madam i'll follow unto death

bastard our country manners give our betters way

now blessed hour by night or day

am thy grandam richard call so
bastard madam by chance but not by truth what though
something about little from right

am howe'er was begot

but many many foot land worse
well now can make any joan lady

new made honour doth forget mens names

if thou stand excommunicate curs'd
king philip good reverend father make person yours
tell how would bestow yourself
this royal hand mine are newly knit
married league coupled link'd together
all religious strength sacred vows
latest breath gave sound words
was deep sworn faith peace amity true love
between our kingdoms our royal selves
even before this truce but new before
no longer than well could wash our hands
clap this royal bargain up peace
heaven knows they were besmear'd overstaind
fearful difference incensed kings
shall these hands so lately purg'd blood
so newly joind love so strong both
unyoke this seizure this kind regreet
play fast loose faith so jest heaven
make such unconstant children ourselves
as now again snatch our palm from palm
unswear faith sworn marriage bed
smiling peace march bloody host
true sincerity o holy sir
reverend father let not so
out grace devise ordain impose
some gentle order then shall blest
do pleasure continue friends
pandulph all form formless order orderless
save what opposite england's love
therefore arms champion our church
or let church our mother breathe her curse
france thou mayst hold serpent by tongue
chafed lion by mortal paw
fasting tiger safer by tooth
than keep peace hand which thou dost hold
king philip may disjoin hand but not faith
pandulph so mak'st thou faith an enemy faith
civil war set'st oath oath
thy tongue against thy tongue o let thy vow
first made heaven first heaven perform'd
what since thou swor'st sworn against thyself
may not performed by thyself
which thou hast sworn do amiss
not amiss when truly done
being not done where doing tends ill
truth then most done not doing
better act purposes mistook
mistake again though indirect
yet indirection thereby grows direct
within scorched veins one new burnd
religion doth make vows kept
but thou hast sworn against religion
by what thou swear'st against thing thou swear'st
mak'st an oath surety thy truth
against an oath truth thou art unsure
swear swears only not forsworn
else what mockery should swear
but thou dost swear only forsworn
therefore thy later vows against thy first
thyself rebellion thyself
better conquest never canst thou make
than arm thy constant thy nobler parts
against these giddy loose suggestions
upon which better part our pray'rs come
if thou vouchsafe them but if not then know
peril our curses fight thee
so heavy as thou shalt not shake them off
austria rebellion flat rebellion
bastard willt not
will not calf's skin stop mouth thine
lewis father arms
blanch upon thy wedding day
against blood thou hast married
what shall our feast kept slaughtered men
shall braying trumpets loud churlish drums
clamours hell measures our pomp
'husband' mouth even name
which till this time tongue did ne'er pronounce
upon knee beg go not arms
against mine uncle
constance o upon knee
made hard kneeling do pray thee
thou virtuous dauphin alter not doom
forethought by heaven
blanch now shall see thy love what motive may
constance which upholdeth him thee upholds
his honour o thine honour lewis thine honour
lewis muse majesty doth seem so cold
when such profound respects do pull
pandulph will denounce curse upon his head

as he will well then france shall rue

which side must go withal
am both each army hath hand
their rage having hold both
they whirl asunder dismember
husband cannot pray thou mayst win
uncle needs must pray thou mayst lose
father may not wish fortune thine
whoever wins side shall lose
assured loss before match play'd
lewis lady thy fortune lies
blanch there where fortune lives there life dies

rage whose heat hath this condition
nothing can allay nothing but blood

ashes ere our blood shall quench fire
look thyself thou art jeopardy

scene 4
enter king philip lewis pandulph attendants

are not beaten not angiers lost

so hot speed such advice dispos'd
such temperate order so fierce cause
doth want example who hath read or heard
any kindred action this
king philip well could bear england had this praise
so could find some pattern our shame

look who comes here grave unto soul

prithee lady go away

but which ends all counsel true redress

come grin will think thou smilst
buss thee as thy wife misery's love
o come
king philip o fair affliction peace
o tongue were thunder's mouth
then passion would shake world
rouse from sleep fell anatomy
which cannot hear lady's feeble voice
which scorns modern invocation
pandulph lady utter madness not sorrow
constance thou art not holy belie so
am not mad this hair tear mine
name constance was geffrey's wife
am not mad would heaven were
then 'tis should forget myself
o if could what grief should forget
preach some philosophy make mad
thou shalt canoniz'd cardinal
being not mad but sensible grief
reasonable part produces reason
how may deliver'd these woes
teaches kill or hang myself
or madly think babe clouts were he
am not mad too well too well feel
different plague each calamity
king philip bind up those tresses o what love note
fair multitude those her hairs
where but by chance silver drop hath falln
even drop ten thousand wiry friends
do glue themselves sociable grief
true inseparable faithful loves
constance england if will
king philip bind up hairs
constance yes will wherefore will do
tore them from their bonds cried aloud
'o these hands could so redeem son
as they have given these hairs their liberty'
but now envy at their liberty
will again commit them their bonds
because poor child prisoner
shall see know our friends heaven
if true shall see boy again
since birth cain first male child
him did but yesterday suspire
there was not such gracious creature born
but now will canker sorrow eat bud
chase native beauty from his cheek
he will look as hollow as ghost
as dim meagre as an ague's fit
when shall meet him court heaven
shall not know him therefore never never
must behold pretty arthur more

constance he talks never had son

then have reason fond grief
fare well had such loss as
could give better comfort than do
will not keep this form upon head
tearing her hair
when there such disorder wit
o lord boy arthur fair son
life joy food ail world

life as tedious as twice told tale
vexing dull ear drowsy man

yields nought but shame bitterness
pandulph before curing strong disease
even instant repair health
fit strongest evils take leave
what have lost by losing this day
lewis all days glory joy happiness
pandulph if had won certainly had
no no when fortune means men most good
she looks upon them threat'ning eye
'tis strange think how much king john hath lost
this which he accounts so clearly won
are not griev'd arthur his prisoner
lewis as heartily as he glad he hath him
now hear speak prophetic spirit
even breath what mean speak
shall blow each dust each straw each little rub
out path which shall directly lead
thy foot england's throne therefore mark
john hath seiz'd arthur cannot
whiles warm life plays infant's veins
misplac'd john should entertain an hour
one minute nay one quiet breath rest
must boisterously maintaind as gaind
he stands upon slipp'ry place
makes nice no vile hold stay him up
john may stand then arthur needs must fall
so cannot but so

pandulph right lady blanch wife
may then make all claim arthur did
lewis lose life all as arthur did
john lays plots times conspire
he steeps his safety true blood
shall find but bloody safety untrue
this act so evilly borne shall cool hearts
all his people freeze up their zeal
none so small advantage shall step forth
check his reign but they will cherish
no natural exhalation sky
no scope nature no distemper'd day
but they will pluck away his natural cause
call them meteors prodigies signs
abortives presages tongues heaven
plainly denouncing vengeance upon john

but hold himself safe his prisonment

if young arthur not gone already

kiss lips unacquainted change
pick strong matter revolt wrath
out bloody fingers' ends john
methinks see this hurly all foot
o what better matter breeds
than have nam'd bastard faulconbridge

offending charity if but dozen french

or as little snow tumbled about
anon becomes mountain o noble dauphin

what may wrought out their discontent
now their souls are topful offence

lewis strong reasons makes strong actions let us go
if say ay king will not say no exeunt

best had princess wrought

watchful minutes hour

would not harm

scene 2
england king johns palace
enter king john pembroke salisbury other lords
king john here once again sit once again crownd
look'd upon hope cheerful eyes
pembroke this once again but highness pleas'd
was once superfluous were crownd before
high royalty was ne'er pluck'd off
faiths men ne'er stained revolt
any long'd change or better state
salisbury therefore possess'd double pomp
guard title was rich before
gild refined gold paint lily
throw perfume violet
smooth ice or add another hue
unto rainbow or taper light
seek beauteous eye heaven garnish
wasteful ridiculous excess
this act as an ancient tale new told
last repeating troublesome
being urged at time unseasonable
salisbury this antique well noted face
plain old form much disfigured
shifted wind unto sail
makes course thoughts fetch about
startles frights consideration
makes sound opinion sick truth suspected
pembroke when workmen strive do better than well
they do confound their skill covetousness
oftentimes excusing fault
doth make fault worse by th' excuse
as patches set upon little breach
discredit more hiding fault
than did fault before was so patch'd
salisbury this effect before were new crownd
breath'd our counsel but pleas'd highness
since all every part what would
doth make stand at what highness will
king john some reasons this double coronation
have possess'd think them strong
more more strong when lesser fear
shall indue meantime but ask
what would have reform'd not well
well shall perceive how willingly
will both hear grant requests
sound purposes all their hearts
both myself them but chief all
safety which myself them
bend their best studies heartily request
th' enfranchisement arthur whose restraint
doth move murmuring lips discontent
break into this dangerous argument
if what rest have right hold
why then fears which as they say attend
tender kinsman choke his days
barbarous ignorance deny his youth
rich advantage good exercise
time's enemies may not have this
grace occasions let our suit
have bid us ask his liberty
which our goods do no further ask
than whereupon our weal depending
counts weal he have his liberty
direction
enter hubert
aside hubert what news
pembroke this man should do bloody deed
he show'd his warrant friend mine
image wicked heinous fault
lives his eye close aspect his
doth show mood much troubled breast
do fearfully believe 'tis done
salisbury colour king doth come go
between his purpose his conscience
heralds 'twixt two dreadful battles set
his passion so ripe needs must break
pembroke when breaks fear will issue thence
foul corruption sweet child's death
king john cannot hold mortality's strong hand
good lords although will give living
suit which demand gone dead
salisbury indeed fear'd his sickness was past cure
pembroke indeed heard how near his death he was
before child himself felt he was sick
this must answer'd either here or hence

think bear shears destiny
have commandment pulse life

greatness should so grossly offer

find th' inheritance this poor child
his little kingdom forced grave
blood which ow'd breadth all this isle
three foot doth hold bad world while
this must not thus borne this will break out

there no sure foundation set blood

other four wondrous motion
king john five moons
hubert old men beldams streets
do prophesy upon dangerously
young arthur's death common their mouths
when they talk him they shake their heads
whisper one another ear
he speaks doth gripe hearer's wrist
whilst he hears makes fearful action
saw smith stand his hammer thus
whilst his iron did anvil cool
open mouth swallowing tailor's news
who his shears measure his hand
standing slippers which his nimble haste
had falsely thrust upon contrary feet
told many thousand warlike french
were embattailed rank'd kent
another lean unwash'd artificer

king john curse kings attended
by slaves take their humours warrant
break within bloody house life
winking authority
dangerous majesty when perchance frowns
more upon humour than advis'd respect
hubert here hand seal what did

made then shall this hand seal
witness against us damnation
how oft sight means do ill deeds
make deeds ill done hadst not thou been by
fellow by hand nature mark'd
this murder had not come into mind
but taking note thy abhorr'd aspect
finding thee fit bloody villainy
apt liable employ'd danger
faintly broke thee arthur's death
thou endeared king
made no conscience destroy prince
hubert lord
king john hadst thou but shook thy head or made pause
or turnd an eye doubt upon face
as bid tell tale express words
deep shame had struck dumb made break off
those thy fears might have wrought fears
but thou didst understand by signs
didst signs again parley sin
yea without stop didst let thy heart consent
consequently thy rude hand act
deed which both our tongues held vile name
nobles leave state braved
even at gates ranks foreign pow'rs
nay body fleshly land
this kingdom this confine blood breath
hostility civil tumult reigns
between conscience cousins death
hubert arm against other enemies
i'll make peace between soul
young arthur alive this hand mine
not painted crimson spots blood
within this bosom never ent'red yet
dreadful motion murderous thought
have slander'd nature form
which howsoever rude exteriorly
yet cover fairer mind
than butcher an innocent child

throw this report their incensed rage
forgive comment passion made
upon thy feature rage was blind
foul imaginary eyes blood
presented thee more hideous than thou art
o answer not but closet bring

conjure thee but slowly run more fast exeunt
scene 3
england before castle
arthur wall high yet will leap down
good ground pitiful hurt not
there's few or none do know if they did

if get down do not break limbs
i'll find thousand shifts get away
as good die go as die stay leaps down
o uncle's spirit these stones
empty

this gentle offer perilous time
