salisbury count melun noble lord france
whose private dauphins love
much more general than these lines import
salisbury or rather then set forward 'twill
two long days' journey lords or ere meet
enter bastard
bastard once more day well met distemper'd lords
king by requests presence straight
salisbury king hath dispossess'd himself us
will not line his thin bestained cloak
our pure honours nor attend foot
leaves print blood where'er walks
bastard whate'er think good words think were best
salisbury our griefs not our manners reason now
bastard but there little reason grief
therefore 'twere reason had manners now
pembroke sir sir impatience hath his privilege
bastard 'tis true hurt his master no man else
salisbury this prison what he lies here
pembroke o death made proud pure princely beauty
earth had not hole hide this deed
doth lay open urge revenge
bigot or when he doom'd this beauty grave
found too precious princely grave
salisbury sir richard what think have beheld
or have read or heard or could think
or do almost think although see
do see could thought without this object
form such another this very top
height crest or crest unto crest
wildest savagery vilest stroke
ever wall ey'd wrath or staring rage
presented tears soft remorse
pembroke all murders past do stand excus'd this
this so sole so unmatchable
shall give holiness purity
yet unbegotten sin times
prove deadly bloodshed but jest
exampled by this heinous spectacle
graceless action heavy hand
if work any hand
salisbury if work any hand
had kind light what would ensue
shameful work hubert's hand
practice purpose king
from whose obedience forbid soul
kneeling before this ruin sweet life
breathing his breathless excellence
never taste pleasures world
never infected delight
nor conversant ease idleness
till have set glory this hand
by giving worship revenge
pembroke bigot our souls religiously confirm thy words
enter hubert
hubert lords am hot haste seeking
arthur doth live king hath sent
avaunt thou hateful villain get thee gone
hubert am no villain
salisbury must rob law drawing his sword
bastard sword bright sir put up again
salisbury not till sheathe murderer's skin
hubert stand back lord salisbury stand back say
by heaven think sword's as sharp as yours
would not have lord forget yourself
nor tempt danger true defence
worth greatness nobility
bigot out dunghill dar'st thou brave nobleman
hubert not life but yet dare defend
innocent life against an emperor
salisbury thou art murderer
hubert do not prove so
yet am none whose tongue soe'er speaks false
not truly speaks who speaks not truly lies
pembroke cut him pieces
salisbury stand by or shall gall faulconbridge
bastard thou wert better gall devil salisbury
if thou but frown or stir thy foot
or teach thy hasty spleen do shame
i'll strike thee dead put up thy sword betime
or i'll so maul toasting iron
shall think devil come from hell
bigot what wilt thou do renowned faulconbridge
second villain murderer
bigot who killd this prince
hubert 'tis not an hour since left him well
honour'd him lov'd him will weep
date life out his sweet life's loss
salisbury trust not those cunning waters his eyes
villainy not without such rheum
he long traded makes seem
rivers remorse innocency
away all whose souls abhor
am stifled this smell sin
bigot away toward bury dauphin there
pembroke there tell king he may inquire us out
exeunt lords
bastard here's good world knew this fair work
beyond infinite boundless reach
mercy if thou didst this deed death
art thou damnd hubert
hubert do but hear sir
thou'rt damnd as black nay nothing so black
thou art more deep damnd than prince lucifer
there not yet so ugly fiend hell
as thou shalt if thou didst kill this child
hubert upon soul
bastard if thou didst but consent
this most cruel act do but despair
if thou want'st cord smallest thread
ever spider twisted from her womb
hang thee or wouldst thou drown thyself
put but little water spoon
shall as all ocean
enough stifle such villain up
do suspect thee very grievously
hubert if act consent or sin thought
guilty stealing sweet breath
which was embounded this beauteous clay
let hell want pains enough torture
bastard go bear him thine arms
am amaz'd methinks lose way
among thorns dangers this world
how easy dost thou take all england up
from forth this morsel dead royalty
life right truth all this realm
fled heaven england now left
tug scamble part by th' teeth
unowed interest proud swelling state
doth dogged war bristle his angry crest
snarleth gentle eyes peace
now powers from home discontents at home
meet one line vast confusion waits
as doth raven sick falln beast
imminent decay wrested pomp
now happy he whose cloak cincture can
hold out this tempest bear away child
follow speed i'll king
heaven itself doth frown upon land exeunt
act v scene 1
england king johns palace
enter king john pandulph attendants
king john thus have yielded up into hand
circle glory
pandulph gives back crown take again
from this hand as holding pope
sovereign greatness authority
from his holiness use all power
stop their marches fore are inflam'd
our discontented counties do revolt
our people quarrel obedience
swearing allegiance love soul
stranger blood foreign royalty
this inundation mistemp'red humour
rests by only qualified
then pause not present time's so sick
or overthrow incurable ensues
pandulph was breath blew this tempest up
upon stubborn usage pope
but since are gentle convertite
tongue shall hush again this storm war
make fair weather blust'ring land
this ascension day remember well
upon oath service pope
go make french lay down their arms exit
say before ascension day at noon
crown should give off even so have
did suppose should constraint
but heaven thank'd but voluntary

bastard all kent hath yielded nothing there holds out
but dover castle london hath receiv'd
kind host dauphin his powers
nobles will not hear but are gone
wild amazement hurries up down
little number doubtful friends

after they heard young arthur was alive
bastard they found him dead cast into streets
an empty casket where jewel life
by some damnd hand was robbed ta'en away

bastard so soul he did aught he knew
great act as have been thought
let not world see fear sad distrust

bragging horror so shall inferior eyes
borrow their behaviours from great
grow great by example put

scene 7
orchard at swinstead abbey
enter prince henry salisbury bigot
prince henry too late life all his blood
touch'd corruptibly his pure brain
which some suppose souls frail dwelling house
foretell ending mortality
enter pembroke
pembroke his highness yet doth speak holds belief
being brought into open air
would allay burning quality
fell poison which assaileth him
prince henry let him brought into orchard here
doth he still rage exit bigot
pembroke he more patient
prince henry o vanity sickness fierce extremes
their continuance will not feel themselves
death having prey'd upon outward parts
leaves them invisible his siege now
against mind which he pricks wounds
many legions strange fantasies
which their throng press last hold
confound themselves 'tis strange death should sing
am cygnet this pale faint swan
from organ pipe frailty sings
his soul body their lasting rest
salisbury good comfort prince are born
set form upon indigest
which he hath left so shapeless so rude
re enter bigot attendants who bring
king john chair
king john ay marry now soul hath elbow room
would not out at windows nor at doors
all bowels crumble up dust
am scribbled form drawn pen
upon parchment against this fire
do shrink up
prince henry how fares majesty
king john poisond ill fare dead forsook cast off
none will bid winter come
thrust his icy fingers maw
nor let kingdom's rivers take their course
make his bleak winds kiss parched lips
comfort cold do not ask much
beg cold comfort are so strait
so ingrateful deny
prince henry o there were some virtue tears
might relieve
king john salt them hot
within hell there poison
as fiend confind tyrannize
enter bastard
bastard o am scalded violent motion
spleen speed see majesty
king john o cousin thou art come set mine eye
tackle heart crack'd burnt
all shrouds wherewith life should sail
are turned one thread one little hair
heart hath one poor string stay by
which holds but till thy news uttered
module confounded royalty
bastard dauphin preparing hitherward
where god he knows how shall answer him
night best part pow'r
as upon advantage did remove
were washes all unwarily
devoured by unexpected flood king dies
salisbury breathe these dead news as dead an ear
liege lord but now king now thus
what surety world what hope what stay
when this was now king now clay
bastard art thou gone so do but stay behind
do office thee revenge
then soul shall wait thee heaven
as earth hath been thy servant still
now now stars move right spheres
where pow'rs show now mended faiths
instantly return again
out weak door our fainting land
straight let us seek or straight shall sought
dauphin rages at our very heels
salisbury seems know not then so much as
cardinal pandulph within at rest
who half an hour since came from dauphin
brings from him such offers our peace
as honour respect may take
purpose presently leave this war
ourselves well sinewed our defence
salisbury nay 'tis manner done already
many carriages he hath dispatch'd
sea side put his cause quarrel
disposing cardinal
whom yourself myself other lords
if think meet this afternoon will post
consummate this business happily
bastard let so noble prince
shall wait upon father's funeral
prince henry at worcester must his body interr'd
so he willd
bastard thither shall then
happily may sweet self put
lineal state glory land
whom all submission knee
do bequeath faithful services
true subjection everlastingly
rest without spot evermore
prince henry have kind soul would give thanks
knows not how do but tears
bastard o let us pay time but needful woe
since hath been beforehand our griefs
this england never did nor never shall
lie at proud foot conqueror
but when first did help wound itself
now these her princes are come home again
shall shock them nought shall make us rue
if england itself do rest but true exeunt
end

tragedy julius caesar
by william shakespeare

act scene
rome street
enter flavius marullus certain commoners
this holiday what know not
being mechanical ought not walk
upon laboring day without sign
profession speak what trade art thou
first commoner why sir carpenter
marullus where thy leather apron thy rule
what dost thou thy best apparel
sir what trade are
second commoner truly sir respect fine workman am
marullus but what trade art thou answer directly
second commoner trade sir hope may use safe
conscience which indeed sir mender bad soles
marullus what trade thou knave thou naughty knave what trade
second commoner nay beseech sir not out yet
if out sir can mend
marullus what meanst thou by mend thou saucy fellow
second commoner why sir cobble
flavius thou art cobbler art thou
meddle no tradesmans matters nor womens matters but
awl am indeed sir surgeon old shoes when they are
great danger recover them as proper men as ever trod upon
neat's leather have gone upon handiwork
flavius but wherefore art not thy shop today
why dost thou lead these men about streets
second commoner truly sir wear out their shoes get myself
into more work but indeed sir make holiday see caesar
rejoice his triumph
what tributaries follow him rome
grace captive bonds his chariot wheels
blocks stones worse than senseless things
o hard hearts cruel men rome
knew not pompey many time oft
have climb'd up walls battlements
towers windows yea chimney tops
infants arms there have sat
livelong day patient expectation
when saw his chariot but appear
have not made an universal shout
tiber trembled underneath her banks
hear replication sounds
made her concave shores
do now put best attire
do now cull out holiday
do now strew flowers his way
comes triumph over pompey's blood
run houses fall upon knees
pray gods intermit plague
needs must light this ingratitude
flavius go go good countrymen this fault
assemble all poor men sort
draw them tiber banks weep tears
into channel till lowest stream
do kiss most exalted shores all
exeunt all commoners
they vanish tongue tied their guiltiness
go down way towards capitol
this way will disrobe images
if do find them deck'd ceremonies
marullus may do so
know feast lupercal
flavius no matter let no images
hung caesar's trophies i'll about
drive away vulgar from streets
these growing feathers pluck'd from caesar's wing
will make him fly an ordinary pitch
who else would soar above view men
keep us all servile fearfulness exeunt
scene ii
public place
flourish enter caesar antony course calpurnia portia

music ceases

when he doth run his course antonio

touch calpurnia our elders say
shake off their sterile curse
antony shall remember
when caesar says do this perform'd
caesar set leave no ceremony out flourish

caesar ha who calls

hear tongue shriller than all music

caesar what man

cassius fellow come from throng look upon caesar

soothsayer beware ides march
caesar he dreamer let us leave him pass
sennet exeunt all but brutus cassius
brutus not
cassius pray do
brutus am not gamesome do lack some part
quick spirit antony
let not hinder cassius desires
i'll leave
cassius brutus do observe now late
have not from eyes gentleness
show love as was wont have
over friend loves
brutus cassius
not deceived if have veild look
turn trouble countenance
merely upon myself vexed am
late passions some difference
conceptions only proper myself
which give some soil perhaps behaviors
but let not therefore good friends grieved
nor construe any further neglect
than poor brutus himself at war
forgets shows love other men
cassius then brutus have much mistook passion
by means whereof this breast mine hath buried
thoughts great value worthy cogitations
tell good brutus can see face
brutus no cassius eye sees not itself
but by reflection by some other things
very much lamented brutus
have no such mirrors as will turn
hidden worthiness into eye
might see shadow have heard
where many best respect rome
except immortal caesar speaking brutus
groaning underneath this age's yoke
have wish'd noble brutus had his eyes
brutus into what dangers would lead cassius
which not
cassius therefore good brutus prepared hear
since know cannot see yourself
so well as by reflection glass
will modestly discover yourself
yourself which yet know not
not jealous gentle brutus
were common laugher or did use
stale ordinary oaths love
do fawn men hug them hard
after scandal them or if know
profess myself banqueting
all rout then hold dangerous
flourish shout
brutus what means this shouting do fear people
choose caesar their king
cassius ay do fear
then must think would not have so
but wherefore do hold here so long
what would impart
if aught toward general good
set honor one eye death i' other
will look both indifferently
let gods so speed as love
name honor more than fear death
cassius know virtue brutus
as well as do know outward favor
cannot tell what other men
think this life but single self
had as lief not as live
awe such thing as myself
was born free as caesar so were
both have fed as well can both
endure winter's cold as well as he
once upon raw gusty day
troubled tiber chafing her shores
leap into this angry flood
swim yonder point upon word
accoutred as was plunged
bade him follow so indeed he did
torrent roar'd did buffet
lusty sinews throwing aside
stemming hearts controversy
but ere could arrive point proposed
caesar cried help cassius or sink
did from flames troy upon his shoulder
old anchises bear so from waves tiber
did tired caesar this man
now become god cassius
wretched creature must bend his body
if caesar carelessly but nod him
he had fever when he was spain
when fit was him did mark
how he did shake 'tis true this god did shake
same eye whose bend doth awe world
did lose his luster did hear him groan
ay tongue his bade romans
mark him write his speeches their books
alas cried give some drink titinius
as sick girl ye gods doth amaze
man such feeble temper should
so get start majestic world
bear palm alone shout flourish
do believe these applauses are
some new honors are heap'd caesar
cassius why man he doth bestride narrow world
colossus petty men
walk under his huge legs peep about
find ourselves dishonorable graves
men at some time are masters their fates
fault dear brutus not our stars
but ourselves are underlings
why should name sounded more than yours
write them together yours as fair name
sound them doth become mouth as well
weigh them as heavy conjure 'em
brutus will start spirit as soon as caesar
now names all gods at once
upon what meat doth this our caesar feed
he grown so great age thou art shamed
rome thou hast lost breed noble bloods
but was famed more than one man
when could they say till now talk'd rome
her wide walls encompass'd but one man
now rome indeed room enough
when there but one only man
o have heard our fathers say
there was brutus once would have brook'd
eternal devil keep his state rome
as easily as king
what would work have some aim
how have thought this these times
shall recount hereafter this present
would not so love might entreat
any further moved what have said
will consider what have say
will patience hear find time
both meet hear answer such high things
till then noble friend chew upon this
than repute himself son rome
under these hard conditions as this time
lay upon us
cassius am glad weak words
have struck but thus much show fire from brutus
re enter caesar his train
brutus games are done caesar returning
cassius as they pass by pluck casca by sleeve
he will after his sour fashion tell
brutus will do so but look cassius
angry spot doth glow caesar's brow
all rest look chidden train
calpurnia's cheek pale cicero
looks such ferret such fiery eyes
as have seen him capitol
being cross'd conference by some senators
cassius casca will tell us what matter
caesar antonio
caesar let have men about are fat
sleek headed men such as sleep o' nights
yond cassius has lean hungry look
he thinks too much such men are dangerous
antony fear him not caesar he's not dangerous
he noble roman well given
caesar would he were fatter but fear him not
yet if name were liable fear
do not know man should avoid
he great observer he looks
quite through deeds men he loves no plays
as thou dost antony he hears no music
seldom he smiles smiles such sort
as if he mock'd himself scornd his spirit
could moved smile at anything
such men as he never at heart's ease
whiles they behold greater than themselves
therefore are they very dangerous
than what fear always am caesar
come right hand this ear deaf
tell truly what thou think'st him
sennet exeunt caesar all his train but casca
casca pulld by cloak would speak
brutus ay casca tell us what hath chanced today
caesar looks so sad
casca why were him were not
brutus should not then ask casca what had chanced
he put by back his hand thus then
people fell ashouting
brutus what was second noise
casca why too
cassius they shouted thrice what was last cry
casca why too
brutus was crown offered him thrice
casca ay marry wast he put by thrice every time gentler
than other at every putting by mine honest neighbors
cassius who offered him crown
casca why antony
brutus tell us manner gentle casca
casca can as well hang'd as tell manner was
mere foolery did not mark saw mark antony offer him
crown yet 'twas not crown neither 'twas one these
coronets as told he put by once but all
thinking he would fain have had then he offered
him again then he put by again but thinking he
third time he put third time by still as he
refused rabblement hooted clapped their chopped hands
threw up their sweaty nightcaps uttered such deal
stinking breath because caesar refused crown had
almost choked caesar he swounded fell down at
mine own part durst not laugh fear opening lips
receiving bad air
cassius but soft pray what did caesars wound
casca he fell down marketplace foamed at mouth was
brutus 'tis very he hath falling sickness
cassius no caesar hath not but
honest casca have falling sickness
casca know not what mean by but am sure caesar fell
down if tagrag people did not clap him hiss him
according as he pleased displeased them as they use do
players theatre am no true man
brutus what said he when he came unto himself
casca marry before he fell down when he perceived common
offered them his throat cut an had been man any
occupation if would not have taken him at word would
might go hell among rogues so he fell when he came
himself again he said if he had done or said anything amiss
he desired their worships think was his infirmity three or
four wenches where stood cried alas good soul forgave
him all their hearts but there's no heed taken
them if caesar had stabbed their mothers they would have done
no less

cassius did cicero say anything
casca ay he spoke greek
cassius what effect

could tell more news too marullus flavius pulling

better appetite

from disposed therefore meet

who so firm cannot seduced

scene iii
street thunder lightning
enter from opposite sides casca his sword drawn cicero
why are breathless why stare so
casca are not moved when all sway earth
shakes thing unfirm o cicero
have seen tempests when scolding winds
have rived knotty oaks have seen
ambitious ocean swell rage foam
exalted threatening clouds
but never till tonight never till now
did go through tempest dropping fire
or else world too saucy gods
incenses them send destruction
cicero why saw anything more wonderful
casca common slave know him well by sight
held up his left hand which did flame burn
twenty torches joind yet his hand
not sensible fire remaind unscorch'd
besides ha' not since put up sword
against capitol met lion
without annoying there were drawn
upon heap hundred ghastly women
transformed their fear who swore they saw
men all fire walk up down streets
yesterday bird night did sit
even at noonday upon marketplace
howling shrieking when these prodigies
do so conjointly meet let not men say
these are their reasons they are natural
unto climate they point upon
cicero indeed strange disposed time
but men may construe things after their fashion
clean from purpose things themselves
comes caesar capitol tomorrow
casca he doth he did bid antonio
send word he would there tomorrow
cicero good then casca this disturbed sky
not walk
enter cassius
cassius who's there
casca roman
cassius casca by voice
casca ear good cassius what night this
cassius very pleasing night honest men
casca who ever knew heavens menace so
cassius those have known earth so full faults
part have walk'd about streets
thus unbraced casca as see
have bared bosom thunderstone
when cross blue lightning seem'd open
breast heaven did present myself
even aim very flash
casca but wherefore did so much tempt heavens
part men fear tremble
when most mighty gods by tokens send
such dreadful heralds astonish us
should roman do want
or else use not look pale gaze
put fear cast yourself wonder
see strange impatience heavens
but if would consider true cause
why all these fires why all these gliding ghosts
why birds beasts from quality kind
why old men fools children calculate
why all these things change from their ordinance
monstrous quality why shall find
heaven hath infused them these spirits
make them instruments fear warning
unto some monstrous state
now could casca name thee man
most this dreadful night
thunders lightens opens graves roars
as doth lion capitol
man no mightier than thyself or
fearful as these strange eruptions are
casca 'tis caesar mean not cassius
cassius let who romans now
have thews limbs their ancestors
but woe while our fathers' minds are dead
are governd our mothers' spirits
our yoke sufferance show us womanish
casca indeed they say senators tomorrow
mean establish caesar as king
every place save here italy
cassius know where will wear this dagger then
cassius from bondage will deliver cassius
therein ye gods make weak most strong
therein ye gods tyrants do defeat
nor stony tower nor walls beaten brass
nor airless dungeon nor strong links iron
can retentive strength spirit
but life being weary these worldly bars
if know this know all world besides
part tyranny do bear
can shake off at pleasure thunder still
casca so can
so every bondman his own hand bears
power cancel his captivity
cassius why should caesar tyrant then
poor man know he would not wolf
but he sees romans are but sheep
those haste will make mighty fire
begin weak straws what trash rome
what rubbish what offal when serves
base matter illuminate
so vile thing as caesar but o grief
where hast thou led perhaps speak this
before willing bondman then know
answer must made but am arm'd
dangers are indifferent
no fleering tell tale hold hand
factious redress all these griefs
will set this foot mine as far
as who goes farthest
cassius there's bargain made
now know casca have moved already
some certain noblest minded romans
undergo an enterprise
honorable dangerous consequence
pompey's porch now this fearful night
there no stir or walking streets
complexion element
favor's work have hand
most bloody fiery most terrible

he friend cinna where haste so

our attempts am not stay'd cinna

there's two or three us have seen strange sights

cinna yes are
o cassius if could

decius brutus trebonius there

act ii scene

how might change his nature there's question

then grant put sting him
at his will he may do danger
abuse greatness when disjoins
remorse from power speak truth caesar
have not known when his affections sway'd
more than his reason but 'tis common proof
lowliness young ambitions ladder
whereto climber upward turns his face

by which he did ascend so caesar may

every man hence his idle bed

till each man drop by lottery but if these

melting spirits women then countrymen

will not palter what other oath
than honesty honesty engaged
this shall or will fall

whose true fix'd resting quality
there no fellow firmament
skies are painted unnumber'd sparks
they are all fire every one doth shine
but there's but one all doth hold his place
so world 'tis furnish'd well men

yet number do know but one
unassailable holds his rank
let little show even this
was constant cimber should banish'd

these people at our back

which taken at flood leads fortune

bound shallows miseries

must take current when serves
or lose our ventures

go arm'd

practices ride easy see business

all me's meet can fashion fit

scene iii
duke albany's palace

act scene
navarre king's park
enter king berowne longaville dumain
king let fame all hunt after their lives
live regist'red upon our brazen tombs
then grace us disgrace death
when spite cormorant devouring time
th' endeavour this present breath may buy
make us heirs all eternity
therefore brave conquerors so are
war against own affections
huge army world's desires
our late edict shall strongly stand force
navarre shall wonder world
our court shall little academe
still contemplative living art
three berowne dumain longaville
fellow scholars keep those statutes
are recorded this schedule here
oaths are pass'd now subscribe names
his own hand may strike his honour down
violates smallest branch herein
if are arm'd do as sworn do
subscribe deep oaths keep too

mind shall banquet though body pine
make rich ribs but bankrupt quite wits

love wealth pomp pine die
all these living philosophy

so much dear liege have already sworn

know thing am forbid know

or having sworn too hard keeping oath

study knows which yet doth not know
swear this will ne'er say no

train our intellects vain delight

which pain purchas'd doth inherit pain
as painfully pore upon book

light seeking light doth light light beguile
so ere find where light darkness lies
light grows dark by losing eyes

by fixing upon fairer eye
who dazzling so eye shall his heed
give him light was blinded by
study heavens glorious sun
will not deep search'd saucy looks
save base authority from others' books
these earthly godfathers heavens lights

than those walk wot not what they are
too much know know nought but fame
every godfather can give name

dumain some salve perjury
have at then affections men at arms
consider what first did swear unto
fast study see no woman
flat treason 'gainst kingly state youth
say can fast stomachs are too young
abstinence engenders maladies
where have vow'd study lords
each have forsworn his book
can still dream pore thereon look
have found ground study's excellence
without beauty womans face
from womens eyes this doctrine derive
they are ground books academes
from whence doth spring true promethean fire
why universal plodding poisons up
nimble spirits arteries
as motion long during action tires
sinewy vigour traveller
have forsworn use eyes
study too causer vow
where author world
teaches such beauty as womans eye
learning but an adjunct ourself
where are our learning likewise
then when ourselves see ladies' eyes
ourselves
do not likewise see our learning there
vow have forsworn our books
when would liege or or
leaden contemplation have found out
such fiery numbers as prompting eyes
beauty's tutors have enrich'd
other slow arts entirely keep brain
therefore finding barren practisers
scarce show harvest their heavy toil
but love first learned lady's eyes
but motion all elements
courses as swift as thought every power
gives every power double power
above their functions their offices
adds precious seeing eye
lover's eyes will gaze an eagle blind
lover's ear will hear lowest sound
when suspicious head theft stopp'd
love's feeling more soft sensible
love's tongue proves dainty bacchus gross taste
valour not love hercules
still climbing trees hesperides
subtle as sphinx as sweet musical
as bright apollo's lute strung his hair
when love speaks voice all gods
make heaven drowsy harmony
never durst poet touch pen write
until his ink were temp'red love's sighs
plant tyrants mild humility
from womens eyes this doctrine derive
they sparkle still right promethean fire
they are books arts academes
show contain nourish all world
else none at all aught proves excellent
then fools were these women forswear
or keeping what sworn will prove fools
wisdom's sake word all men love
or mens sake authors these women
or womens sake by whom men are men

religion thus forsworn
charity itself fulfils law
who can sever love from charity

scene ii
camp near forres alarum within
enter duncan malcolm donalbain lennox attendants
meeting bleeding sergeant
duncan what bloody man he can report
newest state
malcolm this sergeant
who good hardy soldier fought
'gainst captivity hail brave friend
say king knowledge broil
as thou didst leave
sergeant doubtful stood
as two spent swimmers do cling together
choke their art merciless macdonwald
multiplying villainies nature
do swarm upon him from western isles
kerns gallowglasses supplied
fortune his damned quarrel smiling
show'd rebels whore but alls too weak
brave macbeth well he deserves name
disdaining fortune his brandish'd steel
which smoked bloody execution
valor's minion carved out his passage
which ne'er shook hands nor bade farewell him
till he unseam'd him from nave chaps
fix'd his head upon our battlements
duncan o valiant cousin worthy gentleman
sergeant as whence sun 'gins his reflection
shipwrecking storms direful thunders break
so from spring whence comfort seem'd come
discomfort swells mark king scotland mark
no sooner justice had valor arm'd
but norweyan lord surveying vantage
furbish'd arms new supplies men
began fresh assault
duncan dismay'd not this
our captains macbeth banquo
sergeant yes
as sparrows eagles or hare lion
if say sooth must report they were
as cannons overcharged double cracks
doubly redoubled strokes upon foe
except they meant bathe reeking wounds
or memorize another golgotha
cannot tell
but am faint gashes cry help
duncan so well thy words become thee as thy wounds
they smack honor both go get him surgeons
exit sergeant attended
who comes here

point against point rebellious arm 'gainst arm

victory fell us

ross now

till he disbursed at saint colme's inch

as this which now draw

which was not so before there's no such thing
bloody business which informs
nature seems dead wicked dreams abuse
curtaind sleep witchcraft celebrates

same

act scene
duke's palace

exceeds lists all advice

our city's institutions terms
common justice y'are as pregnant
as art practice hath enriched any
remember there our commission
from which would not have warp call hither
what figure us think he will bear

undergo such ample grace honour
lord angelo

come know pleasure
duke angelo
there kind character thy life
th' observer doth thy history
fully unfold thyself thy belongings
are not thine own so proper as waste
thyself upon thy virtues they thee
not light them themselves if our virtues
did not go forth us 'twere all alike
as if had them not spirits are not finely touch'd
but fine issues nor nature never lends
smallest scruple her excellence
but thrifty goddess she determines
herself glory creditor
both thanks use but do bend speech
one can part him advertise
our remove thou at full ourself
mortality mercy vienna
live thy tongue heart old escalus
though first question thy secondary
take thy commission

before so noble so great figure
stamp'd upon
have leavend prepared choice
proceeded therefore take honours
our haste from hence so quick condition
prefers itself leaves unquestiond
matters needful value shall write
as time our concernings shall importune
how goes us do look know
what doth befall here so fare well
th' hopeful execution do leave

may bring something way
duke haste may not admit
nor need mine honour have do
any scruple scope as mine own
so enforce or qualify laws
as soul seems good give hand
i'll privily away love people
but do not stage their eyes
their loud applause aves vehement
nor do think man safe discretion
does affect once more fare well

brother die

accountant law upon pain

owe succeed thy weakness

which are as easy broke as they make forms

are soft as our complexions are
credulous false prints
angelo think well
since suppose are made no stronger
than faults may shake our frames let bold
do arrest words are
woman if more you're none
if one as are well express'd
by all external warrants show now

unsoild name th' austereness life
vouch against place i' th' state
will so accusation overweigh
shall stifle own report
now give sensual race rein
fit thy consent sharp appetite
lay by all nicety prolixious blushes
banish what they sue redeem thy brother
by yielding up thy body will
or else he must not only die death
but thy unkindness shall his death draw out
ling'ring sufferance answer morrow
or by affection now guides most
say what can false o'erweighs true exit
isabella whom should complain did tell this
who would believe o perilous mouths
bear them one self same tongue
either condemnation or approof
bidding law make curtsy their will
hooking both right wrong th' appetite
follow as draws i'll brother
though he hath falln by prompture blood
had he twenty heads tender down
twenty bloody blocks he'd yield them up
before his sister should her body stoop
such abhorr'd pollution
then isabel live chaste brother die
more than our brother our chastity
i'll tell him yet angelo's request
fit his mind death his souls rest exit
act iii scene
enter duke disguised as before claudio provost
duke so then hope pardon from lord angelo
claudio miserable have no other medicine
but only hope
have hope eve am prepar'd die
duke absolute death either death or life
shall thereby sweeter reason thus life
if do lose thee do lose thing
none but fools would keep breath thou art
dost this habitation where thou keep'st
hourly afflict merely thou art death's fool
him thou labour'st by thy flight shun
yet runst toward him still thou art not noble
all th' accommodations thou bear'st
are nurs'd by baseness thou 'rt by no means valiant
thou dost fear soft tender fork
poor worm thy best rest sleep
thou oft provok'st yet grossly fear'st
thou exists many thousand grains
issue out dust happy thou art not
what thou hast not still thou striv'st get
what thou hast forget'st thou art not certain
thy complexion shifts strange effects
after moon if thou art rich thou'rt poor
an ass whose back ingots bows
thou bear'st thy heavy riches but journey
death unloads thee friend hast thou none
mere effusion thy proper loins
do curse gout serpigo rheum
ending thee no sooner thou hast nor youth nor age
but as were an after dinner's sleep
dreaming both all thy blessed youth
becomes as aged doth beg alms
palsied eld when thou art old rich
thou hast neither heat affection limb nor beauty
make thy riches pleasant what's yet this
lie hid moe thousand deaths yet death fear
makes these odds all even
claudio humbly thank
sue live find seek die
seeking death find life let come

scene iii
prison
enter pompey

old women were all dead then there here one master

merchant venice
by william shakespeare
dramatis personae

venice portia's house at belmont
act scene
venice street
antonio sooth know not why am so sad
wearies say wearies
but how caught found or came by
what stuff 'tis made whereof born
am learn
such want wit sadness makes
have much ado know myself
salerio mind tossing ocean
there where argosies portly sail
or as were pageants sea
do overpeer petty traffickers
curtsy them do them reverence
as they fly by them their woven wings
solanio believe sir had such venture forth
better part affections would
hopes abroad should still
plucking grass know where sits wind
peering maps ports piers roads
misfortune ventures out doubt
would make sad
salerio wind cooling broth
would blow an ague when thought
what harm wind too great might do at sea
should not see sandy hour glass run
but should think shallows flats
see wealthy andrew dock'd sand
vailing her high top lower than her ribs
see holy edifice stone
not bethink straight dangerous rocks
which touching but gentle vessels side
would scatter all her spices stream
enrobe roaring waters silks
word but even now worth this
now worth nothing shall have thought
think this shall lack thought
such thing bechanc'd would make sad
sad think upon his merchandise
antonio believe no thank fortune
ventures are not one bottom trusted
nor one place nor whole estate
upon fortune this present year
therefore merchandise makes not sad
solanio why then are love
antonio fie fie
solanio not love neither then let us say are sad
laugh leap say are merry
because are not sad now by two headed janus
nature hath fram'd strange fellows her time
some will evermore peep through their eyes
laugh parrots at bag piper
other such vinegar aspect
they'll not show their teeth way smile
though nestor swear jest laughable
enter bassanio lorenzo gratiano
gratiano lorenzo fare ye well
leave now better company
salerio would have stay'd till had made merry
if worthier friends had not prevented
antonio worth very dear regard
take own business calls
embrace th' occasion depart
salerio good morrow good lords
bassanio good signiors both when shall laugh say when
salerio we'll make our leisures attend yours
exeunt salerio solanio
lorenzo lord bassanio since have found antonio
two will leave but at dinner time
pray have mind where must meet
bassanio will not fail
gratiano look not well signior antonio
have too much respect upon world
they lose do buy much care
antonio hold world but as world gratiano
stage where every man must play part
mine sad one
gratiano let play fool
mirth laughter let old wrinkles come
let liver rather heat wine
than heart cool mortifying groans
why should man whose blood warm within
sit his grandsire cut alabaster
by being peevish tell thee what antonio
love thee 'tis love speaks
there are sort men whose visages
do cream mantle standing pond
do wilful stillness entertain
purpose dress'd an opinion
wisdom gravity profound conceit
as who should say 'i am sir oracle
when ope lips let no dog bark'
therefore only are reputed wise
saying nothing when am very sure
if they should speak would almost damn those ears
which hearing them would call their brothers fools
i'll tell thee more this another time
but fish not this melancholy bait
this fool gudgeon this opinion
come good lorenzo fare ye well awhile
i'll end exhortation after dinner
must one these same dumb wise men
gratiano never lets speak
gratiano well keep company but two years moe
thou shalt not know sound thine own tongue
antonio fare well i'll grow talker this gear
gratiano thanks i' faith silence only commendable
neat's tongue dried maid not vendible
exeunt gratiano lorenzo
antonio anything now
any man all venice his reasons are as two grains wheat hid
two bushels chaff shall seek all day ere find
them when have them they are not worth search
antonio well tell now what lady same
whom swore secret pilgrimage
day promis'd tell
bassanio 'tis not unknown antonio
how much have disabled mine estate
by something showing more swelling port
nor do now make moan abridg'd
from such noble rate but chief care
come fairly off from great debts
wherein time something too prodigal
hath left gag'd antonio
owe most money love
from love have warranty
unburden all plots purposes
how get clear all debts owe
if stand as yourself still do
within eye honour assur'd
purse person extremest means
lie all unlock'd occasions
bassanio school days when had lost one shaft
shot his fellow self same flight
self same way more advised watch
find other forth by adventuring both
oft found both urge this childhood proof
owe much wilful youth
which owe lost but if please
shoot another arrow self way
which did shoot first do not doubt
as will watch aim or find both
or bring latter hazard back again
thankfully rest debtor first
antonio know well herein spend but time
wind about love circumstance
making question uttermost
than if had made waste all have
then do but say what should do
knowledge may by done
am prest unto therefore speak
bassanio belmont lady richly left
she fair fairer than word
wondrous virtues sometimes from her eyes
did receive fair speechless messages
cato's daughter brutus' portia
nor wide world ignorant her worth
four winds blow from every coast
renowned suitors her sunny locks
hang her temples golden fleece
which makes her seat belmont colchos' strond
many jasons come quest her
o antonio had but means
hold rival place one them
should questionless fortunate
antonio thou know'st all fortunes are at sea
neither have money nor commodity
raise present sum therefore go forth
try what credit can venice do
shall rack'd even uttermost
furnish thee belmont fair portia
go presently inquire so will
where money no question make
scene ii
belmont portia's house
enter portia her waiting woman nerissa
portia by troth nerissa little body aweary this
great world
nerissa would sweet madam if miseries were
same abundance as good fortunes are yet aught
see they are as sick surfeit too much as they
starve nothing no mean happiness therefore
competency lives longer
portia good sentences well pronounc'd
nerissa they would better if well followed
portia if do were as easy as know what were good do
chapels had been churches poor mens cottages princes'
palaces good divine follows his own instructions
can easier teach twenty what were good done than one
twenty follow mine own teaching brain may devise
laws blood but hot temper leaps o'er cold decree
counsel cripple but this reasoning not fashion
choose husband o word 'choose' may neither
choose who would nor refuse who dislike so will
living daughter curb'd by will dead father not
hard nerissa cannot choose one nor refuse none
nerissa father was ever virtuous holy men at their death
have good inspirations therefore lott'ry he hath

who chooses his meaning chooses will no doubt never
what warmth there affection towards any these
princely suitors are already come

empty

nerissa then there county palatine

these god defend from these two

act ii scene
flourish cornets enter prince morocco tawny moor all white
three or four followers accordingly portia nerissa train
prince morocco mislike not complexion
shadowed livery burnish'd sun
whom am neighbour near bred
bring fairest creature northward born
where phoebus' fire scarce thaws icicles
let us make incision love
prove whose blood reddest his or mine
hath fear'd valiant by love swear
best regarded virgins our clime
have lov'd too would not change this hue
except steal thoughts gentle queen
portia terms choice am not solely led
by nice direction maidens eyes
besides lott'ry destiny
bars right voluntary choosing
but if father had not scanted
his wife who wins by means told
yourself renowned prince then stood as fair
as any comer have look'd yet
affection
prince morocco even thank
therefore pray lead caskets
try fortune by this scimitar
slew sophy persian prince
won three fields sultan solyman
outbrave heart most daring earth
pluck young sucking cubs from she bear
yea mock lion when 'a roars prey
win thee lady but alas while
if hercules lichas play at dice
which better man greater throw
may turn by fortune from weaker band
so alcides beaten by his page
so may blind fortune leading
die grieving
portia must take chance
either not attempt choose at all
or swear before choose if choose wrong
never speak lady afterward
way marriage therefore advis'd
prince morocco nor will not come bring unto chance
portia first forward temple after dinner
hazard shall made
make blest or cursed'st among men
cornets exeunt

scene vii
belmont portia's house
flourish cornets enter portia prince morocco
their trains
portia go draw aside curtains discover
several caskets this noble prince
prince morocco first gold who this inscription bears
'who chooseth shall gain what many men desire'
second silver which this promise carries
'who chooseth shall get as much as he deserves'
this third dull lead warning all as blunt
'who chooseth must give hazard all he hath'
how shall know if do choose right
portia one them contains picture prince
if choose then am yours withal
will survey th' inscriptions back again
what says this leaden casket
'who chooseth must give hazard all he hath'
must give what lead hazard lead
this casket threatens men hazard all
do hope fair advantages
golden mind stoops not shows dross
i'll then nor give nor hazard aught lead
what says silver her virgin hue
as much as he deserves pause there morocco
weigh thy value an even hand
if thou beest rated by thy estimation
thou dost deserve enough yet enough
may not extend so far as lady
yet afeard deserving
were but weak disabling myself
as much as deserve why that's lady
do birth deserve her fortunes
but more than these love do deserve
what if stray'd no farther but chose here
let's see once more this saying grav'd gold
'who chooseth shall gain what many men desire'
why that's lady all world desires her
from four corners earth they come
kiss this shrine this mortal breathing saint
hyrcanian deserts vasty wilds
wide arabia are as throughfares now
watery kingdom whose ambitious head
spits face heaven no bar
stop foreign spirits but they come
as o'er brook see fair portia
one these three contains her heavenly picture
is't lead contains her 'twere damnation
think so base thought were too gross
rib her cerecloth obscure grave
or shall think silver she's immur'd
o sinful thought never so rich gem
was set worse than gold they have england
coin bears figure an angel
stamp'd gold but that's insculp'd upon
but here an angel golden bed
lies all within deliver key
here do choose thrive as may
portia there take prince if form lie there
then am yours he opens golden casket
carrion death within whose empty eye
there written scroll i'll read writing
'all glisters not gold
often have heard told
many man his life hath sold
but outside behold
gilded tombs do worms infold
had been as wise as bold
young limbs judgment old
fare well suit cold'
cold indeed labour lost
then farewell heat welcome frost
portia adieu have too griev'd heart
take tedious leave thus losers part
exit his train flourish cornets
portia gentle riddance draw curtains go
let all his complexion choose so exeunt

wish'd silence were not his

yet do not suddenly may grieve him
salerio kinder gentleman treads not earth
saw bassanio antonio part

slubber not business sake bassanio
but stay very riping time
jew's bond which he hath
let not enter mind love
merry employ chiefest thoughts
courtship such fair ostents love
as shall conveniently become there'
even there his eye being big tears
turning his face he put his hand behind him
he wrung bassanio's hand so they parted

some delight or other

scene ix
belmont portia's house
enter nerissa servitor
prince arragon hath ta'en his oath
comes his election presently
flourish cornets enter prince arragon
portia their trains
portia behold there stand caskets noble prince
if choose wherein am containd
straight shall our nuptial rites solemniz'd
but if fail without more speech lord
must gone from hence immediately
first never unfold any one
which casket 'twas chose next if fail
right casket never life
woo maid way marriage
empty
if do fail fortune choice
immediately leave gone
portia these injunctions every one doth swear
comes hazard worthless self
heart's hope gold silver base lead
'who chooseth must give hazard all he hath'
shall look fairer ere give or hazard
what says golden chest ha let see
'who chooseth shall gain what many men desire'
what many men desire 'many' may meant
by fool multitude choose by show
not learning more than fond eye doth teach
which pries not th' interior but martlet
even force road casualty
will not choose what many men desire
because will not jump common spirits
rank barbarous multitudes
why then thee thou silver treasure house
tell once more what title thou dost bear

thou but leadest this fashion thy malice
last hour act then 'tis thought
thou'lt show thy mercy remorse more strange
than thy strange apparent cruelty
where thou now exacts penalty
which pound this poor merchant's flesh
thou wilt not only loose forfeiture
but touch'd human gentleness love
forgive moiety principal
have late so huddled his back
enow press royal merchant down
pluck commiseration his state
from brassy bosoms rough hearts flint
from stubborn turks tartars never traind
offices tender courtesy
all expect gentle answer jew

by our holy sabbath have sworn
if deny let danger light
upon charter city's freedom
you'll ask why rather choose have
weight carrion flesh than receive
three thousand ducats i'll not answer
but say humour answer'd
what if house troubled rat
pleas'd give ten thousand ducats
have band what are answer'd yet
some are mad if they behold cat
others when bagpipe sings i' th' nose
cannot contain their urine affection
mistress passion sways mood
what likes or loathes now answer
as there no firm reason rend'red
why he cannot abide gaping pig
why he harmless necessary cat
why he woollen bagpipe but force
as offend himself being offended
so can give no reason nor will not
more than lodg'd hate certain loathing

bid main flood bate his usual height
may as well use question wolf
why he hath made ewe bleat lamb
may as well forbid mountain pines
wag their high tops make no noise
may as well do anything most hard
as seek soften than which what's harder
his jewish heart therefore do beseech
make no moe offers use no farther means
but all brief plain conveniency
let have judgment jew his will

which fike asses dogs mules
use abject slavish parts
because bought them shall say

why sweat they under burdens let their beds
made as soft as yours let their palates

pound flesh which demand him
dearly bought 'tis mine will have
if deny fie upon law
there no force decrees venice

cannot impugn as do proceed
stand within his danger do not

portia do confess bond
antonio do
shylock what compulsion must tell
portia quality mercy not straind
droppeth as gentle rain from heaven
upon place beneath twice blest
blesseth him gives him takes
'tis mightiest mightiest becomes
throned monarch better than his crown
his sceptre shows force temporal power
attribute awe majesty
but mercy above this sceptred sway
enthroned hearts kings
an attribute god himself
earthly power doth then show likest god's
when mercy seasons justice therefore jew
though justice thy plea consider this
course justice none us
should see salvation do pray mercy
same prayer doth teach us all render
mitigate justice thy plea
which if thou follow this strict court venice
must needs give sentence 'gainst merchant there
shylock deeds upon head crave law
penalty forfeit bond

flesh

do but note wild wanton herd

which hot condition their blood
if they but hear perchance trumpet sound
or any air music touch their ears
shall perceive them make mutual stand
their savage eyes turnd modest gaze
by sweet power music therefore poet
did feign orpheus drew trees stones floods
since nought so stockish hard full rage
but music time doth change his nature
nor not mov'd concord sweet sounds
fit treasons stratagems spoils
motions his spirit are dullas night
his affections dark as erebus
let no such man trusted mark music

athens palace theseus
enter theseus hippolyta philostrate attendants
draws apace four happy days bring

step dame or dowager

demetrius
egeus happy theseus our renowned duke

against child daughter hermia

this man hath consent marry her
stand forth lysander gracious duke
this man hath bewitch'd bosom child
interchang'd love tokens child
thou hast by moonlight at her window sung
feigning voice verses feigning love
stoln impression her fantasy
bracelets thy hair rings gawds conceits
knacks trifles nosegays sweetmeats messengers
strong prevailment unhardened youth
cunning hast thou filch'd daughter's heart
turnd her obedience which due
so she will not here before grace
consent marry demetrius
beg ancient privilege athens
as she mine may dispose her
which shall either this gentleman
or her death according our law
immediately provided case
theseus what say hermia advis'd fair maid
father should as god
whom are but as form wax
by him imprinted within his power
leave figure or disfigure
demetrius worthy gentleman
hermia so lysander
theseus himself he
but this kind wanting father's voice
other must held worthier
hermia would father look'd but eyes
hermia do entreat grace pardon
know not by what power am made bold
nor how may concern modesty
such presence here plead thoughts
but beseech grace may know
worst may befall this case
if refuse wed demetrius
theseus either die death or abjure
ever society men
know youth examine well blood
whether if yield not father's choice
can endure livery nun
aye shady cloister mew'd
live barren sister all life
chanting faint hymns cold fruitless moon
thrice blessed they master so their blood
undergo such maiden pilgrimage
but earthlier happy rose distilld
grows lives dies single blessedness
hermia so will grow so live so die lord
ere will yield virgin patent up
unto his lordship whose unwished yoke
soul consents not give sovereignty
theseus take time pause by next new moon
sealing day betwixt love
everlasting bond fellowship
upon day either prepare die
or else wed demetrius as he would
or diana's altar protest
aye austerity single life
demetrius relent sweet hermia lysander yield
thy crazed title certain right
lysander have her father's love demetrius
let have hermia's do marry him
egeus scornful lysander true he hath love
what mine love shall render him
do estate unto demetrius
lysander am lord as well deriv'd as he
as well possess'd love more than his
fortunes every way as fairly rank'd
if not vantage as demetrius'
which more than all these boasts can
am belov'd beauteous hermia
why should not then prosecute right
demetrius i'll avouch his head
won her soul she sweet lady dotes
devoutly dotes dotes idolatry
upon this spotted inconstant man
theseus must confess have heard so much
demetrius thought have spoke thereof
but being over full self affairs
mind did lose but demetrius come
come egeus shall go
have some private schooling both
fit fancies father's will
or else law athens yields up
which by no means may extenuate
death or vow single life
come hippolyta what cheer love
demetrius egeus go along
must employ some business
against our nuptial confer
something nearly concerns yourselves
exeunt all but lysander hermia
lysander how now love why cheek so pale
how chance roses there do fade so fast
hermia belike want rain which could well
beteem them from tempest eyes
lysander ay aught could ever read
could ever hear by tale or history
course true love never did run smooth
but either was different blood
lysander or else misgraffed respect years
hermia o spite too old engag'd young
lysander or else stood upon choice friends
hermia o hell choose love by another's eyes
lysander or if there were sympathy choice
war death or sickness did lay siege
making momentary as sound
swift as shadow short as any dream
brief as lightning collied night
ere man hath power say 'behold'
jaws darkness do devour up
so quick bright things come confusion
hermia if then true lovers have ever cross'd
stands as an edict destiny
then let us teach our trial patience
because customary cross
as due love as thoughts dreams sighs
wishes tears poor fancy's followers
have widow aunt dowager
great revenue she hath no child
from athens her house remote seven leagues
she respects as her only son
there gentle hermia may marry thee
place sharp athenian law
cannot pursue us if thou lovest then
steal forth thy father's house morrow night
wood league without town
do observance morn may
there will stay thee
hermia good lysander
swear thee by cupid's strongest bow
by his best arrow golden head
by simplicity venus' doves
by which knitteth souls prospers loves
by fire which burnd carthage queen
when false troyan under sail was seen
number more than ever women spoke
same place thou hast appointed
morrow truly will meet thee
lysander keep promise love look here comes helena
enter helena
hermia god speed fair helena whither away
helena call fair fair again unsay
demetrius loves fair o happy fair
eyes are lode stars tongue's sweet air
when wheat green when hawthorn buds appear
sickness catching o were favour so
yours would catch fair hermia ere go
ear should catch voice eye eye
tongue should catch tongue's sweet melody
were world mine demetrius being bated
rest i'd give translated
o teach how look what art
sway motion demetrius' heart
helena o frowns would teach smiles such skill
hermia give him curses yet he gives love
helena o prayers could such affection move
hermia more hate more he follows
helena more love more he hateth
hermia his folly helena no fault mine
helena none but beauty would fault were mine
hermia take comfort he no more shall see face
lysander myself will fly this place
seem'd athens as paradise
o then what graces love do dwell
he hath turnd heaven unto hell
lysander helen our minds will unfold
morrow night when phoebe doth behold
her silver visage wat'ry glass
decking liquid pearl bladed grass
time lovers' flights doth still conceal
through athens' gates have devis'd steal
upon faint primrose beds were wont lie
emptying our bosoms their counsel sweet
there lysander myself shall meet
thence from athens turn away our eyes
seek new friends stranger companies
farewell sweet playfellow pray thou us
good luck grant thee thy demetrius
keep word lysander must starve our sight
from lovers' food till morrow deep midnight
as him demetrius dote exit
helena how happy some o'er other some can
through athens am thought as fair as she
but what demetrius thinks not so
he will not know what all but he do know
as he errs doting hermia's eyes
so admiring his qualities
things base vile holding no quantity
love can transpose form dignity
therefore wing'd cupid painted blind
nor hath love's mind any judgment taste
wings no eyes figure unheedy haste
therefore love said child
because choice he so oft beguild
as waggish boys game themselves forswear
so boy love perjur'd everywhere
ere demetrius look'd hermia's eyne
he haild down oaths he was only mine
so he dissolv'd show'rs oaths did melt
will go tell him fair hermia's flight
then wood will he morrow night
pursue her this intelligence
if have thanks dear expense
but herein mean enrich pain
have his sight thither back again exit

hath rotted ere his youth attaind beard

now perceive they have conjoind all three
fashion this false sport spite
injurious hermia most ungrateful maid
have conspir'd have these contriv'd
bait this foul derision

sisters' vows hours have spent
when have chid hasty footed time
parting us o all forgot
hermia two artificial gods
have our needles created both one flower
both one sampler sitting one cushion
both warbling one song both one key
as if our hands our sides voices minds
had been incorporate so grew together
double cherry seeming parted
but yet an union partition
two lovely berries moulded one stern
two first coats heraldry
due but one crowned one crest
will rent our ancient love asunder
join men scorning poor friend
not friendly 'tis not maidenly
our sex as well as may chide
though alone do feel injury
hermia am amazed at passionate words
scorn not seems scorn
follow praise eyes face
made other love demetrius
who even but now did spurn his foot
call goddess nymph divine rare
precious celestial wherefore speaks he this
her he hates wherefore doth lysander
deny love so rich within his soul
tender forsooth affection
but by setting by consent
so hung upon love so fortunate
but miserable most love unlov'd
this should pity rather than despise
hermia understand not what mean by this
helena ay do persever counterfeit sad looks
make mouths upon when turn back
wink each at other hold sweet jest up
this sport well carried shall chronicled
if have any pity grace or manners
but fare ye well 'tis partly own fault
which death or absence soon shall remedy
lysander stay gentle helena hear excuse
love life soul fair helena
helena o excellent
hermia sweet do not scorn her so
demetrius if she cannot entreat can compel

think but this all mended

this weak idle theme

leon o she tore letter into thousand halfpence raild at
herself she should so immodest write one she
knew would flout her 'i measure him' says she 'by own
spirit should flout him if he writ yea though
claud then down upon her knees she falls weeps sobs beats her
heart tears her hair prays curses 'o sweet benedick god give
patience'
leon she doth indeed daughter says so ecstasy hath so
much overborne her daughter sometime afeard she will
do desperate outrage herself very true
pedro were good benedick knew by some other if she
will not discover
claud what end he would make but sport torment
pedro an he should were an alms hang him she's an
excellent sweet lady out all suspicion she virtuous
claud she exceeding wise
pedro everything but loving benedick
leon o lord wisdom blood combating so tender body
have ten proofs one blood hath victory am sorry
her as have just cause being her uncle her guardian
pedro would she had bestowed this dotage would have
daff'd all other respects made her half myself pray
leon were good think
claud hero thinks surely she will die she says she will die
if he love her not she will die ere she make her love known
she will die if he woo her rather than she will bate one
breath her accustomed crossness
pedro she doth well if she should make tender her love 'tis
very possible he'll scorn man as know all hath
contemptible spirit
claud he very proper man
claud before god mind very wise
pedro he doth indeed show some sparks are wit
claud take him valiant
pedro as hector assure managing quarrels
may say he wise either he avoids them great
discretion or undertakes them most christianlike fear
leon if he do fear god 'a must necessarily keep peace if he
break peace he ought enter into quarrel fear
empty
seems not him by some large jests he will make well am

her love
claud never tell him lord let her wear out good
empty
leon nay that's impossible she may wear her heart out first

cool while love benedick well could wish he would
modestly examine himself see how much he unworthy so good
leon lord will walk dinner ready
they walk away

empty
pedro let there same net spread her must
daughter her gentlewomen carry sport will when they
hold one an opinion another's dotage no such matter
that's scene would see which will merely dumb
show let us send her call him dinner
benedick advances from arbour
bene this can no trick conference was sadly borne they
have truth this from hero they seem pity lady
seems her affections have their full bent love why
must requited hear how am censur'd they say will bear
myself proudly if perceive love come from her they say too
she will rather die than give any sign affection did
never think marry must not seem proud happy are they
hear their detractions can put them mending they say
'tis so cannot reprove wise but loving by
troth no addition her wit nor no great argument
her folly will horribly love her may chance
have some odd quirks remnants wit broken because
have railed so long against marriage but doth not appetite
alters man loves meat his youth he cannot endure
his age shall quips sentences these paper bullets
brain awe man from career his humour no world
must peopled when said would die bachelor did not
enter beatrice
here comes beatrice by this day she's fair lady do spy
some marks love her
beat against will am sent bid come dinner

beat took no more pains those thanks than take pains
thank if had been painful would not have come
bene take pleasure then message
beat yea just so much as may take upon knives point
empty
bene ha 'against will am sent bid come dinner'
there's double meaning 'i took no more pains those
thanks than took pains thank me' that's as much as
say 'any pains take as easy as thanks' if
do not take pity her am villain if do not love her
am jew will go get her picture exit
act iii scene
leonato's orchard
hero good margaret run thee parlour
there shalt thou find cousin beatrice
proposing prince claudio
whisper her ear tell her ursley
walk orchard our whole discourse
all her say thou overheard'st us
bid her steal into pleached bower
where honeysuckles ripened by sun
forbid sun enter favourites
against power bred there will she hide her
listen our propose this thy office
bear thee well leave us alone
marg i'll make her come warrant presently exit
hero now ursula when beatrice doth come
as do trace this alley up down
our talk must only benedick
when do name him let thy part
praise him more than ever man did merit
sick love beatrice this matter
little cupid's crafty arrow made
only wounds by hearsay
enter beatrice
now begin
look where beatrice lapwing runs
close by ground hear our conference
beatrice hides arbour
urs pleasant'st angling see fish
greedily devour treacherous bait
so angle beatrice who even now
couched woodbine coverture
fear not part dialogue
hero then go near her her ear lose nothing
false sweet bait lay
they approach arbour
no truly ursula she too disdainful
know her spirits are as coy wild
urs but are sure
benedick loves beatrice so entirely
hero so says prince new trothed lord
urs did they bid tell her madam
hero they did entreat acquaint her
but persuaded them if they lov'd benedick
wish him wrestle affection
never let beatrice know
urs why did so doth not gentleman
as ever beatrice shall couch upon
hero o god love know he doth deserve
as much as may yielded man
but nature never fram'd womans heart
prouder stuff than beatrice
disdain scorn ride sparkling her eyes
misprizing what they look her wit
values itself so highly her
all matter else seems weak she cannot love
she so self endeared
urs sure think so
therefore certainly were not good
she knew his love lest she'll make sport at
hero why speak truth never yet saw man
how wise how noble young how rarely featur'd
but she would spell him backward if fair fac'd
she would swear gentleman should her sister
if black why nature drawing an antic
if low an agate very vilely cut
if speaking why vane blown all winds
if silent why block moved none
so turns she every man wrong side out
never gives truth virtue
which simpleness merit purchaseth
urs sure sure such carping not commendable
hero no not so odd from all fashions
as beatrice cannot commendable
she would mock into air o she would laugh
out myself press death wit
therefore let benedick cover'd fire
consume away sighs waste inwardly
were better death than die mocks
which as bad as die tickling
urs yet tell her hear what she will say
hero no rather will go benedick
counsel him fight against his passion
stain cousin one doth not know
how much an ill word may empoison liking
urs o do not do cousin such wrong
she cannot so much without true judgment
having so swift excellent wit
as she priz'd have as refuse
so rare gentleman as signior benedick
hero he only man italy
always excepted dear claudio
speaking fancy signior benedick
shape bearing argument valour
goes foremost report through italy
hero indeed he hath an excellent good name
urs his excellence did earn ere he had
when are married madam
hero why every day morrow come go
i'll show thee some attires have thy counsel
which best furnish morrow
urs she's lim'd warrant have caught her madam
hero if prove so then loving goes by haps
some cupid kills arrows some traps
exeunt hero ursula
beatrice advances from arbour
beat what fire mine ears can this true
stand condemnd pride scorn so much
contempt farewell maiden pride adieu
no glory lives behind back such
taming wild heart thy loving hand
if thou dost love kindness shall incite thee
bind our loves up holy band
others say thou dost deserve
believe better than reportingly exit
scene ii
room leonato's house
enter don pedro claudio benedick leonato

marriage as show child his new coat forbid him wear
will only bold benedick his company from
crown his head sole his foot he all mirth
he hath twice or thrice cut cupid's bowstring little
hangman dare not shoot at him he hath heart as sound as
bell his tongue clapper what his heart thinks
his tongue speaks
leon so say methinks are sadder

truly touch'd love if he sad he wants money

would have appear he

empty

act iv scene
church
enter don pedro john bastard leonato friar francis claudio
benedick hero beatrice attendants
leon come friar francis brief only plain form
marriage shall recount their particular duties
empty
claud no
leon married her friar come marry her
friar lady come hither married this count
hero do

not conjoined charge souls utter
claud know any hero
hero none lord
friar know any count
claud o what men dare do what men may do what men daily do not
knowing what they do
bene how now interjections why then some laughing as
ah ha he
claud stand thee by friar father by leave
will free unconstrained soul
give this maid daughter
leon as freely son as god did give her
claud what have give back whose worth
pedro nothing unless render her again
claud sweet prince learn noble thankfulness
there leonato take her back again
give not this rotten orange friend
she's but sign semblance her honour
behold how maid she blushes here
o what authority show truth
can cunning sin cover itself withal
comes not blood as modest evidence
all see her she were maid
by these exterior shows but she none
she knows heat luxurious bed
her blush guiltiness not modesty
leon what do mean lord
claud not married
not knit soul an approved wanton
leon dear lord if own proof
have vanquish'd resistance her youth
claud know what would say if have known her
will say she did embrace as husband
so extenuate forehand sin
no leonato
never tempted her word too large
but as brother his sister show'd
bashful sincerity comely love
hero seem'd ever otherwise
claud out seeming will write against
as chaste as bud ere blown
but are more intemperate blood
than venus or those pamp'red animals
rage savage sensuality
hero lord well he doth speak so wide
leon sweet prince why speak not
pedro what should speak
stand dishonour'd have gone about
link dear friend common stale
john sir they are spoken these things are true
bene this looks not nuptial
hero 'true' o god
claud leonato stand here
this prince this prince's brother
this face hero's are our eyes our own
leon all this so but what this lord
claud let but move one question daughter
by fatherly kindly power
leon charge thee do so as thou art child
hero o god defend how am beset
what kind catechising call this
claud make answer truly name
hero not hero who can blot name
any just reproach
claud marry can hero
hero itself can blot out hero's virtue
what man was he talk'd yesternight
now if are maid answer this
hero talk'd no man at hour lord
pedro why then are no maiden leonato
am sorry must hear upon honour
myself brother this grieved count
did see her hear her at hour last night
talk ruffian at her chamber window
who hath indeed most liberal villain
confess'd vile encounters they have had
john fie fie they are not nam'd lord
not spoke
there not chastity enough language
without offence utter them thus pretty lady
am sorry thy much misgovernment
claud o hero what hero hadst thou been
if half thy outward graces had been plac'd
about thy thoughts counsels thy heart
but fare thee well most foul most fair farewell
thee i'll lock up all gates love
eyelids shall conjecture hang
turn all beauty into thoughts harm
never shall more gracious
leon hath no mans dagger here point
hero swoons
beat why how now cousin wherefore sink down
john come let us go these things come thus light
smother her spirits up
bene how doth lady
beat dead think help uncle
hero why hero uncle signior benedick friar
leon o fate take not away thy heavy hand
death fairest cover her shame
may wish'd
beat how now cousin hero
friar have comfort lady
leon dost thou look up
leon wherefore why doth not every earthly thing
cry shame upon her could she here deny
story printed her blood
do not live hero do not ope thine eyes
did think thou wouldst not quickly die
thought thy spirits were stronger than thy shames
myself would rearward reproaches
strike at thy life griev'd had but one
child at frugal nature's frame
why ever wast thou lovely eyes
why had not charitable hand
took up beggar's issue at gates
who smirched thus mir'd infamy
might have said 'no part mine
this shame derives itself from unknown loins'
but mine mine lov'd mine prais'd
mine was proud mine so much
myself was myself not mine
into pit ink wide sea
hath drops too few wash her clean again
salt too little which may season give
her foul tainted flesh
bene sir sir patient
part am so attir'd wonder
know not what say
beat o soul cousin belied
bene lady were her bedfellow last night
have this twelvemonth been her bedfellow
leon confirm'd confirm'd o stronger made
which was before barr'd up ribs iron
would two princes lie claudio lie
who lov'd her so speaking her foulness
wash'd tears hence from her let her die
friar hear little
have only been silent so long
given way unto this course fortune
thousand blushing apparitions
start into her face thousand innocent shames
angel whiteness beat away those blushes
her eye there hath appear'd fire
burn errors these princes hold
against her maiden truth call fool
trust not reading nor observation
which experimental seal doth warrant
tenure book trust not age
if this sweet lady lie not guiltless here
under some biting error
leon friar cannot
thou seest all grace she hath left
she will not add her damnation
sin perjury she not denies
why seek'st thou then cover excuse
which appears proper nakedness
friar lady what man he are accus'd
if know more any man alive
than which maiden modesty doth warrant
let all sins lack mercy o father
prove any man convers'd
at hours unmeet or yesternight
maintaind change words any creature
refuse hate torture death
friar there some strange misprision princes
bene two them have very bent honour
practice lives john bastard
whose spirits toil frame villanies
leon know not if they speak but truth her
these hands shall tear her if they wrong her honour
proudest them shall well hear
time hath not yet so dried this blood mine
nor age so eat up invention
nor fortune made such havoc means
nor bad life reft so much friends
both strength limb policy mind
ability means choice friends
quit them throughly
friar pause awhile
let counsel sway this case
daughter here princes left dead
let her awhile secretly kept
publish she dead indeed
maintain mourning ostentation
hang mournful epitaphs do all rites
appertain unto burial
leon what shall become this what will this do
friar marry this well carried shall her behalf
change slander remorse some good
but not dream this strange course
but this travail look greater birth
she dying as must so maintaind
upon instant she was accus'd
every hearer so falls out
what have prize not worth
whiles enjoy but being lack'd lost
why then rack value then find
virtue possession would not show us
whiles was ours so will fare claudio
when he shall hear she died upon his words
th' idea her life shall sweetly creep
into his study imagination
shall come apparelld more precious habit
more moving delicate full life
into eye prospect his soul
than when she liv'd indeed then shall he mourn
if ever love had interest his liver
wish he had not so accused her
no though thought his accusation true
let this so doubt not but success
will fashion event better shape
but if all aim but this levelld false
supposition lady's death
will quench wonder her infamy
if sort not well may conceal her
as best befits her wounded reputation
some reclusive religious life
out all eyes tongues minds injuries
bene signior leonato let friar advise
though know inwardness love
yet by mine honour will deal this
as secretly justly as soul
should body
leon being flow grief
smallest twine may lead
friar 'tis well consented presently away
strange sores strangely they strain cure
come lady die live this wedding day
perhaps but prolong'd have patience endure
bene lady beatrice have wept all this while
beat yea will weep while longer
bene will not desire
beat have no reason do freely
bene surely do believe fair cousin wronged
beat ah how much might man deserve would right
empty
bene there any way show such friendship
beat very even way but no such friend
beat mans office but not yours
bene do love nothing world so well as not
empty
beat as strange as thing know not were as possible
say loved nothing so well as but believe not
yet lie not confess nothing nor deny nothing am sorry
cousin
bene by sword beatrice thou lovest
beat do not swear eat

ant if go thus will kill yourself
'tis not wisdom thus second grief
against yourself
leon pray thee cease thy counsel
which falls into mine ears as profitless
as water sieve give not counsel
but such one whose wrongs do suit mine
bring father so lov'd his child
whose joy her overwhelm'd mine
bid him speak patience
measure his woe length breadth mine
let answer every strain strain
as thus thus such grief such
every lineament branch shape form

patch grief proverbs make misfortune drunk
candle wasters bring him yet
him will gather patience
but there no such man brother men
can counsel speak comfort grief
which they themselves not feel but tasting
their counsel turns passion which before
would give preceptial medicine rage
fetter strong madness silken thread
no no 'tis all mens office speak patience
those wring under load sorrow
but no mans virtue nor sufficiency
so moral when he shall endure
himself therefore give no counsel
griefs cry louder than advertisement

made push at chance sufferance
