act scene
venice street
enter roderigo iago
roderigo tush never tell take much unkindly
as if strings were thine shouldst know this
iago 'sblood but will not hear
if ever did dream such matter
abhor
roderigo thou told'st thou didst hold him thy hate
iago despise if do not three great ones city
personal suit make his lieutenant
off capp'd him by faith man
know price am worth no worse place
evades them bumbast circumstance
horribly stuff'd epithets war
conclusion
nonsuits mediators certes says he
have already chose officer
what was he
forsooth great arithmetician
one michael cassio florentine
fellow almost damnd fair wife
nor division battle knows
more than spinster unless bookish theoric
wherein toged consuls can propose
as masterly as he mere prattle without practice
all his soldiership but he sir had election
whom his eyes had seen proof
at rhodes at cyprus other grounds
christian heathen must belee'd calm'd
by debitor creditor this counter caster
god bless mark his moorship's ancient
roderigo by heaven rather would have been his hangman
iago why there's no remedy 'tis curse service
preferment goes by letter affection
not by old gradation where each second
stood heir first now sir judge yourself
whether any just term am affined
love moor
roderigo would not follow him then
follow him serve turn upon him
cannot all masters nor all masters
cannot truly follow'd shall mark
many duteous knee crooking knave
doting his own obsequious bondage
wears out his time much his master's ass
nought but provender when he's old cashier'd
whip such honest knaves others there are
who trimm'd forms visages duty
throwing but shows service their lords
do well thrive by them when they have lined their coats
do themselves homage these fellows have some soul
such one do profess myself
sir
as sure as are roderigo
were moor would not iago
following him follow but myself
heaven judge not love duty
when outward action doth demonstrate
native act figure heart
complement extern 'tis not long after
but will wear heart upon sleeve
daws peck at am not what am
roderigo what full fortune does thick lips owe
if he can carry't thus
iago call up her father
rouse him make after him poison his delight
though he fertile climate dwell
plague him flies though his joy joy
yet throw such changes vexation ont
as may lose some color
roderigo here her father's house i'll call aloud
iago do timorous accent dire yell
as when by night negligence fire
spied populous cities

look house daughter bags
thieves thieves
brabantio appears above at window
brabantio what reason this terrible summons
what matter there
roderigo signior all family within

brabantio why wherefore ask this
iago 'zounds sir you're robb'd shame put gown
even now now very now an old black ram
tupping white ewe arise arise
awake snorting citizens bell
or else devil will make grandsire
arise say
brabantio what have lost wits
roderigo most reverend signior do know voice
brabantio not what are
roderigo name roderigo
have charged thee not haunt about doors
honest plainness thou hast heard say
daughter not thee now madness
being full supper distempering draughts
upon malicious bravery dost thou come
start quiet
roderigo sir sir sir
brabantio but thou must needs sure
spirit place have them power
roderigo patience good sir

house not grange
roderigo most grave brabantio
simple pure soul come
iago 'zounds sir are one those will not serve god
if devil bid because come do service
think are ruffians you'll have daughter covered
barbary horse you'll have nephews neigh you'll have
brabantio what profane wretch art thou
iago am one sir comes tell daughter
moor are now making beast two backs
brabantio thou are villain
iago are senator
brabantio this thou shalt answer know thee roderigo
roderigo sir will answer anything but beseech
if't pleasure most wise consent
as partly find fair daughter
transported no worse nor better guard
but knave common hire gondolier
gross clasps lascivious moor
if this known allowance
then have done bold saucy wrongs
but if know not this manners tell
have wrong rebuke do not believe
from sense all civility
thus would play trifle reverence
say again hath made gross revolt
tying her duty beauty wit fortunes
an extravagant wheeling stranger
here everywhere straight satisfy yourself
if she her chamber or house
let loose justice state
thus deluding
brabantio strike tinder ho
give taper call up all people
belief oppresses already
light say light exit above
iago farewell must leave
seems not meet nor wholesome place
produced as if stay shall
against moor do know state
however this may gall him some check
cannot safety cast him he's embark'd
such loud reason cyprus wars
another his fathom they have none
lead their business which regard
though do hate him as do hell pains
yet necessity present life
must show out flag sign love
which indeed but sign shall surely find him
lead sagittary raised search
there will him so farewell exit
enter below brabantio his nightgown
brabantio too true an evil gone she
what's come despised time
nought but bitterness now roderigo
where didst thou see her o unhappy girl
moor say'st thou who would father
how didst thou know 'twas she o she deceives
past thought what said she get more tapers
raise all kindred are they married think
roderigo truly think they are
fathers from hence trust not daughters' minds
by what see them act there not charms
by which property youth maidhood
may abused have not read roderigo
some such thing
roderigo yes sir have indeed
brabantio call up brother o would had had her
some one way some another do know
where may apprehend her moor
get good guard go along
brabantio pray lead at every house i'll call
may command at most get weapons ho
raise some special officers night
good roderigo i'll deserve pains exeunt
scene ii
another street
enter othello iago attendants torches
iago though trade war have slain men

throwing restraint upon us or say they strike us
why have galls though have some grace

their wives have sense them they see smell
have their palates both sweet sour
as husbands have what they do
when they change us others sport
think doth affection breed

so too have not affections
then let them use us well else let them know
ills do their ills instruct us so

cannot give vital growth again

king richard second
by william shakespeare

enter richard john gaunt other nobles attendants
king richard old john gaunt time honoured lancaster
hast thou according thy oath band
brought hither henry hereford thy bold son
here make good boist'rous late appeal
which then our leisure would not let us hear
against duke norfolk thomas mowbray
gaunt have liege
if he appeal duke ancient malice
or worthily as good subject should
some known ground treachery him
gaunt as near as could sift him argument
some apparent danger seen him
aim'd at highness no inveterate malice
king richard then call them our presence face face
frowning brow brow ourselves will hear
accuser accused freely speak
rage deaf as sea hasty as fire
enter bolingbroke mowbray
bolingbroke many years happy days befall
gracious sovereign most loving liege
mowbray each day still better other's happiness
until heavens envying earth's good hap
add an immortal title crown
king richard thank both yet one but flatters us
as well appeareth by cause come
cousin hereford what dost thou object
against duke norfolk thomas mowbray
bolingbroke first heaven record speech
devotion subject's love
tend'ring precious safety prince
free from other misbegotten hate
come appellant this princely presence
now thomas mowbray do turn thee
mark greeting well what speak
or divine soul answer heaven
thou art traitor miscreant
too good so too bad live
since more fair crystal sky
uglier seem clouds fly
once more more aggravate note
foul traitor's name stuff thy throat
wish so please sovereign ere move
what tongue speaks right drawn sword may prove
'tis not trial womans war
bitter clamour two eager tongues
can arbitrate this cause betwixt us twain
blood hot must coold this
yet can not such tame patience boast
as hush'd nought at an say
first fair reverence highness curbs
from giving reins spurs free speech
which else would post until had returnd
setting aside his high blood's royalty
let him no kinsman liege
do defy him spit at him
call him slanderous coward villain
which maintain would allow him odds
meet him were tied run afoot
even frozen ridges alps
or any other ground inhabitable
where ever englishman durst set his foot
by all hopes most falsely doth he lie
bolingbroke pale trembling coward there throw gage
disclaiming here kindred king
lay aside high blood's royalty
which fear not reverence makes thee except
if guilty dread have left thee so much strength
as take up mine honour's pawn then stoop
by all rites knighthood else
will make good against thee arm arm
mowbray take up by sword swear
which gently laid knighthood shoulder
i'll answer thee any fair degree
or chivalrous design knightly trial
when mount alive may not light
if traitor or unjustly fight
king richard what doth our cousin lay mowbray's charge
must great can inherit us
so much as thought ill him
mowbray hath receiv'd eight thousand nobles
name lendings highness' soldiers
which he hath detaind lewd employments
false traitor injurious villain
besides say will battle prove
or here or elsewhere furthest verge
ever was survey'd by english eye
all treasons these eighteen years
complotted contrived this land
further say further will maintain
upon his bad life make all this good
he did plot duke gloucester's death
suggest his soon believing adversaries
consequently traitor coward
sluic'd out his innocent soul through streams blood
which blood sacrificing abels cries
even from tongueless caverns earth
justice rough chastisement
this arm shall do or this life spent
king richard how high pitch his resolution soars
thomas norfolk what say'st thou this
mowbray o let sovereign turn away his face
bid his ears little while deaf
till have told this slander his blood
how god good men hate so foul liar
king richard mowbray impartial are our eyes cars
were he brother nay kingdom's heir
now by sceptre's awe make vow
such neighbour nearness our sacred blood
should nothing privilege him nor partialize
unstooping firmness upright soul
he our subject mowbray so art thou
free speech fearless thee allow
mowbray then bolingbroke as low as thy heart
through false passage thy throat thou liest
three parts receipt had calais
other part reserv'd by consent
sovereign liege was debt
upon remainder dear account
since last went france fetch his queen
now swallow down lie gloucester's death
slew him not but own disgrace
neglected sworn duty case
noble lord lancaster
honourable father foe
trespass doth vex grieved soul
but ere last receiv'd sacrament
did confess exactly begg'd
grace's pardon hope had
this fault as rest appeald
issues from rancour villain
recreant most degenerate traitor
which myself boldly will defend
interchangeably hurl down gage
prove myself loyal gentleman
even best blood chamber'd his bosom
haste whereof most heartily pray
highness assign our trial day
king richard wrath kindled gentlemen ruld by
let's purge this choler without letting blood
this prescribe though no physician
deep malice makes too deep incision
forget forgive conclude agreed
good uncle let this end where begun
we'll calm duke norfolk son
gaunt make peace shall become age
throw down son duke norfolk's gage
king richard norfolk throw down his
gaunt when harry when
obedience bids should not bid again
king richard norfolk throw down bid
there no boot
life thou shalt command but not shame
one duty owes but fair name
despite death lives upon grave
dark dishonour's use thou shalt not have
am disgrac'd impeach'd baffld here
pierc'd soul slander's venom'd spear
which no balm can cure but his heart blood
which breath'd this poison
king richard rage must withstood
mowbray yea but not change his spots take but shame
resign gage dear dear lord
purest treasure mortal times afford
spotless reputation away
men are but gilded loam or painted clay
jewel ten times barr'd up chest
bold spirit loyal breast
mine honour life both grow one
take honour from life done
live will die
king richard cousin throw up gage do begin
bolingbroke o god defend soul from such deep sin
shall seem crest fallen father's sight
or pale beggar fear impeach height
before this outdar'd dastard ere tongue
shall wound honour such feeble wrong
or sound so base parle teeth shall tear
slavish motive recanting fear
where shame doth harbour even mowbray's face
exit gaunt
king richard were not born sue but command
which since cannot do make friends
ready as lives shall answer
at coventry upon saint lambert's day
there shall swords lances arbitrate
swelling difference settled hate
since can not atone shall see
lord marshal command our officers at arms
ready direct these home alarms exeunt
scene 2
london duke lancaster's palace
enter john gaunt duchess gloucester
gaunt alas part had woodstock's blood
doth more solicit than exclaims
stir against butchers his life
but since correction lieth those hands
put our quarrel will heaven
who when they see hours ripe earth
will rain hot vengeance offenders' heads
duchess finds brotherhood thee no sharper spur
hath love thy old blood no living fire
edward's seven sons whereof thyself art one
were as seven vials his sacred blood
or seven fair branches springing from one root
some those seven are dried by nature's course
but thomas dear lord life gloucester
one vial full edward's sacred blood
one flourishing branch his most royal root
crack'd all precious liquor spilt
hack'd down his summer leaves all faded
by envy's hand murder's bloody axe
ah gaunt his blood was thine bed womb
mettle self mould fashiond thee
made him man though thou livest breathest
some large measure thy father's death
thou seest thy wretched brother die
who was model thy father's life
call not patience gaunt despair
suff'ring thus thy brother slaught'red
thou showest naked pathway thy life
teaching stern murder how butcher thee
which mean men entitle patience
pale cold cowardice noble breasts
best way venge gloucester's death
gaunt god's quarrel god's substitute
his deputy anointed his sight
hath caus'd his death which if wrongfully
let heaven revenge may never lift
an angry arm against his minister
duchess where then alas may complain myself
gaunt god widow's champion defence
duchess why then will farewell old gaunt
our cousin hereford fell mowbray fight
o sit husband's wrongs hereford's spear
may enter butcher mowbray's breast
or if misfortune miss first career
mowbray's sins so heavy his bosom
they may break his foaming courser's back
throw rider headlong lists
caitiff recreant cousin hereford
farewell old gaunt thy sometimes brother's wife
gaunt sister farewell must coventry
as much good stay thee as go
duchess yet one word more grief boundeth where falls
not empty hollowness but weight
take leave before have begun
sorrow ends not when seemeth done
commend thy brother edmund york
lo this all nay yet depart not so
though this all do not so quickly go
all good speed at plashy visit
alack what shall good old york there see
but empty lodgings unfurnish'd walls
unpeopled offices untrodden stones
what hear there welcome but groans
therefore commend let him not come there
seek out sorrow dwells every where
desolate desolate will hence die
last leave thee takes weeping eye exeunt
lists at coventry

so thy fortune this royal fight

if gor'd mowbray's spear
as confident as falcons flight
loving lord take leave
noble cousin lord aumerle
not sick although have do death
but lusty young cheerly drawing breath
lo as at english feasts so regreet
daintiest last make end most sweet
o thou earthly author blood
whose youthful spirit regenerate
doth twofold vigour lift up
add proof unto mine armour thy prayers
thy blessings steel lance's point
may enter mowbray's waxen coat
furbish new name john o' gaunt
even lusty haviour his son
gaunt god thy good cause make thee prosperous
swift lightning execution
let thy blows doubly redoubled
fall amazing thunder casque
rouse up thy youthful blood valiant live
bolingbroke mine innocence saint george thrive
mowbray however god or fortune cast lot
there lives or dies true king richard's throne
loyal just upright gentleman
never did captive freer heart
cast off his chains bondage embrace
his golden uncontrolld enfranchisement
more than dancing soul doth celebrate
most mighty liege companion peers
take from mouth wish happy years
as gentle as jocund as jest
go fight truth hath quiet breast

virtue valour couched thine eye
order trial marshal begin

henry hereford lancaster derby
god his sovereign him disloyal
courageously free desire
attending but signal begin
marshal sound trumpets set forward combatants
charge sounded
stay king hath thrown his warder down
king richard let them lay by their helmets their spears
withdraw us let trumpets sound
while return these dukes what decree
long flourish while king consults his council
draw near
list what our council have done
our kingdom's earth should not soild
dear blood which hath fostered
our eyes do hate dire aspect
civil wounds plough'd up neighbours' sword
sky aspiring ambitious thoughts
rival hating envy set
wake our peace which our country's cradle
draws sweet infant breath gentle sleep
which so rous'd up boist'rous untund drums
harsh resounding trumpets' dreadful bray
grating shock wrathful iron arms
might from our quiet confines fright fair peace
make us wade even our kindred's blood
cousin hereford upon pain life
till twice five summers have enrich'd our fields
shall not regreet our fair dominions
but tread stranger paths banishment
bolingbroke will done this must comfort
sun warms here shall shine
those his golden beams here lent
shall point gild banishment
king richard norfolk thee remains heavier doom
sly slow hours shall not determinate
dateless limit thy dear exile
hopeless word 'never return
breathe against thee upon pain life
mowbray heavy sentence most sovereign liege
all unlook'd from highness' mouth
dearer merit not so deep maim
as cast forth common air
have deserved at highness' hands
native english now must forgo
now tongue's use no more
than an unstringed viol or harp
or cunning instrument cas'd up
or being open put into his hands
knows no touch tune harmony
within mouth have engaold tongue
doubly portcullis'd teeth lips
dull unfeeling barren ignorance
am too old fawn upon nurse
too far years pupil now
what thy sentence then but speechless death
which robs tongue from breathing native breath
king richard boots thee not compassionate
after our sentence plaining comes too late
mowbray then thus turn from countrv's light
dwell solemn shades endless night
king richard return again take an oath thee
swear by duty owe god
our part therein banish yourselves
keep oath administer
never shall so help truth god
embrace each other's love banishment
nor never look upon each other's face
nor never write regreet nor reconcile
this louring tempest home bred hate
nor never by advised purpose meet
'gainst us our state our subjects or our land
bolingbroke swear
mowbray keep all this
bolingbroke norfolk so far as mine enemy
by this time had king permitted us
one our souls had wand'red air
banish'd this frail sepulchre our flesh
as now our flesh banish'd from this land
confess thy treasons ere thou fly realm
clogging burden guilty soul
mowbray no bolingbroke if ever were traitor
name blotted from book life
from heaven banish'd as from hence
but what thou art god thou do know
all too soon fear king shall rue
farewell liege now no way can stray
save back england an world's way exit
king richard uncle even glasses thine eyes
hath from number his banish'd years
pluck'd four away bolingbroke six frozen winters spent
return welcome home from banishment
bolingbroke how long time lies one little word
four lagging winters four wanton springs
end word such breath kings
gaunt thank liege regard
he shortens four years sons exile
but little vantage shall reap thereby
can change their moons bring their times about
oil dried lamp time bewasted light
shall extinct age endless night
inch taper will burnt done
blindfold death not let see son
king richard why uncle thou hast many years live
gaunt but not minute king thou canst give
shorten days thou canst sullen sorrow
pluck nights from but not lend morrow
but stop no wrinkle his pilgrimage
thy word current him death
but dead thy kingdom cannot buy breath
king richard thy son banish'd upon good advice
whereto thy tongue party verdict gave
why at our justice seem'st thou then lour
gaunt things sweet taste prove digestion sour
urg'd as judge but had rather
would have bid argue father
smooth his fault should have been more mild
partial slander sought avoid
sentence own life destroy'd
alas look'd when some should say
was too strict make mine own away
but gave leave unwilling tongue
against will do myself this wrong
king richard cousin farewell uncle bid him so
six years banish him he shall go
aumerle cousin farewell what presence must not know
from where do remain let paper show
marshal lord no leave take will ride
as far as land will let by side
gaunt o what purpose dost thou hoard thy words
thou returnest no greeting thy friends
bolingbroke have too few take leave
when tongue's office should prodigal
breathe abundant dolour heart
bolingbroke joy absent grief present time
gaunt what six winters they are quickly gone
bolingbroke men joy but grief makes one hour ten
gaunt call travel thou tak'st pleasure
bolingbroke heart will sigh when miscall so
which finds an enforced pilgrimage
gaunt sullen passage thy weary steps
esteem as foil wherein thou art set
precious jewel thy home return
will but remember what deal world
wander from jewels love
must not serve long apprenticehood
foreign passages end
having freedom boast nothing else
but was journeyman grief
gaunt all places eye heaven visits
are wise man ports happy havens
teach thy necessity reason thus
think not king did banish thee
but thou king woe doth heavier sit
where perceives but faintly home
go say sent thee forth purchase honour
not king exild thee or suppose
devouring pestilence hangs our air
thou art flying fresher clime
look what thy soul holds dear imagine
lie way thou goest not whence thou com'st
grass whereon thou tread'st presence strew'd
flowers fair ladies thy steps no more
than delightful measure or dance
gnarling sorrow hath less power bite
man mocks at sets light
bolingbroke o who can hold fire his hand
by thinking frosty caucasus
or cloy hungry edge appetite
by bare imagination feast
by thinking fantastic summer's heat
o no apprehension good
gives but greater feeling worse
fell sorrow's tooth doth never rankle more
than when he bites but lanceth not sore
gaunt come come son i'll bring thee thy way
had thy youtli cause would not stay
bolingbroke then england's ground farewell sweet soil adieu
mother nurse bears yet
though banish'd yet trueborn english man exeunt
scene 4
london court
enter king bagot green at one door

how far brought high hereford his way
aumerle brought high hereford if call him so
but next high way there left him
aumerle faith none except north east wind
which then blew bitterly against our faces
awak'd sleeping rheum so by chance
did grace our hollow parting tear
king richard what said our cousin when parted him
aumerle 'farewell'
heart disdained tongue
should so profane word taught craft
counterfeit oppression such grief
marry would word 'farewell have length'ned hours
added years his short banishment
he should have had volume farewells
but since would not he had none
king richard he our cousin cousin but 'tis doubt

whether our kinsman come see his friends
ourself bushy bagot here green
observ'd his courtship common people
humble familiar courtesy

our coffers too great court

our affairs hand if come short

whereto when they shall know what men are rich
they shall subscribe them large sums gold

will make ireland presently

act ii scene
london ely house
enter john gaunt sick duke york etc
gaunt will king come may breathe last
wholesome counsel his unstaid youth
york vex not yourself nor strive not breath
all vain comes counsel his ear
gaunt o but they say tongues dying men
where words are scarce they are seldom spent vain
they breathe truth breathe their words pain
he no more must say listend more
than they whom youth ease have taught glose
more are mens ends mark'd than their lives before
setting sun music at close
as last taste sweets sweetest last
writ remembrance more than things long past
though richard life's counsel would not hear
york no stopp'd other flattering sounds
as praises whose taste wise are fond
lascivious metres whose venom sound
open ear youth doth always listen
report fashions proud italy
whose manners still our tardy apish nation
limps after base imitation
where doth world thrust forth vanity
so new there's no respect how vile
then all too late comes counsel heard
where will doth mutiny wit's regard
direct not him whose way himself will choose
'tis breath thou lack'st breath wilt thou lose
gaunt methinks am prophet new inspir'd
thus expiring do foretell him
his rash fierce blaze riot cannot last
violent fires soon burn out themselves
small showers last long but sudden storms are short
eager feeding food doth choke feeder
light vanity insatiate cormorant
consuming means soon preys upon itself
this royal throne kings this scept'red isle
this earth majesty this seat mars
this other eden demi paradise
this fortress built by nature herself
against infection hand war
this happy breed men this little world
which serves office wall
or as moat defensive house
against envy less happier lands
this blessed plot this earth this realm this england
this nurse this teeming womb royal kings

christian service true chivalry
as sepulchre stubborn jewry
this land such dear souls this dear dear land
dear her reputation through world
now leas'd out die pronouncing

inky blots rotten parchment bonds

scene 2
windsor castle

cannot do yet know no cause

save bidding farewell so sweet guest
as sweet richard yet again methinks
some unborn sorrow ripe fortune's womb
coming towards inward soul
nothing trembles at some thing grieves
more than parting from lord king
which shows grief itself but not so
sorrow's eye glazed blinding tears
divides one thing entire many objects
perspectives which rightly gaz'd upon
show nothing but confusion ey'd awry
distinguish form so sweet majesty
looking awry upon lord's departure
find shapes grief more than himself wail
which look'd as nought but shadows
more than lord's departure weep not more not seen

which things true weeps things imaginary

scene 4
camp wales
enter earl salisbury welsh captain
captain lord salisbury have stay'd ten days
hardly kept our countrymen together
yet hear no tidings from king
therefore will disperse ourselves farewell
king reposeth all his confidence thee
captain 'tis thought king dead will not stay
bay trees our country are all wither'd
meteors fright fixed stars heaven
pale fac'd moon looks bloody earth
lean look'd prophets whisper fearful change
rich men look sad ruffians dance leap
one fear lose what they enjoy
other enjoy by rage war
farewell our countrymen are gone fled
as well assur'd richard their king dead exit
salisbury ah richard eyes heavy mind
see thy glory shooting star
fall base earth from firmament

witnessing storms come woe unrest
thy friends are fled wait upon thy foes
crossly thy good all fortune goes exit
bolingbroke's camp at bristol
enter bolingbroke york northumberland percy ross willoughby
bushy green prisoners
bolingbroke bring forth these men
bushy green will not vex souls
since presently souls must part bodies
too much urging pernicious lives
'twere no charity yet wash blood
from off hands here view men
have misled prince royal king
happy gentleman blood lineaments
by unhappied disfigured clean
have manner sinful hours
made divorce betwixt his queen him
broke possession royal bed
staind beauty fair queens cheeks

myself prince by fortune birth
till did make him misinterpret
have stoop'd neck under injuries
sigh'd english breath foreign clouds

whilst have fed upon signories

save mens opinions living blood
this much more much more than twice all this

scene 2
drums flourish colours enter king bishop carlisle
aumerle soldiers

after late tossing breaking seas
king richard needs must well weep joy
stand upon kingdom once again
dear earth do salute thee hand
though rebels wound thee their horses' hoofs
plays fondly her tears smiles meeting
so weeping smiling greet thee earth
do thee favours royal hands
feed not thy sovereigns foe gentle earth
nor thy sweets comfort his ravenous sense
but let thy spiders suck up thy venom
heavy gaited toads lie their way
doing annoyance treacherous feet
which usurping steps do trample thee
when they from thy bosom pluck flower
guard pray thee lurking adder
whose double tongue may mortal touch
throw death upon thy sovereigns enemies
mock not senseless conjuration lords
this earth shall have feeling these stones
prove armed soldiers ere her native king
shall falter under foul rebellions arms
carlisle fear not lord power made king
means heaven yields must embrac'd
not neglected else if heaven would
will not heavens offer refuse
proffered means succour redress
aumerle he means lord are too remiss
whilst bolingbroke through our security
grows strong great substance power
king richard discomfortable cousin know'st thou not
when searching eye heaven hid
then thieves robbers range abroad unseen
murders outrage boldly here
but when from under this terrestrial ball
he fires proud tops eastern pines
darts his light through every guilty hole
then murders treasons detested sins
cloak night being pluck'd from off their backs
stand bare naked trembling at themselves
so when this thief this traitor bolingbroke
whilst were wand'ring antipodes
shall see us rising our throne east
his treasons will sit blushing his face
not able endure sight day
but self affrighted tremble at his sin
not all water rough rude sea
can wash balm off from an anointed king
breath worldly men cannot depose
deputy elected by lord
lift shrewd steel against our golden crown
god his richard hath heavenly pay
glorious angel then if angels fight
weak men must fall heaven still guards right

act v scene 1
london street leading tower
enter queen her attendants
queen this way king will come this way
julius caesar's ill erected tower
whose flint bosom condemned lord
here let us rest if this rebellious earth
have any resting her true king's queen
enter king richard guard
but soft but see or rather do not see
fair rose wither yet look up behold
pity may dissolve dew
wash him fresh again true love tears
ah thou model where old troy did stand
thou map honour thou king richard's tomb
why should hard favour'd grief lodg'd thee
when triumph become an alehouse guest
king richard join not grief fair woman do not so
make end too sudden learn good soul
think our former state happy dream
from which awak'd truth what are
shows us but this am sworn brother sweet
grim necessity he
will keep league till death hie thee france
our holy lives must win new world's crown
which our profane hours here have thrown down
queen what richard both shape mind
transform'd weak'ned hath bolingbroke depos'd
thine intellect hath he been thy heart
lion dying thrusteth forth his paw
wounds earth if nothing else rage
o'erpow'r'd wilt thou pupil
take correction mildly kiss rod
which art lion king beasts
king richard king beasts indeed if aught but beasts
had been still happy king men
good sometimes queen prepare thee hence france
think am dead even here thou takest
as from death bed thy last living leave
winter's tedious nights sit by fire
good old folks let them tell thee tales
woeful ages long ago betid
tell thou lamentable tale
send hearers weeping their beds
why senseless brands will sympathize
heavy accent thy moving tongue
compassion weep fire out
some will mourn ashes some coal black
deposing rightful king
enter northumberland attended
northumberland lord mind bolingbroke chang'd
madam there order ta'en
all swift speed must away france
king richard northumberland thou ladder wherewithal
mounting bolingbroke ascends throne
time shall not many hours age
more than ere foul sin gathering head
shall break into corruption thou shalt think
though he divide realm give thee half
too little helping him all
plant unrightful kings wilt know again
being ne'er so little urg'd another way
pluck him headlong from usurped throne
love wicked men converts fear
fear hate hate turns one or both
worthy danger deserved death
northumberland guilt head there an end
take leave part must part forthwith
king richard doubly divorc'd bad men violate
then betwixt married wife
let unkiss oath 'twixt thee
yet not so kiss 'twas made
part us northumberland towards north
where shivering cold sickness pines clime
wife france from whence set forth pomp
she came adorned hither sweet may
sent back hallowmas or short'st day
queen must divided must part
queen banish us both send king
northumberland were some love but little policy
queen then whither he goes thither let go
king richard so two together weeping make one woe
weep thou france thee here
better far off than near ne'er near
go count thy way sighs mine groans
queen so longest way shall have longest moans
king richard twice one step i'll groan way being short
come come wooing sorrow let's brief
since wedding there such length grief
one kiss shall stop our mouths dumbly part
thus give mine thus take thy heart
queen give mine own again 'twere no good part
take keep kill thy heart
so now have mine own again gone
may strive kill groan
king richard make woe wanton this fond delay
scene 2
duke york's palace
enter duke york duchess
duchess lord told would tell rest
when weeping made break story off
our two cousins' coming into london
york where did leave
duchess at sad stop lord
where rude misgoverned hands from windows' tops
york then as said duke great bolingbroke
mounted upon hot fiery steed
which his aspiring rider seem'd know
slow but stately pace kept his course
whilst all tongues cried 'god save thee bolingbroke'
would have thought very windows spake
so many greedy looks young old
through casements darted their desiring eyes
upon his visage all walls
'jesu preserve thee welcome bolingbroke'
whilst he from one side other turning
bareheaded lower than his proud steed's neck
bespake them thus 'i thank countrymen'
thus still doing thus he pass'd along
duchess alack poor richard where rode he whilst
york as theatre eyes men
after well grac'd actor leaves stage
are idly bent him enters next
even so or much more contempt mens eyes
did scowl gentle richard no man cried 'god save him'
no joyful tongue gave him his welcome home
but dust was thrown upon his sacred head
which such gentle sorrow he shook off
his face still combating tears smiles
badges his grief patience
had not god some strong purpose steeld
hearts men they must perforce have melted
but heaven hath hand these events
whose high will bound our calm contents
bolingbroke are sworn subjects now
whose state honour aye allow
duchess here comes son aumerle
york aumerle was
but lost being richard's friend
madam must call him rudand now
am parliament pledge his truth
enter aumerle
duchess welcome son who are violets now
strew green lap new come spring
aumerle madam know not nor greatly care not
god knows had as lief none as one
york well bear well this new spring time
lest cropp'd before come prime
what news from oxford do these justs triumphs hold
aumerle aught know lord they do
aumerle if god prevent not purpose so
york what seal without thy bosom
yea look'st thou pale let see writing
aumerle lord 'tis nothing
york no matter then who see
will satisfied let see writing
aumerle do beseech grace pardon
matter small consequence
which some reasons would not have seen
fear fear
duchess what should fear
'tis nothing but some bond he ent'red into
gay apparel 'gainst triumph day
york bound himself what doth he bond
he bound wife thou art fool
boy let see writing
aumerle do beseech pardon may not show
york will satisfied let see say
treason foul treason villain traitor slave
duchess what matter lord
york ho who within there
enter servant
saddle horse
god his mercy what treachery here
duchess why york what lord
york give boots say saddle horse
exit servant
will appeach villain
duchess what matter
york peace foolish woman
duchess will not peace what matter aumerle
aumerle good mother content no more
than poor life must answer
duchess thy life answer
york bring boots will unto king
his man enters his boots
hence villain never more come sight
york give boots say
duchess why york what wilt thou do
wilt thou not hide trespass thine own
have more sons or are have
not teeming date drunk up time
wilt thou pluck fair son from mine age
rob happy mother's name
he not thee he not thine own
wilt thou conceal this dark conspiracy
dozen them here have ta'en sacrament
interchangeably set down their hands
kill king at oxford
duchess he shall none
we'll keep him here then what him
york away fond woman were he twenty times son
would appeach him
duchess hadst thou groand him
but now know thy mind thou dost suspect
have been disloyal thy bed
he bastard not thy son
sweet york sweet husband not mind
he as thee as man may
not or any kin
yet love him
york make way unruly woman exit
duchess after aumerle mount thee upon his horse
beg thy pardon ere he do accuse thee
i'll not long behind though old
doubt not but ride as fast as york
never will rise up from ground
till bolingbroke have pardond thee away gone

scene 3
windsor castle
enter bolingbroke as king percy other lords
'tis full three months since did see him last
if any plague hang over us 'tis he
would god lords he might found
inquire at london 'mongst taverns there
there they say he daily doth frequent
unrestrained loose companions
even such they say as stand narrow lanes
beat our watch rob our passengers
which he young wanton effeminate boy
so dissolute crew
percy lord some two days since saw prince
told him those triumphs held at oxford
bolingbroke what said gallant
percy his answer was he would unto stews
from commonst creature pluck glove
wear as favour
he would unhorse lustiest challenger
bolingbroke as dissolute as desperate yet through both
may happily bring forth but who comes here
enter aumerle amazed
aumerle where king
bolingbroke what means our cousin he stares looks
so wildly

have some conference grace alone

aumerle ever may knees grow earth
empty
tongue cleave roof within mouth
unless pardon ere rise or speak
bolingbroke intended or committed was this fault
if first how heinous e'er
win thy after love pardon thee
aumerle then give leave may turn key
no man enter till tale done
duke york knocks at door crieth
york within liege beware look thyself
thou hast traitor thy presence there
bolingbroke drawing villain i'll make thee safe
aumerle stay thy revengeful hand thou hast no cause fear
york within open door secure foolhardy king
shall love speak treason thy face
open door or will break open
enter york
recover breath tell us how near danger
may arm us encounter
york peruse this writing here thou shalt know
treason haste forbids show
aumerle remember as thou read'st thy promise pass'd
do repent read not name there
heart not confederate hand
york was villain ere thy hand did set down
tore from traitor's bosom king
forget pity him lest thy pity prove
serpent will sting thee heart
bolingbroke o heinous strong bold conspiracy
o loyal father treacherous son
thou sheer immaculate silver fountain
from whence this stream through muddy passages
hath held his current defild himself
thy overflow good converts bad
thy abundant goodness shall excuse
york so shall virtue his vice's bawd
he shall spend mine honour his shame
as thriftless sons their scraping fathers' gold
mine honour lives when his dishonour dies
or sham'd life his dishonour lies
thou killst his life giving him breath
traitor lives true mans put death
duchess within what ho liege god's sake let
bolingbroke what shrill voic'd suppliant makes this eager cry
speak pity open door
beggar begs never begg'd before
bolingbroke our scene alt'red from serious thing
now chang'd 'the beggar king'
dangerous cousin let mother
know she come pray foul sin
york if thou do pardon whosoever pray
more sins this forgiveness prosper may
this fest'red joint cut off rest rest sound
enter duchess
duchess o king believe not this hard hearted man
love loving not itself none other can

shall thy old dugs once more traitor rear

empty

never see day happy sees
till thou give joy until thou bid joy
by pardoning rutland transgressing boy

empty
york against them both true joints bended
empty
ill mayst thou thrive if thou grant any grace
duchess pleads he earnest look upon his face
his words come from his mouth ours from our breast
he prays but faintly would denied
pray heart soul all beside
his weary joints would gladly rise know
our knees still kneel till ground they grow
his prayers are full false hypocrisy
ours true zeal deep integrity
our prayers do out pray his then let them have
mercy which true prayer ought have
duchess do not say 'stand up'
say 'pardon first afterwards 'stand up'
an if were thy nurse thy tongue teach
'pardon should first word thy speech
never long'd hear word till now
say 'pardon' king let pity teach thee how
word short but not so short as sweet
no word 'pardon kings' mouths so meet
york speak french king say 'pardonne moy'
ah sour husband hard hearted lord
sets word itself against word
speak 'pardon as 'tis current our land
chopping french do not understand
thine eye begins speak set thy tongue there
or thy piteous heart plant thou thine ear
hearing how our plaints prayers do pierce
pity may move thee 'pardon rehearse
bolingbroke good aunt stand up
pardon all suit have hand
bolingbroke pardon him as god shall pardon
duchess o happy vantage kneeling knee
yet am sick fear speak again
twice saying 'pardon doth not pardon twain
but makes one pardon strong
bolingbroke all heart
pardon him
duchess god earth thou art
all rest consorted crew
destruction straight shall dog them at heels
good uncle help order several powers
oxford or where'er these traitors are
they shall not live within this world swear
but will have them if once know where

mother well hath pray'd prove true
duchess come old son pray god make thee new exeunt
windsor castle
enter sir pierce exton servant
exton didst thou not mark king what words he spake
'have no friend will rid this living fear'
was not so

urg'd twice together did he not

scene 5
pomfret castle dungeon castle
enter king richard
king richard have been studying how may compare
this prison where live unto world
here not creature but myself
cannot do yet i'll hammer out
brain i'll prove female soul
soul father these two beget
generation still breeding thoughts
these same thoughts people this little world
humours people this world
no thought contented better sort
as thoughts things divine are intermix'd
against word
as thus 'come little ones' then again
'it as hard come as camel
thread postern small needle's eye'
thoughts tending ambition they do plot
unlikely wonders how these vain weak nails
may tear passage through flinty ribs
this hard world ragged prison walls
they cannot die their own pride
they are not first fortune's slaves
nor shall not last silly beggars
who sitting stocks refuge their shame
many have others must sit there
this thought they find kind ease
bearing their own misfortunes back
such as have before endur'd
thus play one person many people
none contented sometimes am king
so am then crushing penury
persuades was better when king
then am king'd again by by
think am unking'd by bolingbroke
straight am nothing but whate'er
nor nor any man but man
nothing shall pleas'd till he eas'd
being nothing music plays
music do hear
when time broke no proportion kept
so music mens lives
here have daintiness ear
check time broke disorder'd string
but concord state time
had not an ear hear true time broke
wasted time now doth time waste
now hath time made his numb'ring clock
thoughts are minutes sighs they jar
whereto finger dials point
pointing still cleansing them from tears
now sir sound tells what hour
are clamorous groans which strike upon heart
which bell so sighs tears groans
show minutes times hours but time
runs posting bolingbroke's proud joy
while stand fooling here his jack clock
this music mads let sound no more
seems will make wise men mad
yet blessing his heart gives
'tis sign love love richard
strange brooch this all hating world
enter groom stable
groom hail royal prince
king richard thanks noble peer
cheapest us ten groats too dear
what art thou how comest thou hither
brings food make misfortune live
groom was poor groom thy stable king
when thou wert king who travelling towards york
much ado at length have gotten leave
look upon sometimes royal master's face
o how ernd heart when beheld
london streets coronation day
when bolingbroke rode roan barbary
horse thou so often hast bestrid
king richard rode he barbary tell gentle friend
how went he under him
groom so proudly as if he disdaind ground
king richard so proud bolingbroke was his back
jade hath eat bread from royal hand
this hand hath made him proud clapping him
would he not stumble would he not fall down
since pride must have fall break neck
proud man did usurp his back
since thou created aw'd by man
wast born bear was not made horse
yet bear burden an ass
spurr'd galld tir'd by jauncing bolingbroke
enter keeper meat
keeper fellow give place here no longer stay
king richard if thou love 'tis time thou wert away
groom tongue dares not heart shall say
empty

keeper lord dare not sir pierce exton
who lately came from king commands contrary
king richard devil take henry lancaster thee
patience stale am weary
beats keeper
keeper help help help
murderers exton servants rush armed

snatching weapon killing one
go thou fill another room hell
he kills another then exton strikes him down
hand shall burn never quenching fire
staggers thus person exton thy fierce hand
hath king's blood staind king's own land
mount mount soul thy seat up high
whilst gross flesh sinks downward here die
empty
both have spilld o would deed were good
now devil told did well
says this deed chronicled hell
this dead king living king i'll bear
take hence rest give them burial here exeunt

high sparks honour thee have seen

upon head all this famous land

nor do thee though did wish him dead

but neither good word nor princely favour

never show thy head by day nor light
lords protest soul full woe
blood should sprinkle make grow
put sullen black incontinent

wash this blood off from guilty hand
march sadly after grace mournings here

scene england
king richard third
act scene 1
london street
enter richard duke gloucester solus
made glorious summer by this sun york
all clouds lour'd upon our house
deep bosom ocean buried
now are our brows bound victorious wreaths
our bruised arms hung up monuments
our stern alarums chang'd merry meetings
our dreadful marches delightful measures
grim visag'd war hath smooth'd his wrinkled front
now instead mounting barbed steeds
he capers nimbly lady's chamber
lascivious pleasing lute
but am not shap'd sportive tricks
nor made court an amorous looking glass
am rudely stamp'd want love's majesty
strut before wanton ambling nymph
am curtaild this fair proportion
cheated feature by dissembling nature
deform'd unfinish'd sent before time
so lamely unfashionable
dogs bark at as halt by them
why this weak piping time peace
have no delight pass away time
unless spy shadow sun
descant mine own deformity
therefore since cannot prove lover
entertain these fair well spoken days
am determined prove villain
plots have laid inductions dangerous
by drunken prophecies libels dreams
set brother clarence king
deadly hate one against other
if king edward as true just
as am subtle false treacherous
this day should clarence closely mew'd up
about prophecy which says g
edward's heirs murderer shall
enter clarence guarded brakenbury
brother good day what means this armed guard
waits upon grace
clarence his majesty
tend'ring persons safety hath appointed
this conduct convey th' tower
gloucester upon what cause
clarence because name george
gloucester alack lord fault none yours
o belike his majesty hath some intent
should new christ'ned tower
but what's matter clarence may know
clarence yea richard when know protest
as yet do not but as can learn
he hearkens after prophecies dreams
from cross row plucks letter g
says wizard told him by g
his issue disinherited should
follows his thought am he
these as learn such toys as these
hath mov'd his highness commit now
gloucester why this when men are ruld by women
'tis not king sends tower
lady grey his wife clarence 'tis she
tempers him this extremity
was not she good man worship
antony woodville her brother there
from whence this present day he delivered
are not safe clarence are not safe
clarence by heaven think there no man secure
but queens kindred night walking heralds
trudge betwixt king mistress shore
heard not what an humble suppliant
lord hastings was her delivery
gloucester humbly complaining her deity
got lord chamberlain his liberty
if will keep favour king
her men wear her livery
jealous o'er worn widow herself
since our brother dubb'd them gentlewomen
are mighty gossips our monarchy
brakenbury beseech graces both pardon
his majesty hath straitly given charge
no man shall have private conference
what degree soever brother
may partake any thing say
speak no treason man say king
wise virtuous his noble queen
well struck years fair not jealous
say shore's wife hath pretty foot
cherry lip bonny eye passing pleasing tongue
queens kindred are made gentlefolks
how say sir can deny all this
brakenbury this lord myself have naught do
empty
he doth naught her excepting one
were best do secretly alone
brakenbury what one lord
gloucester her husband knave wouldst thou betray
brakenbury do beseech grace pardon
empty
forbear conference noble duke
clarence know thy charge brakenbury will
gloucester are queens abjects must obey
brother farewell will unto king
whatsoe'er will employ
were call king edward's widow sister
will perform enfranchise
meantime this deep disgrace brotherhood
touches deeper than can imagine
clarence know pleaseth neither us well
gloucester well imprisonment shall not long
meantime have patience
clarence must perforce farewell
exeunt clarence brakenbury guard
gloucester go tread path thou shalt ne'er return
simple plain clarence do love thee so
will shortly send thy soul heaven
if heaven will take present at our hands
but who comes here new delivered hastings
enter lord hastings
gloucester as much unto good lord chamberlain
well are welcome open air
how hath lordship brook'd imprisonment
hastings patience noble lord as prisoners must
but shall live lord give them thanks
were cause imprisonment
gloucester no doubt no doubt so shall clarence too
they were enemies are his
have prevaild as much him as
whiles kites buzzards prey at liberty
gloucester what news abroad
hastings no news so bad abroad as this at home
king sickly weak melancholy
his physicians fear him mightily
gloucester now by saint john news bad indeed
o he hath kept an evil diet long
overmuch consum'd his royal person
'tis very grievous thought upon
hastings he
gloucester go before will follow
exit hastings
he cannot live hope must not die
till george pack'd posthorse up heaven
i'll urge his hatred more clarence
lies well steeld weighty arguments
if fail not deep intent
clarence hath not another day live
leave world bustle
then i'll marry warwick's youngest daughter
what though killd her husband her father
readiest way make wench amends
become her husband her father
which will not all so much love
as another secret close intent
by marrying her which must reach unto
but yet run before horse market
when they are gone then must count gains exit
scene 2
london another street
enter corpse king henry sixth halberds guard
lady anne being mourner attended by tressel berkeley
anne set down set down honourable load
if honour may shrouded hearse
whilst awhile obsequiously lament
th' untimely fall virtuous lancaster
pale ashes house lancaster
thou bloodless remnant royal blood
lawful invocate thy ghost
hear lamentations poor anne
wife thy edward thy slaughtered son
stabb'd by self same hand made these wounds
lo these windows let forth thy life
pour helpless balm poor eyes
o cursed hand made these holes
cursed blood let this blood from hence
more direful hap betide hated wretch
makes us wretched by death thee
than can wish adders spiders toads
or any creeping venom'd thing lives
if ever he have child abortive
prodigious untimely brought light
whose ugly unnatural aspect
may fright hopeful mother at view
if ever he have wife let her made
more miserable by death him
than am made by young lord thee
come now towards chertsey holy load
taken from pauls interred there
still as are weary this weight
rest whiles lament king henry's corse
bearers take up coffin
enter gloucester
anne what black magician conjures up this fiend
stop devoted charitable deeds
gloucester villains set down corse or by saint paul
i'll make corse him disobeys
first gentleman lord stand back let coffin
empty
gloucester unmannerd dog stand thou when command
advance thy halberd higher than breast
or by saint paul i'll strike thee foot
bearers set down coffin
anne what do tremble are all afraid
alas blame not are mortal
mortal eyes cannot endure devil
avaunt thou dreadful minister hell
thou hadst but power over his mortal body
his soul thou canst not have therefore gone
gloucester sweet saint charity not so curst
anne foul devil god's sake hence trouble us not
filld cursing cries deep exclaims
if thou delight view thy heinous deeds
behold this pattern thy butcheries
o gentlemen see see dead henry's wounds
open their congeald mouths bleed afresh
blush blush thou lump foul deformity
'tis thy presence exhales this blood
from cold empty veins where no blood dwells
thy deeds inhuman unnatural
o god which this blood mad'st revenge his death
o earth which this blood drink'st revenge his death
either heav'n lightning strike murd'rer dead
or earth gape open wide eat him quick
as thou dost swallow up this good king's blood
which his hell governd arm hath butchered
gloucester lady know no rules charity
which renders good bad blessings curses
anne villain thou knowest nor law god nor man
gloucester but know none therefore am no beast
anne o wonderful when devils tell truth
gloucester more wonderful when angels are so angry
vouchsafe divine perfection woman
these supposed crimes give leave
by circumstance but acquit myself
anne vouchsafe diffus'd infection man
these known evils but give leave
by circumstance accuse thy cursed self
some patient leisure excuse myself
anne fouler than heart can think thee thou canst make
no excuse current but hang thyself
gloucester by such despair should accuse myself
anne by despairing shalt thou stand excused
doing worthy vengeance thyself
didst unworthy slaughter upon others
gloucester say slew them not
anne then say they were not slain
gloucester did not kill husband
anne why then he alive
gloucester nay he dead slain by edward's hands
anne thy foul throat thou liest queen margaret saw
thy murd'rous falchion smoking his blood
which thou once didst bend against her breast
but thy brothers beat aside point
gloucester was provoked by her sland'rous tongue
laid their guilt upon guiltless shoulders
never dream'st aught but butcheries
didst thou not kill this king
gloucester grant ye
anne dost grant hedgehog then god grant
thou mayst damned wicked deed
o he was gentle mild virtuous
gloucester better king heaven hath
empty
anne he heaven where thou shalt never come
empty
he was fitter place than earth
anne thou unfit any place but hell
gloucester yes one place else if will hear name
anne some dungeon
gloucester bed chamber
anne ill rest betide chamber where thou liest
gloucester so will madam till lie
anne hope so
leave this keen encounter our wits
fall something into slower method
not causer timeless deaths
these plantagenets henry edward
as blameful as executioner
anne thou wast cause most accurs'd effect
gloucester beauty was cause effect
beauty did haunt sleep
undertake death all world
anne if thought tell thee homicide
these nails should rend beauty from cheeks
gloucester these eyes could not endure beauty's
empty
should not blemish if stood by
as all world cheered by sun
so by day life
anne black night o'ershade thy day death thy life

scene 2

enter old duchess york son daughter clarence
son good grandam tell us our father dead
duchess no boy
daughter why do weep so oft beat breast
cry 'o clarence unhappy son'
call us orphans wretches castaways
if our noble father were alive
duchess pretty cousins mistake both
do lament sickness king
as loath lose him not father's death
were lost sorrow wail one that's lost
son then conclude grandam he dead
king mine uncle blame
god will revenge whom will importune
daughter so will

empty
incapable shallow innocents
cannot guess who caus'd father's death

told king provok'd by queen
devis'd impeachments imprison him
when uncle told so he wept
bade rely him as father
he would love dearly as child

virtuous vizor hide deep vice
he son ay therein shame
yet from dugs he drew not this deceit
son think uncle did dissemble grandam
duchess ay boy
son cannot think hark what noise this
ears rivers dorset after her

empty
chide fortune torment myself

myself become an enemy

edward lord thy son our king dead
why wither not leaves want their sap
if will live lament if die brief
our swift winged souls may catch king's
or obedient subjects follow him
his new kingdom ne'er changing night
duchess ah so much interest have thy sorrow
as had title thy noble husband
have bewept worthy husband's death
liv'd looking his images
are crack'd pieces by malignant death
comfort have but one false glass
grieves when see shame him
thou art widow yet thou art mother
hast comfort thy children left
but death hath snatch'd husband from mine arms
pluck'd two crutches from feeble hands
clarence edward o what cause have
thine being but moiety moan
son ah aunt wept not our father's death
how can aid our kindred tears
daughter our fatherless distress was left unmoand
widow dolour likewise unwept

am not barren bring forth complaints
all springs reduce their currents mine eyes
being governd by watery moon
may send forth plenteous tears drown world

empty

duchess what stays had but they they are gone
queen elizabeth was never widow had so dear loss
children were never orphans had so dear loss
duchess was never mother had so dear loss
their woes are parcelld mine general
she an edward weeps so do
clarence weep so doth not she
these babes clarence weep so do
an edward weep so do not they
alas three threefold distress'd
pour all tears am sorrow's nurse
will pamper lamentation
dorset comfort dear mother god much displeas'd
common worldly things 'tis called ungrateful
dull unwillingness repay debt
which bounteous hand was kindly lent
much more thus opposite heaven
requires royal debt lent

let him crownd him comfort lives

empty

which by sign thereof was termed so

found issue was not his begot

london street
enter scrivener
scrivener here indictment good lord hastings
which set hand fairly engross'd
may day read o'er pauls
mark how well sequel hangs together
eleven hours have spent write over
yesternight by catesby was sent
precedent was full as long doing
untainted unexamind free at liberty
here's good world while who so gros
cannot see this palpable device
yet who's so bold but says he sees not
bad world all will come nought
when such ill dealing must seen thought exit
scene 7
london baynard's castle

his enforcement city wives

being right idea father
both form nobleness mind
laid open all victories scotland

scene verona mantua
prologue
enter chorus
chor two households both alike dignity
fair verona where lay our scene
from ancient grudge break new mutiny
from forth fatal loins these two foes
pair star cross'd lovers take their life
whose misadventur'd piteous overthrows
doth their death bury their parents' strife
fearful passage their death mark'd love
continuance their parents' rage
which but their childrens end naught could remove
now two hours' traffic our stage
which if patient ears attend
empty
act scene

enter prince escalus his train
prince rebellious subjects enemies peace
profaners this neighbour stained steel
will they not hear what ho men beasts
quench fire pernicious rage

throw mistempered weapons ground
hear sentence moved prince
three civil brawls bred an airy word
by thee old capulet montague
have thrice disturb'd quiet our streets
made verona's ancient citizens
cast by their grave beseeming ornaments
wield old partisans hands as old
cank'red peace part cank'red hate
lives shall pay forfeit peace
this time all rest depart away

montague come this afternoon
know our farther pleasure this case
old freetown our common judgment place

exeunt all but montague his wife benvolio
mon who set this ancient quarrel new abroach
ben here were servants adversary
yours close fighting ere did approach
drew part them instant came
fiery tybalt his sword prepar'd
which as he breath'd defiance ears
he swung about his head cut winds
who nothing hurt withal hiss'd him scorn
while were interchanging thrusts blows
came more more fought part part
m wife o where romeo saw him day
right glad am he was not at this fray
ben madam an hour before worshipp'd sun
peer'd forth golden window east
troubled mind drave walk abroad
where underneath grove sycamore
westward rooteth from city's side
so early walking did see son
towards him made but he was ware
measuring his affections by own
which then most sought where most might not found
being one too many by weary self
pursu'd humour not pursuing his
gladly shunnd who gladly fled from
mon many morning hath he there been seen
tears augmenting fresh morning's dew
adding clouds more clouds his deep sighs
but all so soon as all cheering sun
shady curtains from aurora's bed
away from light steals home heavy son
private his chamber pens himself
shuts up his windows locks fair daylight
makes himself an artificial night
black portentous must this humour prove
unless good counsel may cause remove
ben noble uncle do know cause
mon neither know nor can learn him
mon both by myself many other friend
but he his own affections' counsellor
himself will not say how true
but himself so secret so close
so far from sounding discovery
as bud bit an envious worm
ere he can spread his sweet leaves air
or dedicate his beauty sun
could but learn from whence his sorrows grow
enter romeo
ben see where he comes so please step aside
i'll know his grievance or much denied
mon would thou wert so happy by thy stay
hear true shrift come madam let's away
exeunt montague wife

was father went hence so fast
ben was what sadness lengthens romeo's hours
rom not having which having makes them short

rom out
ben love
rom out her favour where am love
ben alas love so gentle his view
should so tyrannous rough proof
should without eyes see pathways his will
where shall dine o what fray was here
yet tell not have heard all
here's much do hate but more love
why then o brawling love o loving hate
o anything nothing first create
o heavy lightness serious vanity
misshapen chaos well seeming forms
feather lead bright smoke cold fire sick health
this love feel feel no love this
dost thou not laugh
ben no coz rather weep

ben at thy good heart's oppression

griefs mine own lie heavy breast
which thou wilt propagate have prest
more thine this love thou hast shown
love smoke rais'd fume sighs
being purg'd fire sparkling lovers' eyes
being vex'd sea nourish'd lovers' tears
what else madness most discreet
choking gall preserving sweet
farewell coz
ben soft will go along
an if leave so do wrong
rom tut have lost myself am not here
ben tell sadness who love
rom what shall groan tell thee
ben groan why no
but sadly tell who
rom bid sick man sadness make his will
ah word ill urg'd one so ill
sadness cousin do love woman
ben aim'd so near when suppos'd lov'd
rom right good markman she's fair love
rom well hit miss she'll not hit
cupid's arrow she hath dians wit
strong proof chastity well arm'd
from love's weak childish bow she lives unharm'd
she will not stay siege loving terms
nor bide th' encounter assailing eyes
nor ope her lap saint seducing gold
o she's rich beauty only poor
when she dies beauty dies her store
rom she hath sparing makes huge waste
beauty starv'd her severity
cuts beauty off from all posterity
she too fair too wise wisely too fair
merit bliss by making despair
she hath forsworn love vow
do live dead live tell now
ben ruld by forget think her
rom o teach how should forget think
examine other beauties
rom 'tis way
call hers exquisite question more
these happy masks kiss fair ladies' brows
being black puts us mind they hide fair
he strucken blind cannot forget
precious treasure his eyesight lost
show mistress passing fair
what doth her beauty serve but as note
farewell thou canst not teach forget
ben i'll pay doctrine or else die debt exeunt
scene ii
street
enter capulet county paris servant clown
cap but montague bound as well as
penalty alike 'tis not hard think
men so old as keep peace
par honourable reckoning are both
but now lord what say suit
cap but saying o'er what have said before
child yet stranger world
she hath not seen change fourteen years
let two more summers wither their pride
ere may think her ripe bride
par younger than she are happy mothers made
cap too soon marr'd are those so early made
earth hath swallowed all hopes but she
but woo her gentle paris get her heart
will her consent but part
an she agree within her scope choice
lies consent fair according voice
this night hold an old accustom'd feast
whereto have invited many guest
such as love among store
one more most welcome makes number more
at poor house look behold this night
such comfort as do lusty young men feel
when well apparelld april heel
limping winter treads even such delight
among fresh female buds shall this night
inherit at house hear all all see
her most whose merit most shall
which more view many mine being one
may stand number though reck'ning none

scene iv
street
enter romeo mercutio benvolio five or six other maskers torchbearers
rom what shall this speech spoke our excuse
ben date out such prolixity

scaring ladies crowkeeper
nor no without book prologue faintly spoke
after prompter our entrance
but let them measure us by what they will
we'll measure them measure gone
rom give torch am not this ambling
mer nay gentle romeo must have dance
rom not believe have dancing shoes
nimble soles have soul lead
so stakes ground cannot move
mer are lover borrow cupid's wings
soar them above common bound
rom am too sore enpierced his shaft
soar his light feathers so bound
cannot bound pitch above dull woe
mer sink should burthen love
too great oppression tender thing
rom love tender thing too rough
too rude too boist'rous pricks thorn
mer if love rough rough love
prick love pricking beat love down
give case put visage
visor visor what care
what curious eye doth quote deformities
ben come knock enter no sooner
but every man betake him his legs

tickle senseless rushes their heels
am proverb'd grandsire phrase
i'll candle holder look
game was ne'er so fair am done
mer tut duns mouse constable's own word
if thou art dun we'll draw thee from mire
up ears come burn daylight ho
rom nay that's not so
mer mean sir delay
waste our lights vain lamps by day
take our good meaning our judgment sits
five times ere once our five wits
rom mean well going this masque
but 'tis no wit go
mer why may one ask
mer so did
rom well what was yours
mer dreamers often lie
rom bed asleep while they do dream things true
mer o then see queen mab hath been
she fairies' midwife she comes
shape no bigger than an agate stone
forefinger an alderman
drawn team little atomies
her wagon spokes made long spinners' legs
cover wings grasshoppers
her traces smallest spider's web
her collars moonshine's wat'ry beams
her whip cricket's bone lash film
her wagoner small grey coated gnat
not half so big as round little worm
prick'd from lazy finger maid
her chariot an empty hazelnut
time out o' mind fairies' coachmakers
this state she 'gallops night by night
through lovers' brains then they dream love
o'er courtiers' knees dream cursies straight
o'er lawyers' fingers who straight dream fees
o'er ladies' lips who straight kisses dream
which oft angry mab blisters plagues
because their breaths sweetmeats tainted are
sometime she gallops o'er courtier's nose
sometime comes she tithe pig's tail
tickling parsons nose as 'a lies asleep
then dreams he another benefice
sometimes she driveth o'er soldier's neck
then dreams he cutting foreign throats
breaches ambuscadoes spanish blades
healths five fadom deep then anon
drums his ear at which he starts wakes
being thus frighted swears prayer or two
plats manes horses night
bakes elflocks foul sluttish hairs
which once untangled much misfortune bodes
this hag when maids lie their backs
presses them learns them first bear
making them women good carriage
this she
rom peace peace mercutio peace
thou talk'st nothing
which are children an idle brain
begot nothing but vain fantasy
which as thin substance as air
more inconstant than wind who wooes
even now frozen bosom north
being anger'd puffs away from thence
turning his face dew dropping south
ben this wind talk blows us from ourselves
supper done shall come too late
some consequence yet hanging stars
shall bitterly begin his fearful date
this night's revels expire term
despised life clos'd breast
by some vile forfeit untimely death
but he hath steerage course
direct sail lusty gentlemen
ben strike drum
they march about stage exeunt

act ii scene

when king cophetua lov'd beggar maid
he heareth not he stirreth not moveth not

scene ii
enter romeo
rom he jests at scars never felt wound
enter juliet above at window
but soft what light through yonder window breaks
east juliet sun
arise fair sun kill envious moon
who already sick pale grief
thou her maid art far more fair than she
not her maid since she envious
none but fools do wear cast off
lady o love
o she knew she were
she speaks yet she says nothing what
her eye discourses will answer
am too bold 'tis not she speaks
two fairest stars all heaven
having some business do entreat her eyes
twinkle their spheres till they return
brightness her cheek would shame those stars
as daylight doth lamp her eyes heaven
would through airy region stream so bright
birds would sing think were not night
see how she leans her cheek upon her hand
o were glove upon hand
might touch cheek
jul ay
rom she speaks
as glorious this night being o'er head
as winged messenger heaven
unto white upturned wond'ring eyes
mortals fall back gaze him
when he bestrides lazy pacing clouds
sails upon bosom air
jul o romeo romeo wherefore art thou romeo
deny thy father refuse thy name
or if thou wilt not but sworn love
rom aside shall hear more or shall speak at this
jul 'tis but thy name enemy
thou art thyself though not montague
what's montague nor hand nor foot
nor arm nor face nor any other part
belonging man o some other name
what's name which call rose
by any other name would smell as sweet
so romeo would were he not romeo calld
without title romeo doff thy name
name which no part thee
take all myself
rom take thee at thy word
call but love i'll new baptiz'd
henceforth never will romeo
jul what man art thou thus bescreend night
so stumblest counsel
rom by name
name dear saint hateful myself
because an enemy thee
had written would tear word
jul ears have yet not drunk hundred words
tongue's utterance yet know sound
art thou not romeo montague
rom neither fair saint if either thee dislike
jul how cam'st thou hither tell wherefore
orchard walls are high hard climb
if any kinsmen find thee here
rom love's light wings did o'erperch these walls
stony limits cannot hold love out
what love can do dares love attempt
therefore thy kinsmen are no let
jul if they do see thee they will murther thee
rom alack there lies more peril thine eye
than twenty their swords look thou but sweet
am proof against their enmity
rom have night's cloak hide from their sight
but thou love let them find here
life were better ended by their hate
than death prorogued wanting thy love
jul by whose direction found'st thou out this place
rom by love first did prompt enquire
he lent counsel lent him eyes
am no pilot yet wert thou as far
as vast shore wash'd farthest sea
jul thou knowest mask night face
else would maiden blush bepaint cheek
which thou hast heard speak night
fain would dwell form fain fain deny
what have spoke but farewell compliment
dost thou love know thou wilt say 'ay'
will take thy word yet if thou swear'st
thou mayst prove false at lovers' perjuries
they say jove laughs o gentle romeo
or if thou thinkest am too quickly won
i'll frown perverse say thee nay
so thou wilt woo but else not world
truth fair montague am too fond
therefore thou mayst think haviour light
but trust gentleman i'll prove more true
than those have more cunning strange
should have been more strange must confess
but thou overheard'st ere was ware
not impute this yielding light love
which dark night hath so discovered
rom lady by yonder blessed moon swear
tips silver all these fruit tree tops
jul o swear not by moon th' inconstant moon
monthly changes her circled orb
lest thy love prove likewise variable
rom what shall swear by
jul do not swear at all
which god idolatry
i'll believe thee
rom if heart's dear love
jul well do not swear although joy thee
have no joy this contract night
too rash too unadvis'd too sudden
too lightning which doth cease
ere one can say 'it lightens' sweet good night
this bud love by summer's ripening breath
good night good night as sweet repose rest
come thy heart as within breast
rom o wilt thou leave so unsatisfied
jul what satisfaction canst thou have night
rom th' exchange thy love's faithful vow mine
jul gave thee mine before thou didst request
yet would were give again
rom would'st thou withdraw what purpose love
jul but frank give thee again
bounty as boundless as sea
love as deep more give thee
more have both are infinite
hear some noise within dear love adieu
nurse calls within
anon good nurse sweet montague true
stay but little will come again exit
rom o blessed blessed night am afeard
being night all this but dream
enter juliet above
jul three words dear romeo good night indeed
if thy bent love honourable
thy purpose marriage send word morrow
by one i'll procure come thee
where what time thou wilt perform rite
all fortunes at thy foot i'll lay
follow thee lord throughout world
nurse within madam
do beseech thee
nurse within madam
jul by by come
cease thy suit leave grief
morrow will send
rom so thrive soul
jul thousand times good night exit
rom thousand times worse want thy light
love goes toward love as schoolboys from their books
enter juliet again above
jul hist romeo hist o falconer's voice
lure this tassel gentle back again
bondage hoarse may not speak aloud
else would tear cave where echo lies
make her airy tongue more hoarse than mine
repetition romeo's name
empty
rom soul calls upon name
softest music attending ears
jul romeo
rom dear
jul at what o'clock morrow
shall send thee
rom by hour nine
jul will not fail 'tis twenty years till then
have forgot why did call thee back
rom let stand here till thou remember
rememb'ring how love thy company
rom i'll still stay have thee still forget
forgetting any other home but this
jul 'tis almost morning would have thee gone
yet no farther than wantons bird
lets hop little from her hand
poor prisoner his twisted gyves
silk thread plucks back again
so loving jealous his liberty
jul sweet so would
yet should kill thee much cherishing
good night good night parting such sweet sorrow
shall say good night till morrow
empty

would were sleep peace so sweet rest
hence will ghostly father's cell
his help crave dear hap tell
scene iii
friar laurence's cell
enter friar laurence alone basket
friar grey ey'd morn smiles frowning night
check'ring eastern clouds streaks light
flecked darkness drunkard reels
from forth day's path titans fiery wheels
non ere sun advance his burning eye
day cheer night's dank dew dry
baleful weeds precious juiced flowers
earth that's nature's mother her tomb
what her burying gave her womb
from her womb children divers kind
sucking her natural bosom find
many many virtues excellent
none but some yet all different
o mickle powerful grace lies
plants herbs stones their true qualities
but earth some special good doth give
nor aught so good but straind from fair use
revolts from true birth stumbling abuse
virtue itself turns vice being misapplied
vice sometime's by action dignified
within infant rind this small flower
poison hath residence medicine power
this being smelt part cheers each part
being tasted slays all senses heart
man as well as herbs grace rude will
where worser predominant
full soon canker death eats up plant
enter romeo
rom good morrow father
friar benedicite
what early tongue so sweet saluteth
young son argues distempered head
so soon bid good morrow thy bed
where care lodges sleep will never lie
but where unbruised youth unstuff'd brain
doth couch his limbs there golden sleep doth reign
therefore thy earliness doth assure
thou art uprous'd some distemp'rature
or if not so then here hit right
our romeo hath not been bed night
rom last true sweeter rest was mine
friar god pardon sin wast thou rosaline
have forgot name name's woe
friar that's good son but where hast thou been then
rom i'll tell thee ere thou ask again
have been feasting mine enemy
where sudden one hath wounded
that's by wounded both our remedies
within thy help holy physic lies
bear no hatred blessed man lo
intercession likewise steads foe
riddling confession finds but riddling shrift
rom then plainly know heart's dear love set
fair daughter rich capulet
as mine hers so hers set mine
all combind save what thou must combine
by holy marriage when where how
met woo'd made exchange vow
i'll tell thee as pass but this pray
thou consent marry us day
rosaline thou didst love so dear
so soon forsaken young mens love then lies
not truly their hearts but their eyes
jesu maria what deal brine
hath wash'd thy sallow cheeks rosaline
how much salt water thrown away waste
season love doth not taste
sun not yet thy sighs from heaven clears
thy old groans ring yet mine ancient ears
an old tear not wash'd off yet
if e'er thou wast thyself these woes thine
thou these woes were all rosaline
art thou chang'd pronounce this sentence then
women may fall when there's no strength men
rom thou chid'st oft loving rosaline

scene v
enter romeo juliet aloft at window
jul wilt thou gone not yet near day
was nightingale not lark

believe love was nightingale
rom was lark herald morn

some meteor sun exhales
thee this night torchbearer

therefore stay yet thou need'st not gone
rom let ta'en let put death

'tis but pale reflex cynthia's brow
nor not lark whose notes do beat
vaulty heaven so high above our heads
have more care stay than will go
come death welcome juliet wills so
how is't soul let's talk not day
jul hie hence gone away
lark sings so out tune
straining harsh discords unpleasing sharps
this doth not so she divideth us
some say lark loathed toad chang'd eyes
o now would they had chang'd voices too
since arm from arm voice doth us affray
hunting thee hence hunt's up day
o now gone more light light grows
rom more light light more dark dark our woes

therefore out thy long experienc'd time

'twixt extremes this bloody knife
